description: Seminar on graduate school and career opportunities by guest speakers.

title: Career Pathways Seminar
description: Seminar on graduate school and career opportunities by guest speakers.

title: Career Prep--Ling, ELING, E&P
description: Finding and interpreting job advertisements related to linguistics. Explaining skills of linguistics major to employers. Students should take near the end of their major.

title: Career Prep
description: Discussion of the variety of potential careers for economics majors and how to best prepare for those careers.

title: Career Skills 1
description: Professional communication skills for job search.

title: Career Skills 2
description: Technical and business presentation skills.

title: Career Skills in Math
description: This course prepares math students to apply for jobs and internships in business, industry, tech, government labs, and academia.

title: Careers in Biomed Sciences
description: Lectures and field trips surveying career choices.

title: Careers in CS
description: Career advising for students in computer science. Advice on resumes, applications, and interviews for internships, full-time jobs, and graduate school. Opportunities to network with other students and with employers.

title: Careers in Environmntl Science
description: Career guidance and exposure to the multi-discipline fields of environmental science including resume building, internship placement, and professional networking.

title: Careers in Food Science
description: Guest lectures and exposure to vocations in food science.

title: Careers in Mus Ed
description: Examining preschool through college teaching career options in music; seeking a good fit between personal aspirations, attributes, skills, and job requirements.

title: Carillon
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice.

title: Cartographic Desgn
description: Graphic perception, layout, typography, color, statistical methods, and symbolization of thematic maps through computer-aided techniques.

title: Case Conference
description: Case presentations; professional, ethical, and research issues pertinent to assessment and intervention.

title: Case Studies
description: Contemporary agricultural and environmental problems using decision case studies dealing with  environmental technology issues and analysis.

title: Cash Management & Investments
description: Cash-management systems, policies, and processes in the public-sector; banking services and relationships; and the investment of idle funds.

title: Catullus
description: In-depth study of the poetry of Catullus.

title: Aircraft Structures
description: Requirements, objectives, loads, materials, and tools for design of airframe structures; static behavior of thin-wall structures; durability and damage tolerance; certification and testing. Airframe component team design project.

title: Composite Structures
description: Design and analysis of advanced composite structures; deflections, buckling, and vibration of thin plates and sandwich plates; design guidelines; design examples; project.

title: Computer Struc Optimization
description: Matrix stiffness method for 1D, 2D, and 3D skeletal structure classes.  Implementing the matrix stiffness method as a computer program.  Nonlinear second-order structural analysis.  Structural optimization techniques including stress-ratio method, gradient-based methods, and genetic algorithms.

title: CAE Software Development
description: Programming methods for the development of engineering software. Data structures, architecture, libraries, and graphical user interfaces, with applications to CAD systems.

title: Continuum & Solid Mechanics
description: Derivation of partial differential equations of continuum mechanics. Closed-form solution of classical problems in elasticity. Theory of beams, plates, and axisymmetric shells with closed-form solutions. Large displacement strain tensors, stress tensors, equilibrium equations, beam theory, and plate theory. Constitutive theory including nonlinear elasticity, viscoelasticity, plasticity, and hyperelasticity.

title: Design & Materials Applicatns
description: Applied and residual stress; materials selection; static, impact, and fatigue strength; fatigue damage; surface treatments; elastic deflection and stability--all as applied to mechanical design.

title: Linear Finite Element Methods
description: Linear static finite element analysis of elastic solids; problem formulation, finite element discretization, and equation solving; stability, interpolation theory, and error estimates. Introduction to underlying continuum mechanics principles. Isogeometric analysis as a generalization of classical finite element analysis; basic principles of analysis-suitable computational geometry. Introduction to the industrial practice of finite element modeling leveraging commercial packages. Topics include CAD preprocessing, an overview of the mesh generation process and simulation model setup, and how to effectively use appropriate solution strategies for a given problem. Application domains include strength and durability, vibrations, transient structural dynamics, and multi-physics problems.

title: Nonlinear Finite Element Mthds
description: Nonlinear dynamic finite element analysis of solids. Nonlinear continuum mechanics, finite element formulation, and elementary solution algorithms for nonlinear algebraic problems, focusing on hyperelastic solids. Advanced topics in isogeometric analysis, computational analysis-suitable geometry, and adaptivity. An introduction to dynamics; basic methods of time integration, such as Newmark and "a

title: Optimization Techniques
description: Application of computational optimization techniques to constrained engineering design.  Theory and application of gradient-based and gradient-free algorithms for unconstrained and constrained nonlinear problems.  Robust design methods.

title: Structural Vibrations
description: Dynamic analysis of single degree-of-freedom, discrete multi-degree-of-freedom, and continuous systems. Applications include aerospace, civil structures, and mechanical components.

title: Spectral Analysis Dynamic Sys
description: Digital signal processing and analysis applied to computer-aided testing, system identification, and characterization of random processes. Applications include vibration and acoustic testing, seismic recording and analysis, and system identification for control.

title: Stress Analysis & Design
description: Stress analysis and deflection of structures; general bending and torsion with computer applications to mechanical and aerospace structure design.

title: Cell Biology
description: Fundamentals of cell structure and function with reference to analytical methods used by cell biologists. Practice in designing, executing, and interpreting relative experiments.

title: Cell Bio & Physiology Seminar
description: Seminar (research) presentations for undergraduates in cell biology and physiology.

title: Cell Bio & Physiology Teaching
description: Undergraduate student lecture or laboratory teaching assistantship, or other activities that provide students hands-on curriculum design, teaching, and mentoring experiences.

title: Cell Bio: Adv Princip/Methods
description: Advanced principles and contemporary developments in cell biology. Dynamic relationships between cell structure and the biochemical reactions that are necessary for cell growth, differentiation, survival, and death with an emphasis on eukaryotic cells. Research methodologies in cell biology are emphasized.

title: Cello
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice

title: Biophysics
description: Using electrophysiology and biophysics as an approach to study of physiology. Extensive look at ion channels and cell signaling.

title: Cellular Neuroscience
description: Critical examination of the cellular and molecular bases of nervous system function and development.

title: Elections and Democracy Lab
description: Discuss and critique emerging research. Propose, execute, present, and critique undergraduate research projects relevant to American elections and governance.

title: Central Utah Writing Project
description: Develop a writer's identity, engaging in all levels of the writing process through instructional methods, presentations, consistent practice, and publishing.

title: Ceramics
description: Designing, throwing, hand forming, decorating, glazing, and firing techniques.

title: Ceramics Fundamentals
description: Foundation ceramics.

title: CFA Preparation
description: Preparation to take Level I of the Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) Exam. Topics covered on the exam, and with which students will be able to demonstrate strong proficiency, include: corporate finance, economics, financial reporting and analysis, quantitative methods, alternative investments, derivatives, equity investments, fixed income, and portfolio management and wealth planning.

title: Change Management
description: Theory and practice of change in organizations.

title: Character Dance
description: Beginning character dance technique representing various traditional European dance styles.

title: Character Design
description: This course focuses on concepts and projects dealing with the creation of characters, both realistic and imaginary. Using both traditional and digital techniques, students will apply appropriate artistic direction as practiced throughout the field of illustration.

title: Character Mask
description: Use of the body as a primary tool for character and script interpretation.

title: Charitable Organizations
description: Practical and theoretical concerns in organizing and representing nonprofit or tax-exempt entities.

title: Business Career Essentials
description: Introduction for science, math, and statistics majors to careers in industry. Project planning, oral and written business presentations, business accounting, and technology readiness.

title: Ch En - Health, Safety, Envir
description: Responsibility of chemical engineers in society relative to ethics, leadership, safety, environment, and energy.

title: Ch En for Chemistry Students
description: Intensive treatment of fundamentals of material and energy balances, fluid flow, and heat and mass transfer, with application to design and analysis of engineering systems.

title: Plant Design & Synthesis
description: Design of chemical engineering processes and plants; requiring application of unit operations, chemical process principles, economic analysis.  Synthesis and optimization of chemical processes.

title: Ch En Problem Solving
description: Experiential learning in complex problem solving of industrial scale projects.

title: Ch En Thermodynamics
description: First and second laws of thermodynamics as applied to behavior of real fluids; physical and chemical equilibrium.

title: Chem Handling & Safe Lab Prac
description: Safe handling of chemicals and safe practices in chemistry laboratories.

title: Chemical Process & Fluids Lab
description: Walk-in laboratory course covering topics from Material and Energy Balances and Fluid Mechanics.

title: Chemical Process Principles
description: Material and energy balances.

title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
description: Fundamental principles and equations of chemical kinetics and reactor design.

title: Chemical Stabilization
description: Stabilizer types, soil-stabilizer reaction chemistry, stabilizer concentration determination, construction considerations, performance of stabilized soils, laboratory experimentation.

title: Chemical Thermodynamics
description: Development of the principles of chemical thermodynamics, including laws, pure materials, mixtures, equilibria, and elementary statistical mechanics.

title: Child Advocacy
description: Learn about the juvenile court system and how issues of abuse, neglect and delinquency are handled. Learn how the judicial system affects the lives of children and how advocates can make a difference in the system. Opportunity to "shadow" attorneys from the Guardian Ad Litem's office, the Public Defender's and Attorney General's offices, and to sit in court with a Juvenile Court Judge. Students will tour the Detention Center, the House of Hope, Independence High School, Lightening Peak, Family Support and Treatment and the Children's Justice Center.

title: Child & Adol Psychotherapy
description: Theory and treatment techniques of child and adolescent therapy.

title: Child Soc-Emo Assess & Interv
description: Theory of assessment and intervention for youth with behavioral, social, and emotional problems. Evidence-based interventions focusing on individual, group, and school-wide application. Assessments are aligned with DSM-V and IDEA identification systems. Interventions focus on evidence-based practice.

title: Child Life
description: Roles of child life specialists in preparing children and families for healthcare experiences. Content includes psychosocial and developmental needs of children, adolescents, and families in healthcare settings and impact of illness, injury, and hospitalization on the child and family.

title: Child Neuropsychology
description: Overview of basic concepts and methods in the neuropsychological assessment of child, adolescent, and pediatric populations, including recognizing quantitative and qualitative aspects of test performance and behaviors most relevant to diagnosis.

title: Child Psychopathology
description: Mental disorders of childhood.

title: Children & the Law
description: Issues relating to state regulation of parent-child relations, including children's rights, parent rights, juvenile courts, adoption, health decisions, educational decisions, child abuse and neglect, youth status offenses, and delinquency.

title: Children's Literature
description: Trends and titles in children's and adolescent literature. Reading and critiquing as well as practical uses of children's literature in both school and home.

title: Children's Media
description: Historical and theoretical survey of media for and about children and the literature that informs it; discussions and strategies relating to production, reception, pedagogy, and parenting.

title: China Since 1200
description: Economic and political foundations of modernity during high Imperial China; challenge of new order from the West; rise of Chinese nationalism, revolution, and development to the present.

title: China: Government & Politics
description: Structure and behavior of politics; contemporary problems.

title: Chinese Calligraphy
description: Training in the art of writing Chinese characters with a brush.

title: Chinese Cultural History
description: Methods and approaches of the cultural historian; in-depth investigation of a selected topic in Chinese cultural history. Topics may include women, Silk Roads, material culture, etc.

title: Chinese Culture
description: Selected topics in traditional, modern, and contemporary Chinese culture.

title: Chinese Culture & Society
description: Cultural and social institutions of traditional and modern China, including mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, or other areas of Chinese impact.

title: Chinese Film in Translation
description: Survey course covering the silent era to the present, including selections from Republican China, the People's Republic of China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong.

title: Chin Foreign Polcy
description: Structure and process of foreign policy of the People's Republic of China.

title: Chin Lang Tchg Procedures
description: Acquiring knowledge and skills specific to teaching Chinese as a foreign language. Conducted in Chinese and English.

title: Chin Lit inTranslation--Poetry
description: All readings in English; topics vary.

title: Chin Lit inTranslation-Prose
description: All readings in English; topics vary.

title: Chinese Poetry
description: Readings in Chinese poetry. Topics vary from classical and modern poetry. Various themes and genres introduced, emphasizing shi poetry.  Texts in Chinese.

title: Translation & Interpretation
description: Translation techniques, with practice in oral and written translation either from Chinese to English or from English to Chinese.

title: Choral Arranging
description: Study of published choral arrangements, as well as techniques for adapting and arranging for choirs.

title: Choral Conducting & Develop
description: Principles and practices of score preparation, conducting, and choral development as elements of choral artistry.

title: Choral Conducting Techniques
description: Physical techniques and musical understanding required to conduct a choral performance ensemble.

title: Choral Literature 1
description: Concentrated analytical study and application of choral literature through Beethoven.

title: Choral Literature 2
description: Concentrated analytical study and application of choral literature from post-Beethoven to the present.

title: Choreographic Styles
description: Physical and conceptual aspects of dance styles as they relate to music dance theatre.

title: Christian History and Theology
description: Background and history of Christianity from the first century A.D. to the Reformation with an added emphasis on theological themes and developments.

title: US Church & State
description: U.S. and international religious liberty issues. Focuses on free exercise and establishment clauses of First Amendment.

title: Northeast Field Studies
description: Experiential learning course that offers an on-site study of historical events, foundational revelations, doctrines, and people relevant to the unfolding restoration of the LDS Church in New England, New York, and Pennsylvania from the early 1600s until 1831.

title: Cicero
description: Selections from the works of Cicero.

title: Cinema & Culture in India
description: Anthropology of film in India; the world's largest film industry.  Indian cultural and linguistic diversity.  How different film genres reflect, distort, or utilize Indian cultural diversity.  Evidences in the film work of Satyajit Ray.

title: Circuits
description: Analysis of electric circuits including transients, sinusoidal steady-state, and power. Includes labs.

title: Citizen Nation
description: Exploration of how American definitions of citizenship have evolved from the founding era to the 21st century. Examines the definition, meaning, and the rights, privileges, and responsibilities of citizenship.

title: Civic Engage Leadership
description: Promote leadership in civic engagement through discussion of community involvement and public service, lectures from external speakers, and development of a hands-on project involving some form of public service.

title: Civil Engr Seminar
description: Technical and professional activities in civil engineering.

title: Civil Discovery
description: Students will learn about the discovery process in civil litigation, including depositions, the production of documents, interrogatories, requests for admissions, mandatory disclosures, subpoenas, expert witnesses, and electronic discovery.

title: CE Business Operations
description: Different legal forms of business ownership, business performance metrics, accounting, business development, marketing, operations management, market forces and competition and business strategy.

title: Civil Engineering Design
description: Comprehensive two-semester Civil Engineering culminating design experience based on the knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work and incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

title: Concrete, Masonry, & Asphalt
description: Composition, engineering behavior, and construction of concrete, masonry, and asphalt; laboratory testing.

title: Metals, Woods, & Composites
description: Molecular basis and mechanical behavior of civil engineering structural materials; failure theories; laboratory testing.

title: Civil Engineering Practice
description: Comprehensive two-semester design experience. Topics include writing an effective resume, creating effective teams, developing and achieving team goals, engineering ethics, writing a project scope and reporting on progress.

title: CE Project Management
description: Managing diversity, building effective teams, team coaching, evaluations, managing conflict and conflict resolution, project management approaches, risk management, critical path, partnering, managing outside consultants, staffing, negotiations, and principles of leadership.

title: Civil Engr Seminar
description: Activities of civil engineering; principles and methods involved in solving civil engineering problems.

title: Civil  Engr Seminar
description: Technical and professional activities in civil engineering.

title: Civil Engr Seminar
description: Technical and professional activities in civil engineering.

title: Civil Engr Seminar
description: The course will make graduate students familiar with the processes, procedures, and forms required for graduation. The course will expose graduate students to current research through presentations by faculty and outside experts. The students will learn to survey literature pertinent to their research topics and summarize these works in their prospectus. The course will introduce writing tools and provide instruction on writing style, organization, and content.

title: Civil Engr Seminar
description: Activities of civil engineering; principles and methods involved in solving civil engineering problems.

title: Civil Engr Seminar
description: Technical and professional activities in civil engineering.

title: Civil Infrastructure Const
description: Develop a project bid proposal for a heavy civil project, including the project estimate, schedule, and risk analysis. Utilize heavy civil contract documents including civil infrastructure plan sets, specifications, and geotechnical reports.

title: Civil Procedure
description: A basic study of the operation of courts, including an introduction to the organization of state and federal courts and relationships between them. Topics studied will include jurisdiction over persons, things, and subject matter; venue; the scope of litigation as to claims, defenses, and parties; pleading, pretrial motions, discovery, and pretrial conferences; trials and the functions of judges, juries, and lawyers; appeals and the role of appellate courts; and the enforcement and finality of judgments and decrees.

title: Civil Rights
description: Focuses on the current importance and application of the civil rights laws enacted after the Civil War and in the modern civil rights era. These laws provide the essential foundation for modern litigation on a wide range of constitutional and statutory protections and provide the basis for federal and private enforcement of statutory civil rights protections.

title: Civil Rights Seminar
description: Introduction to the major figures, events, and locations of the Civil Rights Movement in America, with a focus on the 1950s and 1960s. Includes a field trip to civil rights historical sites in Georgia and Alabama.

title: Civil Rights Skills Practicum
description: Civil Rights litigation under section 42 U.S.C. § 1983 (Section 1983) has played a key role in reforming governmental agency operations and the provision of public services. Section 1983 allows citizens to bring suit against governmental agencies and their officers for deprivations of federal constitutional and statutory rights.  A key focus of the course will be on police and prison official misconduct. Will allow students to integrate legal doctrine, theory, professional lawyering skills and legal ethics through in-class simulation experiences.

title: Civil Trial Practice 1
description: The skill of interviewing, drafting, negotiating, and using time efficiently in the context of preparing a legal matter; carrying a case through all the stages of preparation and litigation.

title: Civil Trial Practice 2
description: The skills of interviewing, drafting, negotiating, and using time efficiently in the context of preparing a legal matter; carrying a case through all the stages of preparation and litigation.

title: Civil War Era
description: Causes of the war, major military events (leaders, campaigns, soldiers), war on the home fronts, why the South lost, Reconstruction, the legacy of the war.

title: Civil Wars & Ethnic Violence
description: Foundations of ethnic and nationalist identities and how they related to civil wars worldwide, emphasizing theoretical explanations of civil wars and their resolution.  Key civil war cases examined.

title: Civilization: Literature 1
description: Western civilization from antiquity to early Italian Renaissance, emphasizing socioeconomic, political, intellectual, and aesthetic developments, with primary focus on literary texts.

title: Civilization: Literature 2
description: Western civilization from Europe's high Renaissance to the present, emphasizing socioeconomic, political, intellectual, and aesthetic developments, with primary focus on literary texts.

title: Civilization: Music 1
description: History of civilization from Greek antiquity through the seventeenth century, primarily from perspective of musical literature and the arts; exploring fundamental questions in human experience; examining formative events in history; understanding value of important texts.

title: Civilization: Music 2
description: History of civilization from the eighteenth century through the present day, primarily from perspective of musical literature and the arts; exploring fundamental questions in human experience, examining formative events in history; understanding value of important texts.

title: Civilization: World Lit 1
description: Major world civilizations, with an emphasis on comparative study of Asian and other non-Western traditions with Western traditions, from antiquity to 1500 AD, emphasizing socioeconomic, political, intellectual, and aesthetic developments, with primary focus on literary texts.

title: Civilization: World Lit 2
description: Major world civilizations, with an emphasis on comparative study of Asian and other non-Western traditions with Western traditions, from 1500 AD to the present, emphasizing socioeconomic, political, intellectual, and aesthetic developments, with primary focus on literary texts.

title: Greek History
description: Political, economic, social, and intellectual history of Greece from Mycenaean times to the Hellenistic period.

title: Clarinet
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice

title: Class Inequality
description: Causes and consequences of class, status, and power differences.

title: Classical & Literary Chinese
description: Introduction to syntax and stylistic patterns.

title: Classical & Literary Chinese
description: Introduction to syntax and stylistic patterns.

title: Classical & Medieval Pol Phil
description: Examine selected topics, periods, and figures in social and political philosophy with an aim to understand and apply theories to particular problems and questions.

title: Classical Arabic Texts
description: Quran, Hadith, Sira, Adab.

title: Classical Archaeology
description: Major excavations and antiquities of the Mediterranean region illustrating Greco-Roman history.

title: Classical Greek Poetry
description: Advanced Greek poetry through Homer's Iliad.

title: Classical Greek Prose
description: Advanced Attic Greek through prose authors.

title: Classical Korean (Hanmun)
description: Reading of premodern, documentary Sino-Korean texts, including genealogy records and the Chosŏn Dynasty Annals.

title: Classical Latin Poetry
description: Selections from Vergil's Aeneid and Ovid's Metamorphoses.

title: Classical Latin Prose
description: Readings in Cicero's Catilinarian orations and Sallust's Catiline.

title: Classical Applied Mathematics
description: Classical techniques in applied mathematics and their application to specific problems. The primary focus is on dimensional analysis and asymptotic methods for differential equations as well as asymptotic evaluation of integrals.

title: Classical Music in Pop Culture
description: Surveys the interactions between classical music and popular culture, using methodologies and approaches drawn from anthropology, sociology, media studies, cultural studies, ethnomusicology, and reception theory.

title: Clscl Rhet & Crit
description: Foundational texts in literary theory from ancient Greece and Rome.

title: Classical Social Theory
description: Philosophical foundations of sociological theory; works of major classical theorists such as Marx, Weber, Durkheim, Simmel, Mead, DuBois, Addams, and Parsons.

title: Classical Voice
description: Speech techniques (word stress, inflection, pitch, pace, etc.) applied in the classical play.

title: Classical Voice
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice.

title: Clssrm as Culture&Knowldg Syst
description: Classrooms as culture and knowledge systems and how those systems are created and sustained over time.

title: Classroom Management
description: Current theory, research, and application in classroom management; creating positive teacher-student and peer relationships; developing optimal learning environments.

title: Classroom Management
description: Topics vary.

title: Class & Lab management
description: Current theory, research, and application in classroom management; creating positive teacher-student and peer relationships; developing optimal learning environments.

title: Classroom Mgt & Lab Safety
description: Current theory, research, and application in classroom management; creating positive teacher-student and peer relationships; developing optimal learning environments.

title: Management & Practicum 1
description: This course is one of two required classroom management and practicum courses in the EL ED program. ELED 299R is intended to provide (a) foundational understanding of key elements in creating and maintaining a nurturing, effective, and productive learning environment; and (b) context for preservice teachers to apply the content, methodology, and skills they are learning on campus in real classroom settings with children/youth under the guidance of a mentor classroom teacher and a university clinical supervisor from the EL Ed program. Students will participate in on campus preparation classes, weekly support classes, and extensive time in elementary school classrooms.

title: Management & Practicum 2
description: Instruction on establishing community, personal management philosophy, severe/chronic misbehavior, systems of management, and the BYU-PSP Commitments. Clinical experience includes observation, practice, and reflection in a K-6 grade classroom.

title: Clscs & Engl Trad
description: Major works by such authors as Homer, the Greek and Roman tragedians, Thucydides, Vergil, and Petronius in English translation, emphasizing their influence on English and American literature.

title: Roman History
description: Political, economic, social, and intellectual history of Rome from the foundation of the city to Constantine.

title: Air Quality & Transportation
description: Evaluate climate and air quality impacts of transportation systems through data collection, data analysis and model application.

title: Climate & the Earth System
description: Chemical, physical, and biological processes shaping the Earth's surface and climate, emphasizing quantitative methods for measuring and evaluating contemporary climate and environmental changes relative to the last several thousand years.

title: Global Climate Change
description: Global climate change, including the scientific basis, cultural context, policy options, and spiritual implications.

title: Clinic Prac in School Psych.
description: Hands-on interdisciplinary clinical experiences to complete a psychoeducational assessment case under licensed supervision. Cases shared with Communications Disorders graduate students and supervisors in the BYU Speech and Language Clinic.

title: Clinical Alliance
description: Live-client interactions in field placements under the supervision of seasoned practitioners. Emphasis on the development of professional skills, including legal research and writing, counseling, interviewing, negotiation, mediation, and problem solving.

title: Clinical & Educational Admin
description: Administration and management practices and issues in athletics, athletic training, medicine, and various education settings. Ethical, moral legal, communication, and professional etiquette are core concepts discussed.

title: Clinical Biomechanics
description: Advanced biological and mechanical perspectives into the etiology, diagnosis, and therapeutic resolution of common musculoskeletal disorders.

title: Clinical Chemistry
description: Laboratory diagnosis of disorders involving the major systems of the human body with clinical chemistry.\n

title: Clinical Experience
description: Students will perform the full range of clinical laboratory tests in an affiliated clinical facility.  A variable option of 16 to 24 weeks with a minimum of one semester of enrollment.

title: Clinical Internship
description: Full-time training at approved mental health agency.

title: Clinical Internshp
description: Full-time family therapy training and practice at an approved agency.

title: Clinical Microbiol
description: Approaches to laboratory diagnosis of infectious diseases.

title: Clinical Neuropsychology
description: Comprehensive study of the human dysfunctional brain.

title: Clinical Parasitology Lab
description: Pathogenesis, diagnosis, and epidemiology of human parasitic diseases laboratory.

title: CPE Practicum
description: Supervised encounters with persons in crisis.  Experiencing the interdisciplinary team process of helping persons.  Developing skill in interpersonal and interprofessional relationships and a deeper understanding of ministry.

title: Clinical Phonetics
description: Transcription and analysis of normal and disordered sound production.

title: Clinical Practice in Dietetics
description: Supervised practice in clinical dietetics.

title: Clinical Practices in SSD
description: Survey of theoretical perspectives in phonological development and practical views of the etiology, assessment, and treatment of speech sound disorders. Examining relationships between phonology, language, and literacy development. Course material is presented in relation to traditional and current approaches to clinical intervention. Relevant research will also be reviewed and discussed.

title: Clinical Practicum #1
description: First clinical rotation in health promotion and disease prevention; diagnosing and managing patients across the lifespan with psychosocial and physiological alterations in health, with performance at the novice level.

title: Clinical Practicum #2
description: Second clinical rotation in health promotion and disease prevention; diagnosing and managing patients across the lifespan with psychosocial and physiological alterations in health at the intermediate level.

title: Cl Prac Adults in Crisis
description: Clinical practicum in the nursing interventions and care for individuals and families in crisis.

title: Cl Prac Capstone Nurs
description: Clinical practicum focusing on planning, delivering, and managing patient care in complex environments.  Leadership components incorporated into clinical experiences and practices.

title: Cl Prac Acute/Chronic Illness
description: Clinical practicum is an active learning course in which students apply nursing knowledge and skills in hospitals/clinical settings with adult patients and families and simulated learning experiences in the Nursing Learning Center.

title: Cl Prac Women & Newborns
description: Clinical practicum in the nursing care of childbearing families from diverse backgrounds.  Health promotion, assessment, and interventions related to complicated and uncomplicated pregnancy and birth.  Includes lab and simulation experiences.

title: Cl Prac Psych/Mental Hlth Nurs
description: Clinical practicum in the nursing care for clients with complex psychiatric disorders.

title: Cl Prac Nurs Fundamentals
description: 1.5 credit clinical practicum course focuses on in-person, active application of fundamental nursing concepts and skills with patients in skilled nursing facilities and simulated learning experiences in the Nursing Learning Center.

title: Cl Prac Glob & Pop Hlth Nurs
description: 4-credit to 6-credit clinical practicum focuses on global and population-based nursing perspectives and implementation of an action plan in various local and international settings.

title: Cl Prac Children
description: 1-credit, clinical practicum course focuses on the acquisition and application of basic nursing skills with children and families in in-patient hospital settings and simulated learning experiences by adapting nursing knowledge and care to pediatric patients.

title: Clinical Psychology
description: Personality theories, psychopathology, diagnostic interviewing and testing, psychotherapy techniques; research methods.

title: Clinical Research
description: Overview of research examining processes and outcomes of psychological treatments for psychological disorders.

title: Clog Dance Technique 2
description: Fundamentals of advanced Clogging and PowerTap techniques.

title: Clogging Dance Int Tech 1
description: Fundamentals of intermediate Clogging and PowerTap technique.

title: Cloud Architecture & Security
description: Fundamentals of building and securing IT infrastructure in the cloud. Covers architectural and security design patterns, infrastructure as code, optimization, reliability, and pricing, in a variety of contexts.

title: Topics: Greek & Roman History
description: Study of the history of Greece and Rome through the examination of primary Greek and Latin historiographical texts and secondary scholarship. Topics vary.

title: Topics: Ancient Greek History
description: Study of the history of Greece through the examination of primary Greek historiographical texts and secondary scholarship. Topics vary.

title: Topics: Ancient Roman History
description: Study of the history of Rome through the examination of primary Latin historiographical texts and secondary scholarship. Topics vary.

title: CMOS  Amp Design
description: Factors affecting performance of MOS devices in analog applications. Design of MOS amplifiers, buffers, and comparators.

title: Coaching Baseball & Softball
description: Theory, fundamentals, strategies, and techniques of coaching baseball and softball.

title: Coaching Basketball
description: Theory, fundamentals, strategies, and techniques of coaching basketball.

title: Coaching Competitive Swimming
description: Theory, fundamentals, strategies, and techniques of coaching swimming.

title: Coaching Football
description: Theory, fundamentals, strategies, and techniques of coaching football.

title: Coaching Selected Sports
description: Theory, fundamentals, strategies, and techniques for coaching sports sanctioned by the Utah High School Athletic Association.

title: Coaching Soccer
description: Theory, fundamentals, strategies, and techniques of coaching soccer.

title: Coaching Track & Field
description: Theory, fundamentals, strategies, and techniques of coaching track and field.

title: Coaching Volleyball
description: Theory, fundamentals, strategies, and techniques of coaching volleyball.

title: Coal Comb
description: Fundamentals of coal combustion and gasification processes, including particle mechanics, devolatilization, heterogeneous oxidation, radiative heat transfer, and combustion of coal in practical flames.

title: Coding for Genetic Analysis
description: Practical training in computational analysis of moderately-sized molecular biology datasets. Introduction to coding and graphics analysis in R and shell.

title: Coding for Tech & Engr Educat
description: Students will become familiar with and be able to use various coding languages needed to teach middle and high school technology and engineering courses.

title: Cognition
description: Perceptual organization; information processing; cognitive development; relationships between sensory analysis, perception, memory, learning, language, and problem solving.

title: Cognition & Brain Function
description: Basic principles of cognition and affect as they relate to normal brain function and following neural disease or injury.

title: Cognitive&Affective Processes
description: Theory and research in perception, attention, language, problem solving, and other thinking processes.

title: Cognitive Comm Disorders
description: Assessment and treatment of cognitive communication disorders associated with acquired brain injury.

title: Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy
description: Theory, treatment principles, and techniques of cognitive-behavioral therapy.

title: Collaboration
description: Foundations in collaborating with school professionals, para-professionals, and families of children with disabilities.

title: Collaborative Design Projects
description: This class invites students to collaborate with students from other majors in creating products, experiences, systems, and services together. Naturally, students will draw on their domains of expertise, but collaboration in this class should not be limited to each studentâ€™s discipline. Instead, collaboration should compound their team membersâ€™ strengths through frequent collaboration, iteration, and validation across disciplines.

title: Collab Des: Brand & Strategy
description: Well-designed interactive products become most successful when they account for the complete context of their creation: from business strategy and brand narrative to well-crafted interfaces and targeted end goals. Consequently, the best products require collaboration between various domains working toward a common goal. Every student in this class will gain rich experience in developing a brand and strategy for a real-world product or business creation.

title: Collab Leadership for Change
description: Collaborative leadership theories and practices leading to meaningful change in educational organizations and institutions at the micro through macro levels.

title: Collab. UX Design: Discovery
description: Students will seek and validate new ideas for their collaborative projects in this course. In addition, they will develop strategies for idea creation and discovery-based research that will inform the more profound study and work they will complete in subsequent Collaborative UX Design classes.

title: Collab. UX Design: Implement.
description:
Well-designed interactive products become most successful when they account for the complete context of their creation: from business strategy and brand narrative to well-crafted interfaces and targeted end goals. Consequently, the best products require collaboration between various domains (designers, software engineers, and product managers) working toward a common goal. Every student in this class will gain a rich experience in real-world product creation.

You are invited to think of yourself as more than designers but as co-founders, not just students but entrepreneurs. For you and your teams, collaboration should not be limited to each memberâ€™s own domain of expertise and should compound your team membersâ€™ strengths through frequent collaboration, iteration, and validation.

title: Collab. UX Design: Research
description:
Well-designed interactive products become most successful when they account for the complete context of their creation: from business strategy and brand narrative to well-crafted interfaces and targeted end goals. Consequently, the best products require collaboration between various domains (designers, software engineers, and product managers) working toward a common goal. Every student in this class will gain a rich experience in real-world product creation.

Students are invited to think of themselves as more than designers but as co-founders, not just students but entrepreneurs. For you and your teams, collaboration should not be limited to each memberâ€™s own domain of expertise and should compound your team membersâ€™ strengths through frequent collaboration, iteration, and validation.

title: College Algebra
description: Functions, polynomials, theory of equations, exponential and logarithmic functions, matrices, systems of linear equations, permutations, combinations, binomial theorem.

title: Student Council
description: Active involvement on the student council for the College of Life Sciences. Issues facing students in the college explored and solutions suggested.

title: College Reading & Study Skills
description: Learning strategies to improve reading speed and to understand materials used in university classes.

title: Colloq in Comparative Studies
description: Introduction to graduate studies and academia. Focus on development of professional skills, intensive writing, and exposure to a range of academic fields, subfields, and faculty specializations.

title: Colloquium in Natural Science
description: Not a valid course. Only to be used to apply credits to General Education requirements.

title: Coll in Soc & Behavioral Sci
description: Not a valid course. Only to be used to apply credits to General Education requirements.

title: Colonial US Fam Hist Research
description: Advanced research class covering records, historical background, paleography, and methodologies for reconstructing individual families and development of family history studies in colonial North America, including British, French, Spanish, and other European colonies.

title: Combinatorics
description: Permutations, combinations, recurrence relations, applications.

title: Combinatorics & Graph Theory
description: A proof-based introduction to discrete mathematics, including substantial treatment of both enumerative combinatorics and graph theory. Activities include writing and reading proofs, considering examples and counterexamples, and categorizing discrete mathematical structures.

title: Combustion
description: Introduction to first- and second-law ideal gas combustion systems along with elementary models of homogeneous and heterogeneous premixed and/or diffusion flames.

title: Comb Model
description: Theory of combustion systems and quantitative procedures for computing performance of combustion chambers.  Applications include turbulent combustion of gases, sprays, and particulates.

title: Comb Proc
description: Fundamentals of transport processes in reacting flow systems with specific applications of various combustion processes.

title: Comedy
description: History and theory of comedy.

title: Commercial Music Capstone Proj
description: Creating a demo CD and resume from course work, creative project, and internship experiences.  Career goals and opportunities.

title: Commercial Music Special Proj
description: Projects vary.

title: Commercial Real Estate Mgt
description: Fundamentals of commercial real estate investment, understanding market influences, contracts and property portfolio management.

title: Commercializing Innovation
description: Commercializing innovations in interdisciplinary teams to bring innovative solutions to customers in the market.

title: Communication in Public Admin
description: Crucial communication skills for managers and leaders in public and not-for-profit organizations.  Emphasis on writing and oral presentations.

title: Comm Mgt Principles & Theory
description: Management principles and theory, emphasizing responsible management benefiting organizations and their stakeholders. Approaches may include crisis communication, media or agency management, and programming.

title: Comm. Tech & Systems
description: Use of, interaction with, and teaching about communication, technologies.

title: History & Hist Rsrch Methods
description: In-depth investigation of the history of mass media, including study of historical research methods.

title: Comms Practicum
description: Practice and projects in communication.

title: Research Methods
description: In-depth exploration of a qualitative or quantitative research design and methodology used in communications/social science research.

title: Community & Economic Dev Rep
description: Students participate in simulated exercises on transactional matters which are commonly addressed through local community/economic development and redevelopment efforts. Students will have the opportunity to role play advising clients.

title: Community & Ecosyst Ecology
description: Integrating ecological and biogeochemical concepts to understand the structuring of biological communities and ecological systems. Topics include community assembly, trophic dynamics, systems biology, ecosystem services, and biodiversity-ecosystem function.

title: Comm Engage & Lead in Music
description: Opportunities to grow as versatile artists, arts advocates, and global artist citizens through collaboration, community engagement, and student-led entrepreneurial projects.

title: Festivals and Events
description: Equipping students with relevant knowledge and skills to design and implement community festivals and other special events.

title: Community Lawyer
description: Christian reconstruction of the lawyer's role in public life, especially how that role is performed among the disadvantaged.

title: Community Nutrition
description: Public health nutrition applied to community programs.

title: Commutative Algebra
description: Commutative rings, modules, tensor products, localization, primary decomposition, Noetherian and Artinian rings, application to algebraic geometry and algebraic number theory.

title: Comprtv & Intrnl Devpmnt Educ
description: Substance and methods of comparative and international development education.  How comparisons between systems have implicit in them a theory of comparisons of politics and economics.  The role of multilateral aid agencies in influencing the development of schooling.

title: Comparative Animal Nutrition
description: Comparative digestion, absorption, and utilization of nutrients and nutritional applications of domestic, pet, and wildlife species.

title: Comparative Animal Physiology
description: We will compare different animals' anatomical and physiological solutions to organismal needs (e.g., energy metabolism, sensory processes, reproduction, etc.) considering their different environments and evolutionary pressures.

title: Comparative Constitutnl Law
description: Introduction to the major systems of constitutional judicial review outside the United States with a focus on equal protection, separation of powers, constitutional interpretation, and fundamental rights.

title: Comparative Genomics
description: Analysis and interpretation of eukaryotic genomes in a comparative context. Theory behind commonly used methods for comparing whole genomes, such as read alignment, whole genome alignment, orthology prediction, variant calling, detection of positive selection, and phylogenomic analysis. Second of a two-course series.

title: Comparative Governmnt&Politics
description: Patterns of European, Asian, Latin American, and other political systems.

title: Comp Intl Soc Wel
description: Social welfare policies of various countries. Solving global social problems within framework of human rights directives.

title: Comparative Law
description: Non-common-law legal tradition, emphasizing civil law.  Legal traditions of Islamic and socialist countries.

title: Comp. Parties and Elections
description: Analyzes the electoral process and political parties in both the United States and other countries. Special attention is given to gender issues, campaigns, financing, corruption, extremist parties, religion, class, issues, fairness, accountability, electoral rules, and democracy.

title: Comparative Political Econ
description: Overview of political economy from a comparative perspective. Classic theorists (Smith, Marx, Schumpeter, etc.); classic questions (industrialization, national economic policy, property, globalization, law, and economics).

title: Compensation and Benefits
description: The use of total rewards--compensation and benefits--to help organizations gain and sustain a competitive advantage in a global environment. Designed to help new managers and HR professionals make important compensation and benefits decisions, and know how to do vital compensation and benefits activities.

title: Compnstn, Benefits, & Perf Mgt
description: Wage and salary administration, incentives, employee benefits, grievance and discipline systems, performance appraisal.

title: Competitive Strategy
description: Advanced course in competitive strategy for dynamic markets. Exploring topics such as growth, competitor analysis, positioning, and real options. Employing frameworks such as rugged landscapes, Schumperterian competition, and evolutionary economics to develop strategic options.

title: Strategy Analytics
description: The application of??various tools in micro-economic theory (demand, cost, production, oligopoly, game, etc.), strategic frameworks (strategic groups, portfolio analysis, diagnostic tools, etc.), and statistical analysis (regression, factor, cluster, etc.) to provide students with a broad exposure to the kinds of strategic analysis that yield key insights for managers engaged in the work of strategy. Applications fall into categories of competition, customers, costs, and capabilities.??Beyond the development of analytical skills, the course also aims to provide practice in delivering strategic insights to managers by assigning students to work on a project for a company of their choosing.

title: High-Perf Systems Comp
description: Compilation and synthesis strategies for high-performance hardware/software systems.

title: Complex Analysis
description: Introduction to theory of complex analysis at beginning graduate level. Topics: Cauchy integral equations, Riemann surfaces, Picard's theorem, etc.

title: Complex Litigation
description: Building on the basic civil procedure course by focusing on the substantive doctrines and procedural requirements relating to complex litigation in the United States, including class actions, multidistrict litigation, and other high-stakes litigation. Topics to be covered include but are not limited to certification of a class, removal, joinder, transfer, settlement, and federal statutes relating to class actions.

title: Complex Organizations
description: Theoretical approaches and empirical studies of organizations, their structures, processes, and problems; studies of industrial organizations, universities, hospitals, etc.

title: Complex SLA Research Designs
description: Investigate current research and design strategies related to language acquisition.

title: Compliant Mechanisms
description: Design and analysis of compliant mechanisms and compliant structures. Large-deflection analysis/force displacement relationships; mechanisms synthesis.

title: Composer-Performer Studies
description: Study of the theory and practice of the hybrid composer-performer through research into prominent composer-performers, discussion and formulation of composer-performer theory, and application of these ideas in musical projects.

title: Composite Material Design
description: Macro- and micro-mechanical analysis and design of uni- and multidirectional composite materials.

title: Composition
description: Introduction to principles of recent art music; composition and performance of student works for one to five instruments.

title: Composition 2
description: Invention and exploration of sound, control of multivoiced textures and larger forms, and recent art music.

title: Composition Pedagogy
description: Practicum for graduate students teaching First-Year Writing courses.

title: Composition Seminar.
description: Seminars in principles and techniques of recent art music.

title: Comprehension Instruction
description: Topics vary.

title: Compressible Fluid Flow
description: One-dimensional analysis of compressible flow with area change, friction, heat transfer, shock waves, and combined effects, including experimental methods.

title: Computational Cancer Biology
description: Examine the altered cellular phenotypes of cancer through a computational exploration of molecular and clinical data, comparing and contrasting different cancer types.

title: Computational Creativity
description: Project-based course for understanding creativity as a way to increase the robustness of intelligent systems while applying AI/ML tools to challenging problems.

title: Comput Fluids & Heat Transfer
description: Fluid dynamics and heat transfer analysis by numerical methods. Theory and implementation of finite difference and finite volume methods.

title: Computational Linear Algebra
description: Practical linear algebraic computations and applications.

title: Computational Methods
description: Computational techniques for solving problems in civil engineering and construction.

title: Computational Methods
description: Numerical methods and statistics for engineers, implemented using software and computer programming

title: Computational Neuroimaging
description: Development of skills in basic command line operations in the Unix environment that are specific to neuroimaging design and analysis.

title: Computational Physics
description: Practical and theoretical aspects of computational physics. Theoretical foundations of computation. Numerical recipes for scientific computing. Best practices for scientific computing.

title: Computational Physics Lab 1
description: Introduction to numerical and symbolic computation and graphical analysis using a symbolic mathematics program.  Applications to mechanics, optics, and special relativity.

title: Computational Physics Lab 2
description: Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations with applications to dynamics and chaos.  Introduction to scientific programming.

title: Computational Physics Lab 3
description: Computational study of static and dynamic boundary value problems, partial differential equations, linear algebra, and eigenvalues. Applications such as electrostatics, thermodynamics, waves, and quantum mechanics.  Computational tools to store, share, and analyze data, including machine learning.

title: Computational Tools
description: Use of spreadsheets, advanced equation-solving packages, and structured languages to solve engineering problems.  Introduction to chemical process principles.

title: Computer Application in Art Ed
description: Basic program applications for developing instructional materials in art education.

title: Comp Applications Studio-Photo
description: Individual photography project using high-end hardware and software.

title: Computer Architecture & Org
description: Principles of computer hardware and instruction set architecture.  Subjects include:  internal CPU organization and implementation, peripheral interconnect and IO systems, and low-level programming and security issues.

title: Comp Comms & Networking
description: Introduction to data communications and computer networking.  Communications fundamentals, computer networks, software, architecture, telecommunications, regulation, standards.

title: Computer Graphics
description: Interactive computer graphics systems programming and architecture.

title: Computer Networks
description: Learn the principles and practices of network protocols used on the Internet. Develop software that interfaces with computer networks. Examine networking challenges such as reliability, security, and privacy.

title: Computer Organization
description: Architecture, organization and design of computer systems, including assembly language programming, computer arithmetic, instruction execution, performance analysis, pipelining, memory hierarchy, and the design of datapath and control logic.

title: Computer Organization
description: Architecture, organization and design of computer systems, including assembly language programming, computer arithmetic, instruction execution, performance analysis, pipelining, memory hierarchy, and the design of datapath and control logic.

title: Computer Program Kinesiol
description: Course designed to teach students to manage the large amounts of data collected during various analyses of human movement through computer programming. Students will also learn how to create their own software for data analysis.

title: Computer Security
description: Introduction to computer security fundamentals: confidentiality, integrity, authentication, and access control. Secret key and public key cryptography, network security protocols, viruses, and fire walls.

title: Computer System Reliability
description: Analysis, modeling, and design of reliable, fault-tolerant computing systems.

title: Computer Systems
description: Machine-level representations of programs and data, processor architecture, program performance optimization, memory hierarchies, virtual memory, linking, exceptions.

title: Computer Systems Lab
description: Experience building complex computer system that interact with humans and computer networks. Practice principles of computer systems and systems programming on a combination of software and hardware.

title: Computer Vision
description: Introduction to fundamental concepts and algorithms of computer vision, including feature extraction, detection, segmentation, registration, recognition, motion, 3D vision, and image understanding. Applies techniques from image processing, geometry, Bayesian methods, optimization, and machine learning to computer vision problems.

title: Computer-Aided Manufacturing
description: Manual and computer-assisted programming of computer numerical controlled (CNC) equipment. Developing CNC programs to manufacture parts for high production.

title: Computer-Assisted Translation
description: Exploration of computer-assisted translation technology and how it is used to solve problems concerning translation quality, speed, and freedom of content.

title: Computer-Based Practice System
description: Teaches students to use document automation tools to develop automated legal documents and practice systems, and examines how these knowledge tools are used to improve legal service delivery.

title: Computer-Mediated Comm
description: Students will develop skills needed to study the intersection of human communication, personal relationships, and communication technologies. In particular, students will be able to engage with key theoretical issues associated with communication in social media contexts. Further, they will evaluate influential research on creativity, organization, politics, virality, interpersonal communication, identity, representation, and civility, and apply them to online social interaction. The innovative ideas addressed in this seminar will equip media scholars and professionals with the grounding necessary to determine the best practices to use when communicating via emergent media technologies.

title: Cmptrs in Ed Measurement
description: Types of computerized measurement and assessment methods and item forms, as well as their development, delivery, and statistical theory.

title: Computers in Hist Rsrch & Publ
description: Use of computer programs and the internet in researching family, local, and social history; including programs and techniques for publishing.

title: Computing Competitions
description: Students work in teams to prepare for and compete in computer science competitions in areas such as programming, data science, and ethical hacking.

title: Apps in Lab Medicn
description: Case presentations of various medical disorders.

title: Concept Design
description: Illustration methods and processes applied to visual problems in collaborative, creative development for interactive entertainment production. Faculty-led teams research, visualize and render original compositions to convey narratives through character and world design.

title: Concepts & Princ. of Beh. 1
description: Introduction to the current issues and research behind the principles, concepts, and experimental foundation of behavior analysis.

title: Princ. of Beh. 2: Verbal Beh.
description: Introduction to the conceptual, philosophical, and experimental foundations of verbal behavior, providing students with a strong conceptual foundation when encountering applied problems. Expansion on the philosophical foundation, conceptual analysis, and principles of behavior. Exploration of the special meaning of verbal behavior in terms of stimulus control, generalization, and role of the listener. This course is a part of the BCBA Verified Course Sequence.

title: Concepts of Chemistry
description: The chemical nature of the world and the process of scientific inquiry.  Application to critical scientific issues facing society.

title: Concepts of Math
description: Concept-oriented exploration of rational numbers and proportional reasoning, probability, and early algebraic reasoning in relation to children's learning.

title: Concepts of Programng Lang
description: Principles and concepts characterizing high-level computer programming languages, process and data abstration, encapsulation, inheritance, functional programming, logic programming, scanners, and parsers.

title: Illustration 3
description: Conceptual illustration problems and market applications, using various media.

title: Concept. Pract & Creative Expl
description: This course serves as a critical examination of the photographic medium as a form of visual communication and creative expressionâ€”an exploration that will come about mainly through readings, discussions, and image-making activities.

title: Concrete, Masonry, and Asphalt
description: Managing concrete, masonry, and asphalt construction including estimating, controls, quality, and safety.

title: Conditioning
description: Dance 230 is designed on the principles of experiential learning in physical exercise, mental practice and spiritual reflection.

title: Rsrch in Second Lang Tchg
description: Reviewing, understanding, and evaluating published research; designing quantitative and qualitative research studies; using basic statistical procedures for analyzing data; writing a research prospectus conforming to APA style guidelines.

title: Conflict of Laws
description: Jurisdiction issues, choice of law, and recognition of judgments in cases involving interstate and state-federal conflicts.

title: Conflict Resolution
description: Learn how to resolve conflict more effectively and build peace on the interpersonal, national, and international levels. Includes gospel perspectives and practical strategies and theories on negotiation and peace building, and explores conflict in politics, gender, and race.

title: Conflict Resolution Mgt
description: Modern techniques associated with resolution of conflicts surrounding natural resources.

title: Congress & Legislative Process
description: Election process; structure, organization, and procedures of legislative bodies; relations with pressure groups, the president, and executive branch.

title: Con & Col Lat Amer
description: Pre-Columbian civilizations, Iberian exploration and conquest of the New World, and colonial development of Hispanic and Portuguese America from 1492 to 1823.

title: Conservation Genomics
description: Introduction to conservation genetics and genomics. Fundamental concepts in conservation genetics taught in a modern context through the analysis of data derived from cutting-edge genomic technologies.

title: Conservation of Carnivores
description: Life histories of representative carnivores with political, popular, and managerial problems surrounding their existing and proposed conservation.

title: Const Law-Am Federal System
description: Students will discuss the institutional issues surrounding US government structures, specifically the rights and powers of the President, Congress, the judiciary, states, and individuals.

title: Const Law-Rights & Immunities
description: Students will learn about some of the most important parts of American politics, the US Supreme Court and its decisions as well as the historical development of the most important legal doctrines of the Supreme Court.

title: Constitutional Law and Educ
description: Impact of Constitution on education in America; cases under constitutional law that have influenced policy and practice in the educational system.

title: Constitutional Research
description: The United States Constitution; research on original sources used to create the Constitution.

title: Construction Accounting
description: Cost and managerial accounting topics for construction companies, including break-even analysis, ratio analysis, capital budgeting, job cost systems, master budgets pricing and decision-making, allocating costs.

title: Const Co Developmt
description: Advanced topics in the development of construction companies, including strategic planning, negotiations, banking relations, successful companies, risk management, productivity, trending and forecasting, zoning and development, entitlements, career balance, and sub-contract and resource management.

title: Const. Co. Financial Mgt.
description: An in-depth review of management concepts and financial strategies needed to successfully grow and enhance profitability of a construction company. Topics include business entities, budgeting and cash management, finance and investments, accounting, financial statements, cost controls (variance and earned value analysis), real estate investing, taxation, break even analysis and capital budgeting.

title: Constr Comp Opers and HR
description: Managing human resources in construction companies including hiring, firing, retention, training and employee development motivation, incentives, personality profiles and company culture.

title: Const Company Operatns & Mgt
description: Organizing, controlling, and directing operations of construction companies; financial management, budgeting, cash-flow analysis, purchasing and cost control, and business planning.

title: Construction Law
description: Contractual literacy and the role of contracts in communication, risk assignment, legal compliance, and setting expectations between parties.  Related themes of liability analysis, ethics, negotiation and conflict resolution are also explored.  Key legislation and government organizations/agencies are reviewed related to construction, development, and associated businesses.

title: Const Innovation & Tech
description: Students in the course will study the current political, regulatory, technological, environmental, and leadership trends and issues related to construction management.

title: Construction Modeling
description: Developing architectural plans using Building Information Modeling; floor, foundation, plot, elevations, sections, and details. Renderings and other advanced modeling techniques.

title: Const Project Mgt & Control
description: Managing and controlling construction projects. Planning, startup procedures, inspections, progress measurements, field reports, change order and submittal processing, equipment management, and project closeout.

title: Construction Safety
description: Protecting the lives and well being of employees is a value. Students learn safety requirements and responsibilities in construction; the cost and impact of accidents; accident investigation; safety inspection; hazards analysis; record keeping; and instituting a culture of safety.

title: Const Scheduling & Cost Contrl
description: Planning, scheduling, and monitoring construction projects, including development and implementation of critical path networks, management controls, and reporting mechanisms. Modern scheduling software is also applied through a culminating portfolio project.

title: Construction Surveying
description: Construction surveying and layout using traditional as well as advanced tools and techniques. Hands on training with construction survey tools including: hand tools, leveling instruments, total stations, robotic total stations, global positioning systems, and developing surveying technologies.

title: Consult W/Sch &Fam
description: Models and methods of consultation with teachers, parents, and professionals.

title: Consulting Field Study
description: Working as a team with faculty and management in strategic consulting projects for local, national, and international business.

title: Consulting Project Management
description: Work as project leads for introduction to management consulting class projects.

title: Consumer Behavior
description: Improving managerial decisions by gaining an in-depth understanding of consumers.  Topics include transproduct consumer needs, perception, information processing, persuasion, decision-making, and post-consumption evaluation.

title: Consumer Behavior
description: Mental and emotional processes and physical actions that people engage in when selecting, purchasing, using, and discarding products and services to satisfy consumer needs and desires.

title: Consumerism and the Market
description: A pre-service preparation course designed to prepare FACSED classroom teachers to teach content regarding dynamics of consumerism and the marketplace and develop skills for implementing a discipline-based approach for teaching consumerism in secondary schools.

title: Contaminant Hydrogeology
description: Principles, tools, and applications used to solve heavy metal, organic, and radionuclide groundwater contamination problems.  Topics include regulations, mass transport, multiphase flow, transformation, retardation, and attenuation.

title: Contemporary Theory
description: Anthropological theory from the late 20th century to the present. Current theoretical concerns of anthropology. Theoretical frameworks and how these theories can inform master's thesis research.

title: Contemporary Art
description: Critical evaluation of trends in art since 1945.

title: Contemporary Chinese Liter
description: Contemporary literature of Taiwan and the PRC. Texts in Chinese.

title: Contemporary Culture
description: Contemporary Spanish (or Spanish- American) culture: the people and their customs and institutions.

title: Contemporary Culture
description: Contemporary Portuguese or Brazilian culture: the people and their customs and institutions.

title: Contemporary Dance Theatre
description: Contemporary modern dance performing company. Performs on campus and tours regionally, nationally and internationally.

title: Contemp. France, Francophone
description: Current cultural, political, and social trends and issues in France as well as in the francophone world.

title: Contemporary Issues
description: Eligibility issues for intercollegiate student athletes. Skills relating to academic performance and career selection.

title: Contemp Issues in Educ Ldrshp
description: Developing problem-solving skills in understanding and resolving educational issues affecting schools.

title: Contemp Issues in Ed Leadershp
description: Major issues, theories, and policies affecting education today emphasizing U.S. public education.  Students will form overarching visions of the current state of U.S. education.

title: Contemporary Issues
description: Methods and practices of the discipline.  Developing and executing research programs.  Writing thoughtful, well-informed and sophisticated papers.  Introduction to significant and pressing cultural issues such as globalization, media and the arts, memory and history, among others.

title: Contemporary Japan
description: Using movies and popular media to examine the social structures and family life dynamics of contemporary Japan.

title: Cont Mdrn Dnce Choreo Interm
description: Intermediate choreographic studies in contemporary modern dance.

title: Cont Mdrn Dnc Technq & Thry 4
description: Advanced technique and theory in contemporary modern dance.

title: Cntmpry Mdrn Tech Forms
description: Intermediate-advanced contemporary modern dance techniques and theory,

title: Contemp Mdrn Dance, Beg
description: Beginning contemporary modern dance technique, improvisation, choreography, and theory.

title: Contemp Mdrn, Tech & Theory 1
description: Fundamental contemporary modern dance technique, improvisation, choreography, and theory.

title: Contemp Mdrn, Tech & Theory 2
description: Intermediate contemporary modern dance technique and theory.

title: Cont Modrn Tech & Theory 3
description: Intermediate-advanced contemporary modern dance technique and theory.

title: Contemporary Partnering
description: Theory and technique of partnering as it relates to contemporary modern dance.

title: Contemp Performance Practices
description: Advanced studies in performance theory and practice.

title: Contemp Political Philosophy
description: Examine selected topics, periods, and figures in social and political philosophy with an aim to understand and apply theories to particular problems and questions.

title: Contemporary Political Theory
description: History of political science, including the moral and ethical dimensions of politics.

title: Contemporary Screens
description: Introduction to theories of contemporary screens (including television, games, web, etc.) as well as practices of analyzing and creating content for new media.

title: Contemp Sociological Theory
description: Recent developments in sociological theory. In-depth analysis of structure and assumptions of contemporary sociological theories.

title: Contemporary Soc Theory
description: Ideas, critiques, and arguments that form contemporary sociological inquiry.

title: Contempry Theory
description: Problems in contemporary theory; topics vary.

title: Cntmp Urb Soc Strc
description: Research-oriented examination of social forces in contemporary urban life that influence patterns of human interaction.

title: Contemporary Voice
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice.

title: Content-Area Literacy
description: Topics vary.

title: Content-Area Literacy
description: Current theory and related practices in literacy assessment and instruction for content-area classrooms.

title: Content-Area LiteracyInstructn
description: Content-area instructional strategies attuned to vocabulary, concept development demands, nature of content-area texts. Issues of negotiating and creating texts in content-area disciplines.

title: Content-Based Instruction
description: Planning for integration of academic content, language, and culture in K-12 dual language immersion classrooms. Managing immersion classrooms, selecting and modifying materials, differentiating instruction, and assessing learning.

title: ELL Content Instruction
description: Major concepts, principles, theories, and research relating to content-based instruction for ELLs; creating learning environments that support academic development of ELLs.

title: Content-Based Lang. Instr.
description: Instructional methods, strategies, and materials for integrating curriculum content and language instruction.  Teaching, creating, and adapting lesson materials in a multicultural context.

title: Dual Immersion Cntnt-Bsd Instr
description: Theory, method, and practical application for teaching language in content area subjects such as math, science, and social studies in K-12 dual language immersion classrooms.
