Research-based principles used for the creation of criteria and frameworks for curriculum that integrates content-based instruction and second language learning needs.

title: Content-Based Literacy
description: Instructional methods, strategies, and materials for integrating curriculum content and language instruction.  Teaching, creating, and adapting lesson materials in a multicultural context.

title: Contracts
description: Examination of the promises enforced by law, and the nature of the protection given. Inquiry made into the formation, performance, and discharge of contracts; their assignment, termination, and modification; and the variety, scope, and limitations on remedies. Attention will be given to Article 2 of the Uniform Commercial Code.

title: Span & Engl Struct
description: Contrastive analysis of phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics of Spanish and English.

title: Convectv Heat Tran
description: Advanced engineering analysis of convective heat transfer in internal and external laminar and turbulent flows.

title: Coordinated Research
description: Student research directed by faculty member on topic of mutual interest.

title: Copyright Law
description: Copyrights purpose, statutory structure, application in the courts, and role within intellectual property law and society. Topics include the subject matter requirements for copyrightability; the exclusive rights of copyright owners; duration, ownership, and transfer; copyright infringement litigation; contributory and vicarious liability; and fair use.

title: Corp Compliance & Legal Risk
description: Considers the theory and practice of risk assessment, compliance systems, and related corporate culture.

title: Corporate Finance
description: Introduction to the principles of modern corporate finance. Topics include: the time value of money; the relation between risk and return; the workings and efficiency of capital markets; valuing perpetuities and annuities; valuing the securities that corporations use to finance their business activities (stock, bonds, and options); valuing businesses as a going concern; optimal capital structure and dividend policies; debt covenants and other lender protections; basic financial accounting; derivatives; and the application of these principles to selected areas of corporate and securities law.

title: Corp Fin Reporting
description: Accounting principles of corporate financial reporting.  Judgments managers make preparing financial statement information.  How complexities, alternatives, and impacts affect completed financial statements.

title: Corporate Financial Reporting
description: Analyzing financial accounting and reporting issues used by prospective managers.

title: Corporate Financial Reporting
description: Introduction to concepts and issues of financial reporting with an emphasis on how financial statements reflect economic events.

title: Corporate Governance
description: How corporate boards are led, focusing especially on the role of the director, the rights of shareholders, the compensation of executives, and the challenge boards face in balancing the needs of shareholders, managers, and other stakeholders.

title: Corporate Social Impact
description: Introduction to corporate led efforts in social impact. Shareholder, management, and employee views of corporate social impact (CSI) efforts. Frameworks for understanding increasing efforts by corporations to show demonstrable outcomes of their CSI efforts.

title: Corporate Social Innovation
description: Examining and applying models of social innovation unique to corporations: direct investment, partnerships with governments and/or NGOs, direct- or foundation-based philanthropy, and industry-or sector-level interventions, in both domestic and international contexts.

title: Corporate Social Strategy
description: Explore the idea that essential business institutions can be leveraged for positive social impact. As part of a larger effort to build a theory and practice of corporate social impact, students engage principles derived from economics, sociology, psychology, and business management and apply them to live cases in the corporate world.

title: Corporate Taxation
description: Focuses on the federal system of taxation for corporations under Subchapter C of the Internal Revenue Code and their shareholders.

title: Corporate Taxation 1
description: Federal income taxation of corporations and shareholders.

title: Corporate Taxation 2
description: Continuation of Corporate Taxation 1.  Includes consolidated returns.

title: Corpus Linguistics
description: Using large collections of texts for research and teaching; focusing on variation (by dialect, genre, time, author, etc.) in language.

title: Corpus Linguistics Topics
description: Studies in specialized topics within corpus linguistics.

title: Corruption
description: Theories, causes and consequences of corruption, and select regimes established to combat and measure it, particularly the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and, to a lesser extent, the 2010 UK Bribery Act, the UN Convention Against Corruption, and OECD Anti-Bribery Convention.

title: Cost & Managerial Accounting
description: Cost and managerial accounting topics, including business processes, product costing, cost behavior analysis with regression, breakeven analysis with uncertainty, relevant decision making, performance measurement, variance analysis and budgeting.

title: Cost Benefit Analysis
description: Compares and contrasts multiple approaches to cost-benefit analysis, identifying when to apply this set of analytic techniques and examining the analytic and ethical challenges of the cost-benefit approach.

title: Costume Design
description: Comprehensive course in costume design for stage and screen; renderings; costume theory; script research; costume paperwork; collaboration techniques; preparation for work as assistant and/or full designer positions in departmental productions.

title: Cougar Talent Solutions
description: Apply techniques learned in prior Cougar Talent Solutions courses (MBA 646A and MBA 646B) by leading and mentoring student consulting teams within organizations to solve people challenges.

title: Cougar Talent Solutions B
description: Apply topics learned from MBA 646A (Cougar Talent Solutions  Learn) through consulting projects and leadership roles within the Cougar Talent Solutions organization.

title: Cougar Talent Solutions A
description: Learn consulting skills, project management, and change management principles needed to resolve the people challenges in an organization.

title: Counseling in Schools
description: This course builds on the introduction to counseling theory and intervention (CPSE 646) course. From that foundation, evidence-based counseling techniques specifically designed for children and adolescents within school settings are presented and practiced.

title: Counseling Psych Clerkship
description: Clinical experiences and psychotherapeutic training conducted off campus in an approved community agency clinical setting.

title: Coun Theory Interv
description: Various theories of counseling, current research, processes, and micro-skills training for interviewing and relationship building.

title: Counterpoint
description: Eighteenth-century contrapuntal styles and techniques, emphasizing those of J. S. Bach.

title: Cntry Wstrn Soc Dance, Beg
description: Beginning popular country western dance.

title: Cntry Wstrn Soc Dnc, Intrmd
description: Intermediate-level instruction in popular country western dances.

title: Hierarchical Linear Modeling
description: Conceptual and applied processes in hierarchical linear modeling with cross sectional nested data and longitudinal repeated measures data.

title: Introduction to Research
description: \tIntroduction to the design options available for conducting basic and applied educational research and how to read and write research reports. Quantitative, qualitative, and mixed methods along with ideas for protecting human subjects are discussed.

title: Qualitative Research 2 (Adv)
description: An in-depth exploration of qualitative research approaches and data analyses. Options include AR/PAR/Self-Study/Narratives; Hermeneutics, Phenomenology; Ethnography/Case Study; Grounded Theory; emerging methods.

title: Statistics 1: Foundations
description: Emphasis on conceptual understanding and practical application of descriptive and basic inferential statistics to decision making. \t

title: Stats 2: Multiple Regression
description: An examination of multiple regression as an inferential statistical procedure in its own right and as a foundation for subsequent courses in structural equation modeling, path analysis, and factor analysis.

title: Structural Equation Modeling
description: Examination of Structural Equation Modeling with expressions in Path Analysis, Confirmatory Factor, and Latent Variable Modeling.

title: Meta Analysis
description: An overview of qualitative research synthesis, methods for systematic literature reviews and meta-analysis. A balanced approach between conceptualization and application with practice using existing data sets and statistical packages.

title: Qualitative Research 1
description: Provides an introduction to qualitative inquiry in education, emphasizing major assumptions of qualitative research, a survey of prominent qualitative approaches, differences between various qualitative approaches and more traditional qualitative strategies, and practice with basic qualitative research skills such as interviewing, transcription, data analysis, and report writing.

title: Creating a Good Life
description: Introduce basic experience design and recreational philosophies, emphasizing positive psychology principles. Explore life design opportunities and perspectives of what constitutes "the good life" across multiple countries, cultures, and diverse populations.

title: Advertising Concepts 1
description: Basic consumer advertising; copywriting, design, and layout developed from creative strategies.  Solving creative problems.

title: Advertising Concepts 2
description: Advanced consumer advertising: copywriting, design, and layout.

title: Software Business
description: Entrepreneurship, idea/opportunity generation, strategic planning, legal organization, product development, marketing/sales, customer support, fund raising, and effective management.

title: Creating New Ventures
description: Learning the critical skills to create a successful new venture by validating an initial idea and business model in the field.

title: Creating New Ventures
description: Learning the critical skills to create a successful new venture by validating an initial idea and business model in the field.

title: Creating Virtuous Organization
description: This course explores the role of business in creating a Zion community, using the lens of organizational virtue as a starting point. Students will actively engage in creating thought leadership for incorporating principles of Zion-patterned governance in business and market institutions, as well as engaging readings on this topic from a variety of religious, scholarly, and popular sources. Students will apply their work to contemporary issues in the practice of business management and work to build a cohesive school of thought that can be shared with a variety of internal and external audiences.

title: Creating Virtuous Orgs
description: This course is a learn-do-become initiative in the Marriott School of Business that promotes the practice of virtuous business principles. The course identifies the cornerstones of theory on which market systems are built, identifies principles and practices for virtuous business, and connects with businesses and other organizations to refine, teach, and apply these principles and practices.

title: Creative Dance Elementary Edu
description: Theory and teaching experience in creative movement for preschool and elementary school children.

title: Creative Drama
description: Theory and methods of teaching drama to young people, grades K-6. Emphasis on creative drama, process drama and contemporary trends in drama pedagogy at the elementary level.

title: Creat Eng and Prob Solving I
description: This course is a hands-on experience centered on preparing students to teach middle school Technology & Engineering Education courses. During this course, students will be exposed to a wide breadth of topics, assignments, teaching styles, and activities within Technology & Engineering Education. Students will explore different pedagogical approaches in the context of career and technology education employment clusters and engage in iterative design, build, automate, test, and refine cycles (e.g., engineering design process)

title: Creat Eng and Prob Solving II
description: Designing solutions to technological problems using innovation, creativity, experimentation, problem solving, and engineering design.  Manufacturing systems; teaching methods and prototype development.

title: Creative Nonfiction Workshop
description: Writing creative nonfiction. Individual consideration of manuscripts.

title: Creative Skill Chem Engr
description: Applications in creativity and technical knowledge from prior course work to solution of relevant, open-ended problems.

title: Creative Strategic Thinking
description: Understanding conditions under which creative ideas/strategies emerge; building skills for creative strategic thinking; generating valuable ideas for companies.

title: Creative Writing
description: Introductory instructions in the writing of poetry, the short story, and the essay.

title: Creative Wrtg Cap: Fiction
description: Advanced writing workshop in fiction.

title: Creative Wrtg Cap: Nonfiction
description: Advanced writing workshop in creative nonfiction.

title: Creative Wrtg Cap: Poetry
description: Advanced writing workshop in poetry.

title: Creative Writing Theory
description: Theories and techniques of creative writers, primarily in fiction, poetry, and creative nonfiction.

title: Creat Collab in Arts and Comms
description: Explore theories of creativity, collaboration, and innovation in a modern, arts-based mediated world; engage in principles of team-building and communication; practice skills of ideation, research, and execution of interdisciplinary projects from conception to completion. Classes are project-based and vary from semester to semester. Please contact the College of Fine Arts and Communications (A-501 HFAC, 801-422-2819).

title: Creativity & Design in MKTG
description: Concepts and strategies to increase creativity, problem solving, and design skills. Emphasis on storytelling, advertising, and content creation.

title: Crime, Justice, & Corrections
description: Nature and extent of criminal behavior; current theory and research related to causes of crime and treatment of criminals.

title: Criminal Law 1
description: Problems in defining what conduct should be subjected to criminal penalties; the limitations of criminal law as a means for prevention and control of undesirable conduct.

title: Crim. Pro: Adjudication
description: Criminal procedure from the filing of charges through the appeals. Pretrial release and detention, the preliminary hearing, the grand jury, the charging instrument, joinder and severance, discovery, selected trial issues, plea bargaining, sentencing and appeals.

title: Criminal Pro: Investigation
description: Problems in administering a system of criminal law; constitutional and policy limitations upon public officers in dealing with suspected, charged, and convicted offenders.

title: Criminal Trial Advocacy
description: This course is designed for students who are interested in a career in criminal law, and have taken the first-year criminal law course. While it would be helpful for students to have taken criminal trial practice first, it is not a prerequisite. The course curriculum covers many of the aspects of criminal trial practice beyond the basics of courtroom practice. Subjects to be covered include criminal discovery practice, grand jury practice, representation of clients pre-indictment, pretrial motion practice (motions to suppress, etc.), jury selection and jury instructions, affirmative defenses (insanity, alibi, self defense, etc.), use of experts in criminal cases and investigators and agents, organizing for trial, use of exhibits, bench and jury trial strategies as well as advocacy before judges versus juries, sentencing considerations, and post-trial motions to include perfecting an appeal, and appeals.

title: Criminal Trial Practice
description: This course will develop the art and practical skill of trial advocacy. It will focus on typical situations that arise in the trial of a criminal case.  Emphasis will be placed on the academic theory, as well as the technique of the whole range of advocacy skills.  The developed skills will be transferable to general civil litigation.

title: Crisis Interventn
description: Human crises; preventive, developmental, and remedial interventions within school and family systems.

title: Crisis Intervention
description: Assessment and intervention in crisis situations with clients.

title: Critical Inquiry&Research Meth
description: Philosophies of critical inquiry. Principles of designing, conducting, and reporting social science investigations.

title: Critical Issues in Psychology
description: Critical and comparative examination of underlying theoretical and philosophical issues relavant to contemporary social, personality, and cognitive psychology, neuroscience,  and psychotherapy.

title: Critical Review of School Math
description: Strengthen understanding of middle-school mathematics with an emphasis on multiplicative structures, proportionality and linearity; gain awareness as mathematics learners in learning communities; learn how to support collaborative communities as teachers.

title: Critical Theory and Methods
description: Theoretical and practical criticism; problems in critical theory. Topics vary and include aesthetics, cultural theory, aspects of contemporary theory.

title: Critical Thinking
description: Equip students with relevant critical thinking and professional judgment knowledge and skills to think critically and evaluate information objectively using approaches such as structured problem solving, research and analysis, design thinking, and good judgment processes.

title: Cross-Cultural Fam & Hum Dev
description: Comparative study of familial, social, and other factors in development.

title: Crusades
description: Age of Holy Wars in the eastern Mediterranean and Near East, 1050-1300. Focus on both Europe and Near East.

title: Culminating Project
description: Continuing enrollment in order to complete final degree requirements such as oral exams and qualifications for the thesis or composition.

title: Cultural Dance Choreography
description: Exploration of fundamental choreographic principles of structure, space, time, and energy within the genre of staged cultural dance.

title: Cultural Dance Forms
description: Intermediate techniques and skills of dance cultures; variable culture focus.

title: Cultural Dance Introduction
description: Recreational folk dances from selected world cultures.

title: Cultural Dance Technique 1
description: Intermediate level recreational dances and specific dance technique from selected world cultural styles.

title: Cultural Dance Technique 2
description: Advanced level techniques from selected world cultures.

title: Cultrl Diversity & Gender Iss
description: Clinical issues in the context of cultural diversity and contemporary social trends.

title: Cultural History of Bulgaria
description: Study of Bulgarian culture using interpersonal, presentational, and interpretive skills in the target language.

title: Cultural History of Czech
description: Study of Czech culture using interpersonal, presentational, and interpretive skills in the target language.

title: Cultural History of Germany
description: Culture, with listening, speaking, reading, writing, and grammar as secondary emphases.  Includes International Cinema.

title: Cultural History of Hungary
description: Study of Hungarian culture using interpersonal, presentational, and interpretive skills in the target language.

title: Cultural History of Latvia
description: Study of Latvian culture using interpersonal, presentational, and interpretive skills in the target language.

title: Cultural History of Lithuania
description: Study of Lithuanian culture using interpersonal, presentational, and interpretive skills in the target language.

title: Cult Hist of Medicinal Plants
description: A global perspective of how medicinal plants have shaped cultural history and how they are used to treat illness and disease.  Issues relating to conservation, natural history, biodiversity, and cultural diversity.

title: Cultural History of Poland
description: Study of Polish culture using interpersonal, presentational, and interpretive skills in the target language.

title: Cultural History of Russia
description: Culture, with listening, speaking, reading, writing, and grammar as secondary emphases.

title: Cultural Hist of Scandinavia
description: Scandinavian culture from the Vikings to the present.

title: Cultural Hist. of the Vikings
description: History of art, literature, mythology, culture, and society in medieval Scandinavia.

title: Cultural Hist of U.S. School
description: Analyzing major philosophical and social assumptions and consequences of public schooling as it evolved over the early part of the nineteenth century.

title: Cultural History of Ukraine
description: Study of Ukrainian culture using interpersonal, presentational, and interpretive skills in the target language.

title: Cultural Proofs
description: Independent research on cultural topics and intercultural communication.

title: Cultural Sociology
description: Recent theories and research in sociological approaches to meaning, including cultural systems and institutions, everyday life, symbolism, agency, power, texts, and globalization.

title: Cultural Survey
description: Multidisciplinary survey of various countries and regions in preparation for extended experience abroad.

title: Cult Resp Practice in SPED
description: Understanding culturally responsive practices in special education: Navigating diversity and inclusion to cultivate belonging

title: Culture Teaching
description: Learning what culture is and how it functions in society.  Practicing techniques and creating materials for teaching culture in ESL/EFL and foreign language classrooms.

title: Culture,Issues,Policy for ELL
description: Major concepts, principles, and theories relating to educating English language learners; creating learning environments supporting educational progress and achievement.

title: Korean Culture
description: Culture, language, and history of Korea. Understanding aspects of Korean culture, such as the particular form of collectivism that is common in Korean culture. Study of Korean history, both recent and long-past, as a way to understand Korean culture today. Study of basic fundamental structures of the Korean language (including the alphabet) to better understand how culture is inflected by language.

title: Culture-Specific Dance Beg.
description: Introduction to dance cultures: variable culture focus.

title: Culture-Specific Dance Tech 1
description: Intermediate techniques and skills of dance cultures; variable culture focus.

title: Cultures of Brazil
description: Culture, history, art, music, and traditions of Brazil.

title: Cultures of Portugal
description: Culture, history, art, music, and traditions of Portugal.

title: Cultures of Spain
description: Culture, history, art, music, and traditions of Spain.

title: Cultures of Spanish America
description: Culture, history, art, music, and traditions of Spanish America.

title: Current Method & Theory
description: Major developments in archaeological method and theory, emphasizing current perspectives.

title: Current Art Practice
description: Current issues in art.

title: Current Art Practice
description: Current issues in art.

title: Current Biochemistry Literatr
description: Designed to increase the depth of student proficiency in current biochemistry literature and improve their formal presentation skills.

title: Current Events & Pol Sci
description: An introduction to political science using both national and international current events. Introduces faculty and academic expectations. Appropriate for non-majors.

title: Current Events in Arabic
description: Current events from online oral and written news sources, including high-level discussions of causes and context with written analyses and oral presentations.

title: Current Science Discussions
description: Discussion and critical evaluation of selected scientific papers in the field of Cell Biology and Physiology.

title: Current Social Problems
description: Individual deviance (violence, insanity, drugs, sex, crime, etc.) and social disorganization (poverty, race and sex discrimination, divorce, overpopulation, etc.). Conditions, causes, solutions.

title: Current Tax Policy
description: Intensive study of special and current tax topics and policies.

title: Current Topics and Issues
description: Individual or group study of current issues and developments in linguistic computing.  Extended readings; research or project required.

title: Current Topics
description: Provides doctoral students an opportunity to explore current literature and give presentations, both on the literature and their individual research.

title: Current Topics in ELL
description: Topics vary.

title: Current Topics in MMBio
description: Readings from current literature on a specific topic; student presentations and discussion.

title: Opportunities in Exp. Econ.
description: Explore current trends and entrepreneurship opportunities in the experiential segment of the consumer economy.

title: Curricular Practical Training
description: Hands-on practical training for MBA international students to be taken after their first year of the MBA program.

title: Curr and Instruct Practicum
description: Implementing active learning strategies in teaching microbiology and molecular biology.

title: Cur & Inst: Severe Disabilits
description: Strategies for designing and implementing educational programs, curricula, and teaching methods for students with severe disabilities. Application of course concepts will occur in a local school district each week.

title: Gifted Curriculum
description: In this course participants will study and demonstrate a variety of research-based models of curriculum and instruction related to students with gifts and talents. Participants will apply core curriculum that is aligned with local, state, and national standards.

title: Theory and Design in PE
description: Theories, concepts, and practices associated with design and delivery of physical education in the public schools and in physical education teacher education.

title: Curriculum Development
description: Advanced language-teaching methodology and its classroom application.

title: Curriculum Theory
description: Theory and practice of curriculum in its various psychological, social, historical, and philosophical contexts.

title: Curric Theory, Design & Assmnt
description: The nature of curriculum design for potentially educative environments.

title: Customer Relationship Mgmt
description: Methods and principles for effective management of customer relationships within service businesses. Analyzing customer-interactive processes with regard to strategic innovation, performance measurement and improvement, process efficiency, interactive job design, service marketing, and service quality assurance.

title: Customer Relationship Mgmt
description: Methods and principles for effective management of customer relationships and interactions. Analyzing customer-interactive processes. Facilitating customer roles in the supply chain pertaining to cost, quality, and workflow. Using customer service technology for strategic advantage.

title: Cyber-Physical Systems
description: Integration of technologies to design, develop, and secure computing systems that interact with the real world, including sensors, actuators, communication protocols, user experience, and microcontrollers. Security analysis of Industrial Control Systems (ICS) and Internet of Things (IoT) systems.

title: Cyberlaw
description: Covers issues in regulating cyberspace (both nationally and internationally), privacy, ownership and access, and speech and content. Briefly reviews intellectual property issues online, primarily copyright.

title: Cybersecurity & Pen Testing
description: Covers advanced computer systems security, vulnerabilities and exploits, system and network attacks, ethical hacking and penetration testing. Also addresses cyber security, cyber weapons, and advanced persistent threats along with legal and regulatory requirements for security and privacy.

title: Cybersecurity & Pen Test
description: Advanced computer systems security.  Vulnerabilities and exploits.  System and network attacks.  Ethical hacking and penetration testing.  Cyber security, cyber weapons, and advanced persistent threats.  Legal and regulatory requirements for security and privacy.

title: Cytogenetics
description: Chromosome structure and function; classical and molecular cytological methods of chromosome and genome analysis.

title: Dance- A Reflection of Culture
description: Application of dance ethnology theory and practices to study cultures of the world and its people.

title: Dance and Diaspora
description: An exploration of the impacts of globalization, migration, and information technology on dance and diaspora. The course will survey several diasporic dance forms, their roots, variations, movement qualities, and teaching methods. Social, cultural, historical, aesthetic, and functional elements will be considered as they pertain to authenticity, sustainability, and teaching/learning.

title: Dance and Film
description: Studies in dance and film.

title: Dance & Identity
description: Exploration of studies and issues regarding dance and identity. Topics include but are not limited to gender, race, ethnicity, culture, spirituality, and dance genre specificities.

title: Choreo, Adv
description: Advanced choreographic studies in dance.

title: Dance for Elementary Classroom
description: Methodology course for elementary education majors; creative dance and structured rhythmic dance forms.

title: Dance History 2
description: Survey of the development of dance in recent history, including significant social, political, economic, and aesthetic trends influencing dance-making.

title: Dance History and Theory
description: Survey of dance history with a focus on critical and conceptual engagement with the cyclical trends of dance throughout history.

title: Dance Improvisation, Interm
description: Intermediate improvisational skills focused on impromptu creative problem solving and movement exploration.

title: Dance Perf-1
description: Participation as dancers in concert dance production.

title: Dance Perf-2
description: Participation as dancers in concert dance production.

title: Dnc Prductn Intro
description: Principles and practices of technical aspects of dance production.

title: Dance Teaching Pract and Mgmt
description: Pre-student teaching course giving students practical teaching and classroom management experience in a mentored environment. Discussion lab integrating theory and experience.

title: DancEnsemble
description: Experiences in contemporary dance choreography and performance.

title: Danish Literature
description: Readings in Danish literature; introduction to basic literary concepts.  Includes International Cinema.

title: Dante's Divine Comedy
description: Intensive examination of Dante's major opus.

title: Data Analysis
description: Basic statistical methods, with an emphasis on manufacturing applications. Topics include sampling guidelines, design of experiments, analysis of variance, regression analysis, and model selection. Introduction to using Excel spreadsheets, Access databases, and VBA programming for data analysis.

title: Data Analysis 1
description: Introduction to descriptive and inferential statistics.

title: Data Analysis 2
description: Quantitative data collection and analysis.

title: Data Analysis in Psych Rsrch 1
description: Using and interpreting major quantitative methods in psychology; some commonly used computer methods.

title: Data Analysis in Psych Rsrch 2
description: Introduction to multivariate data analysis methods, including multivariate analysis of variance, factor analysis, discriminant analysis, multivariate multiple regression, canonical correlation, structural equations modeling, cluster analysis, etc.

title: Data Analysis & Presentation
description: Framing research questions, locating available data, using programs and statistical packages for univariate and bivariate analysis, presenting and summarizing findings.

title: Data Analytics in Accounting
description: Focus on understanding an analytics mindset and using tools to properly apply that mindset to real-world accounting problems. Utilize current analytic tools.

title: Data Communications
description: Principles of data communications, local- and wide-area networks, hardware, software, media, standards, management, and business applications.

title: Data Engineering
description: Provides a foundation in modern data engineering. Using a blend of modern technologies, students will learn how to design efficient data pipelines, build and deploy APIs, and become proficient in managing data across different storage systems and throughout the full ETL lifecycle in a data warehouse.

title: Data Science Capstone 1
description: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.

title: Data Science Capstone 1
description: Principles of data mining; regression, classification, and clustering in data science; Group capstone project.

title: Data Science Capstone 2
description: Data streaming and continuation of second half of capstone group project.\n

title: Data Science Capstone 2
description: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.

title: Data Science Ecosystems
description: Introduction to the basics of the Linux operating system.  Command line interface is used to explore Linux/Unix utilities and tools.  Fundamental concepts of python programming.  Create and run python scripts from the command line.  Introduction to database management systems, the basic structure of relational databases, and how to manage databases with Structured Query Language (SQL).   Read and write simple and complex SQL statements. Integrate R, Python and SQL skills.

title: Data Science for Managers
description: The statistical computer language R will be used to explore, wrangle, program, model, and communicate quantitative relationships using public and private databases.

title: Data Science Careers
description: A review of the data science major and other CPMS data science majors; class planning; information on major resources and career opportunities.

title: Data Science Process
description: Principles of data science; web scraping; data wrangling; exploratory data analysis; data visualization; ethics; version control; data communication.

title: Data Science for Organizations
description: End-to-end data science workflows using R, with a focus on strategy, team management, and real-world experience. Students will become thoughtful, detail-oriented, utility-focused data professionals who appreciate the grit required to deliver real-world, meaningful value through data assets.

title: Data Structures
description: Fundamental data structures and algorithms of computer science; basic algorithm analysis; recursion; sorting and searching; lists, stacks, queues, trees, hashing; object-oriented data abstraction.

title: Data Structures
description: Programming concepts for IS majors pursuing careers in software development. Concepts include lists, stacks, queue, maps, and other structures; sorting and other algorithms; recursion; and computational complexity analysis.

title: Data Visualization
description: Tools for the first steps in using data to answer political science questions: obtaining, cleaning, transforming, analyzing, and visualizing data. How to look at data and how to display that data to others.

title: Data Visualization
description:
The world needs better visualizations of its data. Most organizations are drowning in information but lacking in wisdom and analysis. Designers are uniquely positioned to think visually about research problems and creatively create visualizations that accurately enlighten ideas and concepts.

In this course, students will develop research strategies, master laws of optical hierarchy, deepen their understanding of gestalt principles as applied to data, and demonstrate creative visual concepts necessary to create compelling and memorable data visualizations.

title: Data Visualization
description: Fundamental principles of data visualization; chart types and when to use them; design of clear and meaningful visualizations from complex data; reproducible creation of static and interactive visualizations; development of portfolio of charts and graphs; use of appropriate visualization tools; communication of insights, observations, and results.

title: Data Visualization
description: Principles and practice of effectively communicating data visually to a variety of stakeholders in a pleasing and readily accessible manner, including an understanding of design principles and data communication ethics.

title: Data Decision Making Processes
description: Identifying problems. Using educational research. Collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data in order to solve problems; to establish fair, collaborative decision-making processes; and to inform continuous school and student improvement.

title: Multi-level Data Decision Makg
description: Applying data-driven decision making process to assess outcomes at multiple levels, including student assessment and learning: program and staff evaluation; school performance; community needs and expectations assessment and evaluation.

title: Database Administration
description: The role and responsibilities of database administrators. Database platform, architecture, and configuration; security and account management; backup, restore and disaster recovery; availability, access and performance; data migration.

title: Database Analysis & Design
description: Concepts and techniques of database system development.  Focal areas include: structures, integrity, retrieval, manipulation, validation, and analysis.  SQL used as basis for data interrogation.

title: Database Modeling Concepts
description: Database models:  relational, deductive, object-oriented.  Integrity constraints, query languages, database design.

title: Database Principles & Applictn
description: Database theory and architecture; data modeling; designing application databases. Query languages, data security, relational and non-relational databases.

title: Database Systems
description: Concepts and techniques of database system development, focusing on object-oriented modeling and its implementation methods.

title: Deaf Literature
description: Various genres of Deaf literature. Introduction to analysis of ASL literary works.

title: Death and Dying
description: Death and the dying process will be explored from spiritual, physical, cultural, and psychosocial perspectives. Comparisons will be drawn between end-of-life care in Western compared to other cultures and ethnic backgrounds.

title: Debt Management
description: Advanced study of capital markets, debt instruments, bond issues, debt servicing, and financial disclosure requirements.

title: Decentralized Finance
description: Financial infrastructure built on blockchain networks. Digital signatures, consensus mechanisms, smart contracts, cryptocurrencies and architecture, decentralized exchange, lending protocols, decentralized derivatives, and asset tokenization.

title: Decision Analysis
description: Applying analytical decision-making tools to management situations using spreadsheet decision models based on concepts of risk, uncertainty, and multiple criteria.

title: Deep Foundations
description: Lateral pressures and earth retaining systems, axial and lateral capacities of piles and drilled shafts, foundations subjected to vibratory loadings, foundations on collapsible and expansive soils, soil improvement techniques.

title: Defensive Cybersecurity
description: Defensive security with the knowledge and tools to safeguard critical information. Security best practices, risk management, incident response, and critical defensive technology.

title: Democracy and Autocracy
description: Definition and measurement of democracy; major theories explaining the emergence of democracies and autocracies; exploration of why autocrats use violence or other modes of repression, how they manipulate elections, and why some regimes fail while others survive.

title: Democratic Class Design
description: Design and manage a classroom where students learn, analyze and experience democratic principles; prepare the physical, academic, and social space to foster engaged citizenship and shared responsibility; develop a  Civic Engagement Project; visit local classrooms.

title: Dental School Prep Lab Exper
description: Dental laboratory practices; tooth terminology, morphology, and anatomy. Procedures including oral pathology, diagnosis, and X-rays.

title: Desc Acoustics of Music & Spch
description: Introductory acoustics course, emphasizing physical principles underlying production and perception of music and speech.

title: Descriptive Astronomy
description: Conceptual presentation of knowledge of the content and history of the cosmos, frequently using observatory and/or planetarium.

title: Design 1
description: Students will develop skill in drawing as a method of visual problem solving, and in composition through the application of design principles. Concepts, terminology, and processes necessary to communicate visual ideas.

title: Design 2
description: Study the elements and principles of design through the use of form, visual principles, theoretical and visual experimentation, concept development, and creative thinking. Systems, symbols, icons and expressive typography will be used to visually represent ideas and messages.

title: Consulting Apprenticeship
description: Mentored, applied experience working as a design and analysis consultant for a university.

title: Design & Tech: Asst Stage Mgrs
description: Practical experience working as main season assistant stage managers; related topics.

title: Design Evaluation
description: Introduction to the field of evaluation and how it is used in instructional design and in the evaluation of educational products. Methods for conceptualizing and implementing evaluations, and practical guidelines for planning and completing an evaluation project.

title: Design for Additive Mfg
description: This course explores the past, present, and future of additive manufacturing (AM), including how it enables mass customization and increased design complexity. Lab experiences focus on preparing 3D models, operating several types of AM systems, and post processing finished parts. Students apply "Design for AM" principles to adapt existing part designs for AM and design new products that capitalize on the possibilities only available through AM.

title: Design for Additive Manufact.
description: This course explores the past, present, and future of additive manufacturing (AM), including how it enables mass customization and increased design complexity. Lab experiences focus on preparing 3D models, operating several types of AM systems, and post processing finished parts. Students apply "Design for AM" principles to adapt existing part designs for AM and design new products that capitalize on the possibilities only available through AM.

title: Design for X
description: Design methodologies and guidelines for products and systems. Design for Manufacturing, Design for Assembly, Design for Sustainability, Design for Usability, and other related topics. Concurrent engineering skills for engaging design, manufacturing, and systems engineers in multidisciplinary teams.

title: Design in the Home
description: Intermediate application of elements and principles of design in the home.

title: Design Lab
description: Students work in a collaborative, project-based learning environment.

title: Design Lecture Series
description: Visiting lecture series exploring visual culture and and design practice through the lenses of various practicing professionals.

title: Design of Mechatronic Systems
description: Microcontroller-based mechatronic systems comprised of mechanical, electrical, and software subsystems.  Electronics, printed circuit board design, microcontroller programming and interfacing, and mechanical prototyping.

title: Design of Medical Devices
description: This interdisciplinary course aims to provide a comprehensive and practical understanding of the design, development, and deployment of medical devices. Rooted in mechanical engineering, the course integrates key principles from biomedicine, materials science, quality assurance, and intellectual property law. With a focus on real-world application, students will engage in case studies, a hands-on project, and team-based design exercises that simulate the challenges and opportunities within the medical device industry.

title: Design Practicum
description: Practical experience working as assistant designers; practicum experience in related performance design and/or technology topic areas.

title: Design Psychology
description: This course will introduce students to fundamental principles of psychological research and how they influence design.  In this course, students will learn how people think, basic human psychology, and factors to consider in designing for others.  By the end of this course, students should be able to identify relevant factors that affect design as well as how those factors come into play in different design situations.

title: Design Studio
description: The design studio course engages students in comprehensive design projects, emphasizing critical thinking, sustainable practices, and social awareness in architectural design. Students explore diverse typologies and scales, employing advanced digital tools and interdisciplinary perspectives. The course integrates hands-on exercises, design critiques, and real-world insights to foster a holistic understanding of contemporary architectural practice and the societal impact of design decisions. By the end of the course, students will have a significant portfolio contribution and the skills necessary for further graduate studies in architecture.

title: Design Studio
description: Performance design studio experience in team collaboration, portfolio building, and faculty mentored projects.

title: Design Theory
description: Theoretical and historical readings and discussions explore visual culture, aesthetics, critical studies, ethics, and design practice across various professional disciplines with a focus on historical trajectories and speculative futures.

title: Design Thinking
description: Students will unpack each step of the design thinking process while honing critical thinking, conceptual development, and craft through readings and projects.

title: Dsgn, Fabricatn, Sci Apparatus
description: Machining, computer interfacing, controls, and vacuum systems.

title: Design-Based Research
description: Principles of formative experimentation in studying developing interventions in natural contexts.  Challenges of selecting and integrating inquiry methods, resolving implementation problems, linking programmatic variables to theory, assessing effects, and drawing valid conclusions.

title: Community Based Interventions
description: The purpose of this course is to help you design and implement community-based interventions. Working with a local community center, you will identify specific needs and design projects to address those needs with community involvement and direction.

title: Designing Democ. Constitutions
description: Examining the rich variety of ways in which democracies are designed across the globe. Relying on both theoretical and empirical perspectives, surveying the different rules for governance and representation, and their advantages and disadvantages for various, and often competing, goals, such as accountability, corruption, political violence, and economic development.

title: Designing for Inc  & Belonging
description: Focus on experiences of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging for individuals, families, and organizations. Address both the business and moral imperatives related to diversity, inclusion, and belonging.

title: Detection&Estimation Theory
description: Sufficiency, completeness; Neyman-Pearson and Bayes detector; maximum likelihood, Bayes, minimum mean square, and linear estimation; Kalman filters; selected topics.

title: Developing Adaptive Leaders
description: Developing proficiency in planning, executing, and assessing operations; functioning on a staff; and providing feedback to subordinates with situational real-world opportunities to assess risk, make decisions, and coach others.  Emphasizes leadership ethics.  Lab included.

title: Dev Musicality K-2
description: Literature-based curriculum design and planning, grades K--2. Issues of pure intonation and vocal/aural development. Microteaching in a demonstration school.

title: Intellectual Properties
description: The process of developing a marketable intellectual property within the animation industry. Examining industry constraints, marketing, and how story and visual design relate to an intellectual property. Introduction to the iterative development process from the early stages of development, through pre-production to presentation. Industry demands related to quality, longevity and creativity will be explored.

title: K-12 Liter. 2nd Lang. Learners
description: Instructional strategies, methodologies, and materials for developing reading and writing skills in a second language. Developing cognitive academic language proficiency and integrating multiple cultural perspectives.

title: Development Projct
description: Designing, conducting, and reporting a comprehensive project in development.

title: Developmental Biology
description: Invertebrate and vertebrate developmental biology.  Embryonic gastrulation, neurulation, patterning, etc.  Modern approaches and research strategies.  Emphasizes gene function, cell signaling, signal transduction during embryogenesis.

title: Developmental Genetics
description: Gene function and regulation during cell specification and differentiation, pattern formation, and organogenesis in developing embryo.

title: Language Disorders
description: Causes and characteristics of language impairment; techniques for diagnosis, assessment, and treatment of language disorders.

title: Developmental Plant Physiology
description: Developmental phenomena in higher plants, emphasizing seed physiology, plant growth regulation, and plant stress responses.

title: Develpmntl Psych: Adolescence
description: Development and maturation during adolescence; research methodology.

title: Developmental Psych: Adulthood
description: Stability and change in psychological, physiological, and interpersonal processes through early, middle, and late adulthood.

title: Developmental Psych: Childhood
description: Physical, mental, emotional, and social development of the child.

title: Developmental Psychopathology
description: Advanced study of etiology, diagnosis, prevalence, associated features, and theories of psychological and developmental disorders in children and adolescents.

title: Deviance & Social Control
description: Theory and research related to deviance. Specific topics include psychosis, addiction, violence, and rape, among others.

title: Diag & Mgt of Adult Common Dis
description: Health promotion and disease prevention; diagnosing and managing common psychosocial and physiological alterations in adult patients.

title: Diag & Mgt of Chronic Disord
description: Health promotion and disease prevention; diagnosing and managing chronic psychosocial and physiological alterations in adult and geriatric patients.

title: Diag & Mgt of Ped & Adoles Dis
description: Health promotion and disease prevention; diagnosing and managing psychosocial and physiological alterations in pediatric and adolescent patients and family health.

title: Diag/Trmnt Disordr
description: Diagnosis, classification, and treatment of emotional problems and mental disorders.

title: Dialects
description: Major stage dialects.

title: Diamonds and Gems
description: Hands-on examination of diamonds and gems with particular emphasis on discriminating naturally occurring from man-made products. Field trips and lab studies.

title: Diction Lab 1
description: The study of diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab 1: English
description: The study of English diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab 1: French
description: The study of French diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab 1: German
description: The study of German diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab 1: Italian
description: The study of Italian diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab 2
description: Continuation of the study of Italian diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab 2: English
description: Continuation of the study of English diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab 2: French
description: Continuation of the study of French diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab 2: German
description: Continuation of the study of German diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab 2: Italian
description: Continuation of the study of Italian diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab: English
description: The study of English diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab: French
description: The study of French diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab: German
description: The study of German diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diction Lab: Italian
description: The study of Italian diction for students in the voice area. Focus on IPA, pronunciation, and musical styles.

title: Diet and Cancer
description: Critical examination of scientific evidence regarding the role of dietary macronutrients, vitamins, minerals, and phytochemicals in the initiation, promotion, and progression of cancer.

title: Differential Geometry
description: Geometry of smooth curves and surfaces. Topics include the first and second fundamental forms, the Gauss map, orientability of surfaces, Gaussian and mean curvature, geodesics, minimal surfaces and the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem.

title: Differential Geometry
description: A rigorous treatment of the theory of differential geometry.

title: Differential Topology
description: An introduction to smooth manifolds and their topology: smooth manifolds; tangent, vector, and cotangent bundles; immersions, submersions, and embeddings; tubular neighborhoods; transversality; differential forms, integration, and Stoke's Theorem; deRham cohomology; and degree theory.

title: Text Processing and Analysis
description: Development of computer applications for research in language and literature (text processing, retrieval, and analysis) in one or more programming languages (e.g., Perl, Python, etc.).

title: Digital 3D
description: Introduction to using digital tools to create sculpture. Explores the material, formal, and conceptual potential of sculpture using new technologies.

title: Digital and Visual Literacies
description: Study of multimodal texts and genres with ties to literature, based in theoretical grounding from the fields of adaptation studies, design, folklore, and digital rhetoric.

title: Digital Archaeology
description: Use of digital technologies in archaeology. Focus on software applications, GIS, GPS, and surveying/mapping with a robotic total station and Unmanned Aerial Vehicles.

title: Digital Communication
description: Rhetorical perspectives on critical digital literacy, content creation, and digital engagement.

title: Digital Communications
description: Ohm's law, power, inductance, capacitance, reactance, impedance, resonance, transformers. Properties of waves and electromagnetic radiation, including light. Communication systems, wired and wireless. Bandwidth, modulation; Shannon's theorem, telecommunications. Network physical and data link layers (ISO/OSI model). Optics/Coax/Twisted pair; RS-232/Ethernet; Signals/Protocols/Packets; digital communication theory fundamentals.

title: Digital Forensics
description: Fundamentals of digital forensics, incident response, evidence, chain of custody, threat intelligence, preventive measures for vulnerabilities, response and recovery, and network forensics.

title: Digital Forensics for Orgnztns
description: Digital forensics from an organizational perspective, covering the three functions of digital forensics performed by businesses: employee abuse investigations, incident response, and electronic discovery.

title: Digital History
description: Exploration of digital technology and its potential to revolutionize the discipline of history, from the way research is conducted to methods for knowledge dissemination. Benefits, challenges, and impact of digital methods on the way historians envision and express what happened in the past.

title: Digital Humanities Seminar
description:
Although, as a seminar, the content of this course will vary from section to section, the content will include come combination the following:
1. Humanistic analysis of the digital as both a producer and product of culture.
2. Computational analysis of cultural artifacts such as literature, music, visual art, etc.
3. Technology skills relevant to the above activities.

title: Digital Humanities Project
description: Original research project on open questions within the Digital Humanities field. Content and/or technology advisor is required.

title: Digital Hum Research Seminar
description: Individual or group research of original problems in Digital Humanities research.

title: Digital Imaging & Compositing
description: This course focuses on utilizing current image creation software to pre-visualize and create photographic imagery that did not exist in front of the cameraâ€”including compositing existing imagery, incorporating AI tools, best practice digital workflow, and print output.

title: Digital Interface Design
description: Theoretical and practical principles of designing interfaces for all instructional forms, including message design, representation design, and control design.

title: Dig Lit & Tech in Sec Schl
description: Theories and methods of teaching digital literacies and integrating technology in secondary English classrooms.\n

title: Digital Marketing
description: Digital marketing is broad and varied, so rather than digging deeply into one topic (e.g., search engine optimization) and ignoring all other topics, this class will cover a wide variety of digital marketing topics.  Students will customize their experience by choosing between two different "tracks" in the course: a strategic emphasis or tactical emphasis.\n \n

title: Digital Media Production
description: Practical application of visual and aural multimedia storytelling; acquisition, editing, and distribution of digital audio and video.

title: Digital Painting
description: Tools and techniques of digital painting for concept design in the entertainment industry.

title: Digital Sculpting
description: Developing skills necessary for creating appealing, viable digital models.  Issues involved in designing for the animation and gaming industry.

title: Digital Signal Processing
description: Advanced theory and applications including optimal statistical processing, adaptive processing, and array processing methods.

title: Dinosaurs
description: Hands-on examination of vertebrate fossils -- especially dinosaurs.  For nonscience majors.  Field trips.

title: Direct Enrollment France
description: Register for this course in consultation with department internship coordinator.  To be taken only when enrolled directly in French university as part of BYU professional program in France.  Only enroll when curriculum of other BYU courses do not correspond to the course enrolled in French university.

title: Directed Graduate Studies
description: Guided preparation for department's comprehensive exams and for formulation of research prospectus.

title: Directed Independent Study
description: Faculty-supervised readings as arranged by student.

title: Directed Individual Study
description: Improving understanding of a focused topic through mentored inquiry and completion of related writing or design activities.

title: Directed Middle East Study
description: Study and research in the Middle East.

title: Directed Pub Hlth Readings
description: Self-paced reading and in-depth studying of public health topics.

title: Directed Reading in Sociology
description: Individualized reading program supervised by faculty member. Student selects reading topic and completes systematic in-depth reading of related literature.

title: Directed Readings
description: Reading 2,500 pages on a stated topic.

title: Directed Readings
description: Individual readings beyond what is offered in the curriculum.

title: Directed Readings
description: Course set up only in special circumstances and by permission for focused study of a topic in comparative literature.

title: Directed Readings
description: Students will organize literary texts from Greek and/or Latin traditions into a cogent unit for study and analysis and conduct a thorough investigation into a problem or set of related problems presented by the study unit.

title: Directed Readings
description: Students will read, evaluate, and critique literature related to a specific topic area in political science.

title: Directed Readings
description: Students will read, evaluate, and critique literature related to a specific topic area in political science.

title: Directed Readings
description: Course set up only in special circumstances and by permission for focused study of a topic in the humanities.

title: Directed Readings
description: Course set up only in special circumstances and by permission for focused study of a topic in comparative literature.

title: Directed Readings
description: Individual readings beyond what is offered in the curriculum.

title: Directed Readings
description: Directed individual study of historical topics or ancient texts.

title: Dir Rds C Hist & Doc
description: Topics include the Doctrine and Covenants, LDS Church history, LDS doctrine, Christian history, Christian theology, world religions, etc.

title: Directed Readings
description: For instructors and students who wish to pursue special problems or projects, or who wish to read texts that are not covered by available courses.

title: Directed Readings in Scand
description: Directed individual study.

title: Directed Research
description: Student research directed by faculty member on topic of mutual interest.

title: Directed Research
description: Application of research methods relative to managers.

title: Drctd Research Afr. Stud. Min.
description: Directed research project (library and/or on-site experience) related to African studies or the African diaspora.  Must be supervised by faculty with extensive in-field experience in Africa and African Studies.

title: Directed Research in English
description: Directed research for mentorship grant recipients, research assistants, and other undergraduate students pursuing research projects.

title: Family History Directed Rsrch
description: Student research directed by faculty member on family history topic  of mutual interest.

title: Linguistics Research 1
description: Introduction to mentored scholarly research in German linguistic studies. Focus on gathering and analyzing data. Continued professional skills development.

title: Linguistics Research 2
description: Introduction to mentored scholarly research in German linguistic studies. Focus on conducting linguistic research and writing about the results of linguistic studies. Continued professional development skills.

title: Dir Research Port
description: Under direction of faculty member, designing and conducting research project that covers material not normally presented in regular course work. Research paper required.

title: Directed Research
description: Under faculty member's direction, designing and conducting research project covering material not normally presented in regular course work. Research paper required.

title: Directed Research in Sociology
description: Individualized research program supervised by faculty member.  Student selects topic and completes a research project.

title: Directed Research
description: Under faculty member's direction, designing and conducting research project covering material not normally presented in regular course work. Research paper required.

title: Directed Research in Span
description: Individualized study. Under direction of faculty member, designing and conducting research project that covers material not normally presented in regular course work. Research paper required.

title: Directed Studies
description: Individual study in current topics of industrial design.

title: Directed Studies
description: Individualized studies in language of emphasis, directed by a faculty member. Research paper required.

title: Directed Studies
description: Students will be able to meet regularly with a professor or mentor throughout the course of the semester to complete a project of their own choosing.

title: Directed Studies in Animation
description: Credit for work experience in animation.

title: Directed Studies in Arabic
description: Individual tutorial in topic of student choice; lexical development; major oral and written report in Arabic.

title: Directed Studies in CE
description: Directed studies in Civil Engineering related to professional practice.

title: Directed Studies in GraphicDes
description: Credit for work experience in graphic design.

title: Directed Studies in Illustratn
description: Course credit for work experience in illustration.

title: DirectedStudies in Photography
description: Credit fort work experience in photography.

title: Directed Teaching
description: Supervised, practical experience in teaching Portuguese at the college level.

title: Directed Tchg of Spanish
description: Supervised, practical experience in teaching Spanish at the college level.

title: Directing Narrative Literature
description: Theory and practice of adapting, directing, and performing nondramatic literature. Readers Theatre.

title: Disaster Law
description: Students will learn to analyze the human contributions to "natural disasters" and to develop tools for legislating in the face of uncertainty, designing fair compensation and insurance schemes, and rebuilding communities devastated by disasters.

title: Disaster Response & Emer Prep
description: Key elements of public health preparedness and response to the variety of natural, technological, and man-made disasters occurring routinely on a global basis.

title: Discipleship in Global Mgmt
description: Deepening the understanding of our Savior and restored gospel while maintaining our discipleship by expanding knowledge and preparing to manage careers in a global environment.

title: Discourse Analysis
description: Linguistic analysis of connected speech or written discourse, especially larger linguistic units above the clause level, such as conversational exchanges or written texts.

title: Discourse Analysis
description: Mental and social processes involved in communicating through language; how we construct and interpret meaning through various contexts.

title: Discovering Archaeology
description: Studying past human behaviors and cultures by applying scientific principles and reasoning; exploring case studies concerning archaeological discoveries.

title: Dis Field Material Sci
description: New: Interdisciplinary interactions within the materials science discipline. Mapping the path through a materials science minor. Exposure to facilities and experiential learning opportunities on campus. Preparation for post-baccalaureate employment or education in materials science.

title: Discovering the World
description: General introduction to the practice of attentive reading and literary analysis, with a focus on literary texts and traditions outside the Anglophone United States. The course is centered on a different "big question" or theme each semester.

title: Discrete Structure
description: Introduction to grammars and parsing; predicate and propositional logic; proof techniques; sets, functions, relations, relational data model; graphs and graph algorithms.

title: Dissection Tech Human Anatomy
description: Techniques of human cadaver dissection.

title: Dissertation
description: Successfully complete and defend a dissertation.

title: DEI & Belonging in Counseling
description: Diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging competency training on issues of race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, age, socioeconomic status, disability, and religion. Knowledge, skills, and awareness applied to counseling.

title: Divine Comedy
description: Participation as performers, writers, directors, or crew members of a sketch comedy group.

title: Diving, Springboard
description: Beginning diving. Springboard approach and take-off (inward, reverse, backs, forward), somersaults (inward, reverse, back, forward), twists (forward, back).

title: Doctoral Dissertat
description: Formal report and defense of substantive research topic designed to make an original contribution to knowledge in the field.

title: Dissertation
description: Concluding research for doctoral program, culminating in final oral examination.

title: Dissertation
description: Formal report and defense of a substantive research topic designed to make an original contribution to knowledge in the field.

title: Doctoral Dissertation
description: Students demonstrate significant oral and written communication skills and research competencies through conceiving, proposing, and defending a dissertation.

title: Doctoral Internship
description: Practical experience in the state office, local school districts, higher education settings, or other agencies.

title: Doctoral Practicum
description: Designing and implementing on-site research.

title: Doctoral Seminar
description: This seminar introduces students to doctoral studies in general, enculturates them in the EdD program, and provides ongoing support for their doctoral research studies.

title: Doctoral Seminar
description: Weekly graduate seminar.  Includes speakers,  panels and workshops.  Topics include recent research results, current research trends and discussion of research careers.  Students will be periodically invited to present their recent results.\n\n

title: Sem: Prof Writing
description: This class is designed to teach PhD students the essentials of writing good biomedical manuscripts for publication in appropriate scientific journals.

title: Sem: Research & Grants
description: This class is designed to teach PhD students how to develop a research grant proposal focusing on appropriate structure and scientific content.

title: Doct Contributns of Restoratn
description: Doctrinal contributions of the Restoration from Joseph Smith to the present prophets, seers, and revelators; Latter-day Saint theology and practice.

title: D&C Graduate Seminar
description: Topics in the Doctrine and Covenants, emphasizing doctrinal and historical background.

title: Doctrines of Gospel
description: Doctrines of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints as taught in the scriptures and by latter-day prophets. Intended as a capstone experience to integrate doctrines and principles of the plan of salvation.

title: Domestic Relations
description: Learn about the practical issues involved in handling a divorce case. Study the process, the documents and the primary issues involved in divorce and custody cases. Students will have the opportunity to work with real cases through the Family Justice Center on Tuesday evenings from 5:00-9:00 p.m. Students do not need to be available every Tuesday or for the full range of hours.

title: Domestic Violence Intervention
description: Learn about the dynamics involved within abusive families and how those dynamics play out in court. Learn how domestic violence is treated in each context that might be brought to court: criminal actions, protective and restraining orders, personal injury cases, custody and divorce actions and within the juvenile court system. Students will have the opportunity to work with real cases through the Family Justice center on Tuesday evenings from 5:00-9:00 p.m. Students do not need to be available every Tuesday or for the full range of hours.

title: Don Juan Theme
description: History and development of Don Juan theme.

title: Dostoevsky
description: Survey of Dostoevsky's major  works in English translation.

title: Drama in the Elem Classroom
description: Varied teaching methodologies for application of drama within the pre-K--6 classroom. Dual emphasis on Utah state elementary drama standards as well as integration with core curricula.

title: Dramatic Literature 1
description: Survey of dramatic texts, from ancient Greek to today, through Western literary theories, emphasizing performance.

title: Drama Perf: Antiq to Renais
description: Civilization from Greek antiquity through Renaissance, primarily from perspective of dramatic literature and performance. Ways in which performance functions within particular socioeconomic, political, religious, and aesthetic perspectives.

title: Drama Perf: Renais to Present
description: Civilization from Renaissance through present, primarily from perspective of dramatic literature and performance. Ways in which performance functions within particular socioeconomic, political, religious, and aesthetic perspectives.

title: Dramaturgy 1
description: Graduate-level research and application of hands-on theatrical skills in four critical studies areas: literary management, production dramaturgy, new play development, educational outreach.

title: Dramaturgy 2
description: Develop further research and hands-on theatrical skills in four critical studies areas: literary management, production dramaturgy, new play development, educational outreach.

title: Dramaturgy Practicum
description: Experience as lead dramaturg for main-stage productions; building casebooks and overseeing audience education efforts. Rehearsal and production meeting attendance required.

title: Drawing
description: Drawing as a graphic form of self-expression, emphasizing personal statement in response to various experiences and concepts.

title: Drawing & Composition
description: Drawing methods and practices combined with compositional foundations for visual communicators. Students will develop observation and conceptual drawing skills. Students will also develop visual problem solving, analytical thinking, and craftsmanship by applying design principles to compositional problems. Skills are developed through intensive practice, lecture, demonstration, and critique.

title: Drawing Fundamentals
description: Foundational skills of drawing structure and form.

title: Drugs, Reward and Addiction
description: Examines the biopsychosocial nature of drug and behavioral addiction. This course presents the most current research in the field and bridges psychology and neuroscience.

title: DLI K-12 Student Teaching
description: Supervised full-day experience to develop and demonstrate competence in teaching in an approved dual language immersion school setting. Includes planning, implementing, and assessing a unit of instruction taught in the immersion language.

title: DLI K-12 Student Teaching
description: Supervised, full-day experience to develop and demonstrate competence in teaching content in a foreign language in an approved public school setting.  Observation is stressed initially, with responsibility for teaching increasing across the four-week experience.

title: Dynamic System Modeling
description: Formulating mathematical models for mechanical, electrical, fluid, and combined systems; numerical solution of motion equations; first- and second-order systems, frequency response, and transfer functions.

title: Dynamics
description: Advanced treatment of classical mechanics, including Lagrange's and Hamilton's equations, rigid body motion, and canonical transformations.

title: Dynamics of Clothing
description: Introduction to the influences, meanings, and dimensions of individual clothing selection processes and its effect on families, communities, and cultures.

title: Dynamics of Mech Systems
description: Hamiltonian and Lagrangian dynamics, generalized coordinates, linear and angular momentum, Euler angles, rigid-body motions, and gyroscopic effects. Theory taught with applications integrated.

title: E-Business Projects
description: Consulting/Field studies projects in e-business.

title: Early Africa
description: Explores the formation of African regional political traditions, the rise of fabled kingdoms, and the horrors of expanding slaving frontiers.

title: Early America
description: Interactions among the indigenous peoples of North America and European explorers, traders, and colonizers up to 1765, including their legal, economic, and political frameworks and contrasting approaches to culture, gender, religion, and the environment.

title: Early Amer Political Thought
description: Core principles and seminal texts of American politics from Colonial times through the Lincoln administration.

title: Early Child Lang Intervention
description: Theories and practices in language treatment, emphasizing assessment and intervention for developmentally young children.

title: ECE DAP Practicum
