description: An investigation of the literacies needed to participate in the various disciplines and the support needed to learn those literacies.

title: Literacy Assessment&Interventn
description: Topics vary.

title: Literacy Assessments&Intrvntns
description: Formal and informal assessment procedures. Appropriate instructional interventions for students of varying ages, performance levels, and linguistic abilities, particularly struggling students.

title: Literacy Developmnt&Instructn
description: Topics vary.

title: Literacy Development &Instrctn
description: Emergent, early, and adolescent literacy development; ideas for constructing appropriate literacy learning environments, experiences, and instructional interventions for students pre-K-12.

title: Literacy for ELLs
description: Major concepts, principles, theories, and research relating to developing literacy in English for ELLs in K-12 schools; creating learning environments that promote literacy development.

title: Literacy Development I
description: The purpose of this course is for teacher candidates to understand the essential components of literacy including what they are, how they are expected to develop, how they relate to other concepts, and ways to support, teach, and assess this development for young children (prek-k)

title: Literacy Specialist Practicum
description: Topics vary.

title: Lit Med & Cultures Sr Capstone
description: In-depth study of a focused area of literary media, culture and theory or criticism. Content varies: requires research and writing.

title: Literary Studies of the Bible
description: Scholarly engagement with the aesthetic forms and cultural context of Biblical texts.

title: Literary Studies Sr Capstone
description: In-depth study of a focused area of literature and theory or criticism. Content varies; requires research and writing.

title: Literary Theory & Resrch Meth
description: Introduction to literary theory, emphasizing major theoretical movements and strategies of literary interpretation.  Bibliographical techniques, research methodology, and issues pertaining to the profession.

title: Literary Theory & Resrch Meth
description: Introduction to literary theory, emphasizing major theoretical movements and strategies of literary interpretation. Bibliographical techniques, research methodology, and issues pertaining to the profession.

title: Literary Translation
description: In-depth, project-based study of theory, criticism, and practice of translating various literary genres, focusing on Spanish-English and English-Spanish. Recommended for students who already have broad exposure to translation and desire a more focused experience.

title: Lit & Cinema
description: Interrelationship of literary and cinematic art, problems of adaptation.

title: Lit & Cultures of Amer West
description: Literature and cultural representations of the American West and the frontier.

title: Literature & Film
description: Emphasis on film as an interpretation of texts. Includes International Cinema.

title: Literature & Hist
description: Interrelationship of literary and historical study.

title: Literature & Music
description: Interrelationship of literary and musical art, problems of meaning.

title: Literature & Myth
description: Interrelationship of literary study and study of myth.

title: Lit & Politics
description: Interrelationship of literary art with political science.

title: Literature for Young Children
description: This survey course in children's literature is designed to provide teacher candidates with the skills and knowledge necessary to select and use high quality literature in their future prek-3rd grade classrooms.

title: Literature for Young People
description: Overview of fiction and nonfiction literature for elementary and secondary school students (K-12); authors, current trends, and cross-curriculum classroom applications.

title: Literature for Young People
description: Topics vary.

title: Literature of Journalism
description: Critiquing journalism theories and philosophy ranging from traditional libertarian ideals to contemporary movements of public journalism and public service broadcasting.

title: Literature of the LDS
description: Fiction, poetry, drama, folklore, essay, etc., emerging from and reflecting upon the LDS experience from Joseph Smith to the present.

title: Lit of the Latter-day Saints
description: Fiction, poetry, drama, folklore, personal essay, and other literature emerging from the LDS experience and expressing various perspectives on it.

title: Lusophone Literature
description: Authors from the eight nations whose official language is Portuguese, plus former colonies and regions of important Portuguese influence.  Included are Luso-American and Azorean writers, as well as authors from East Timor (formerly Indonesia), Goa (India), and Macau (China).

title: Literature Synthesis & Review
description: Strategies, methods, and habits for writing and publishing effective critical literature reviews. Students must already have a research topic selected, defined narrowly enough to do meaningful inquiry, and approved by their advisor before taking the course.

title: Literature, Ethics, and Values
description: Study of how literature conveys ethics and values as well as the ways in which ethics and values animate the study of literature.

title: Living Legends
description: Performance that specializes in the music and cultural dance of the Native American, Latin, and Polynesian cultures. Performers will focus on technique and analysis, cultural expertise, performance skills, and leadership. \n

title: Livy
description: Selections from Livy's Ab Urbe Condita.

title: LLM Thesis
description: The student must carry out a substantial research project falling within the area of expertise of a law faculty member who is willing to supervise the student's research.  The required work product is a written research paper which is expected to make a significant scholarly contribution.

title: Local Government 1
description: Introduction to the dynamic world of local government. Topics include forms of government, political relationships and policy making, and issues of service delivery.

title: Local Government 2
description: Current issues facing local governments, including planning, land use and zoning, annexation, growth and sprawl, economic development, and other contemporary issues.

title: Location Production
description: This course introduces students to approaches utilized while working on location, with an emphasis on lighting, set design, and other elements involved with location shoots.

title: Image Acquisition & Processing
description: Small Unmanned Aerial Systems (sUAS) provide high-quality aerial imagery. Emphasizes flight planning, acquisition, and processing of sUAS data to study a variety of complex natural and human systems. Prepare and sit for FAA commercial sUAS license exam.

title: Luso-Brazilian Cinema
description: Introduction to the study of film; background in appreciating the best of motion picture art in Brazil, Portugal, and other Lusophone countries.

title: Luso-Brazilian Cinema
description: Introduction to study of film; background in appreciating the best of motion picture art in Brazil, Portugal and other Lusophone countries.

title: Luso-Brazilian Theatre Prod
description: Theory and practice of dramatic performance. Includes participation in a play to be performed during semester.

title: Luso-Braz Theat Pr
description: Theory and practice of dramatic performance. Includes participation in play to be performed during semester.

title: Lyric
description: Problems of lyric poetry.

title: MA Practicum 1
description: Critical strategies and interpretative skills necessary for MA examinations.

title: MA Practicum 2
description: Critical strategies and interpretative skills necessary for MA examinations.

title: MA Practicum 3
description: Research tools and methods, the process of selecting a thesis topic, compiling a bibliography,  and writing a prospectus.

title: Machado de Assis
description: Critical study of the works of Brazilian author Joaquim Maria Machado de Assis.

title: Machine Learning
description: Learn to create many of the most common types of supervised and unsupervised machine learning models. Learn advanced automation techniques for machine learning pipelines.

title: Machine Learning
description: Supervised and unsupervised learning; model evaluation; recommendation systems; natural language process and unstructured data; deep learning.\n

title: Machine Learning Algorithms
description: Create all types of machine learning models including regression, classification, clustering, forecasting, and text modeling. Learn automation techniques for machine learning pipelines

title: Machine Learning & Dynamic Opt
description: Machine Learning and Dynamic Optimization is a graduate level course on the theory and applications of numerical solutions of time-varying systems with a focus on engineering design and real-time control applications. Concepts taught in this course include physics-based and empirical modeling, machine learning classification and regression, nonlinear programming, estimation, and advanced control methods such as model predictive control.

title: Machine Learning for Bio
description: Students will learn concepts and applications of machine-learning techniques applied to diverse types of biological data.

title: Machine Learning for Econ
description: Theory and practice of machine learning methods for applications in economics.

title: Machine Learning for Engineers
description: Machine Learning for Engineers combines mathematical details with several case studies that provide an intuition for machine learning with methods for classification, regression, and dimensionality reduction. A second phase of the course is a hands-on group project. The engineering problems and theory guide the student towards a working fluency in state-of-the-art methods implemented in Python.

title: Machine Learning: Found & Apps
description: Introduction to fundamental concepts of machine learning in an engineering context. Students will learn foundational mathematical principles underlying machine learning, select and implement machine learning algorithms, and evaluate and improve the performance of models. Special attention is given to engineering problems, including those involving time series data and dynamical systems.

title: MHD Plasma Theory
description: Plasma equilibrium and dynamics using magnetohydrodynamic theory with application to fusion and astrophysical plasmas.

title: Makeup Design
description: \tComprehensive course in makeup design for stage and screen: prosthetics; advanced makeup effects; makeup theory; script research; collaboration techniques; preparation for work as assistant and/or full designer positions in departmental productions.

title: Makeup for Media
description: Advanced projects in makeup application.

title: Mammalogy
description: Mammalian diversity, evolution, distribution, and natural history. Two three-day field trips required.

title: Mammals of North America
description: Focus on the ecology, identification, and management of mammals commonly found in western North America. Learning mammalian characteristics; developing an understanding of mammalian evolution and biogeography; gaining knowledge of mammalian taxonomy, physiological adaptations, and behaviors specific to species found in western North America. Emphasis on sampling methods and techniques used in the conservation and management of these species.

title: Mgmt & Information Technology
description: Management and control with information technology.  Information flow, database design, and use applied to cost controls and managerial decision making.

title: Mgt & Leadership
description: Principles of leadership, problem solving, decisions, discipline, and human relations. Emphasis on career planning as an Air Force junior officer.

title: Mgt & Leadership
description: Writing, speaking, and listening as communication skills; management concepts; responsibilities and ethics for an Air Force junior officer.

title: Management Communication
description: Developing written and oral communications for professional organizations, including composing and designing employment communications. Incorporates oral presentations.

title: Mgmt Consulting & Projects
description: Projects-oriented course where students get hands-on experience performing consulting jobs for businesses in Utah.  Class includes both in-class instruction and business experience.

title: Management Field Study
description: Students complete consulting projects working with faculty and management to resolve business issues.

title: Mgmt in Dietetics
description: Management cycle and theory applied to clinical and administrative dietetics.

title: Management Seminar
description: Invited guests speak on topics of general management interest ranging from ethics, industry problems and opportunities, and government policies to relevant current events.

title: Managerial Accounting 1
description: Objectives and procedures of cost accounting.  Topics include job costing, joint product costing, cost behavior analysis, standard costs, cost allocation problems, and cost data use in management.

title: Managerial Accounting 1
description: Objectives and procedures of cost accounting. Topics include job costing, joint product costing, cost behavior analysis, standard costs, cost allocation problems, and cost data use in management.

title: Acctng & Computer Concepts
description: Accounting systems and processes emphasizing use of management control, financial analysis, decision making, performance evaluation. Spreadsheets and database management.

title: Managerial Finance
description: Topics include working capital management, financial forecasting, asset valuation, capital budgeting, capital structure, cost of capital, investing, international finance, firm valuation, etc. discussed in a framework for both corporations and personal life.

title: Managerial Finance
description: Overview of financial management issues including capital budgeting, cost of capital, capital structure/dividends, and long-term financial planning.

title: Managerial Leadrshp Develpmnt
description: Principles and practices needed to serve as effective leaders in families, church, community, and work settings -- planning, decision making, self-awareness, effective human influence, and community building.

title: Managing a Dietetics Career
description: As graduate dietetics students consider entering the dietetics workforce, they will explore their personal strengths and career ambitions and be exposed to practical information about career management in dietetics.

title: Managing a Software Startup
description: Focuses on managing the people, processes, and infrastructure that promote a scalable, sustainable, and sellable software product. Additional focus on decisions faced by the chief technology officer, tech founder, or other tech lead in helping build a new venture. Gain practical managerial and technical experience utilizing a lean-startup approach to implement a tech strategy and architecture for a software startup.  Major topics include managing product innovation, managing the dev methodology, managing tech team, designing architecture, managing security, and supporting sales.\n

title: Managing Belonging & Inclusion
description: Learn best practices for creating and managing a diverse and inclusive workforce, including tactics organizations may take to manage belonging and inclusion and steps individuals may take to create more inclusive environments and relationships.

title: Managing High Performance Bldg
description: Evolving technologies, energy performance, codes, safety, and financial expectations for high performance buildings. Prepare capital and operating budgets with a focus on Total Cost of Ownership financial modeling.

title: Managing New Ventures
description: Learn skills and tools to start and manage an early-stage company: building a founding team and management team, raising capital, determining legal structures and addressing other legal issues, hiring and growing the company, working with boards, collaborating with supplier & channel partners, establishing critical systems.

title: Managing New Ventures
description: How to operate, grow, and exit new ventures and family-owned businesses following their creation and funding. Consulting project required.

title: Managing Risk in Construction
description: Managing the factors that create risk in a construction company, including contract administration, ethical practices, safety, international risks, insurances, and bonding.

title: MFG Electronics & Microsystems
description: Basics of electricity; behavior and manufacture of resistors, inductors, capacitors, transformers; motors; manufacture of transistors, ICs, MCMs, circuit boards. Computers; digital communications; networking.

title: Graduate Thesis
description: Under the guidance of a faculty mentor, students will carry out research that helps them write and defend a thesis toward the completion of a Masters degree.

title: MFGEN Special Topics
description: Topics arranged in consultation with instructor.

title: Mfg Info Systems
description: Applying and integrating software and information technologies in planning, executing, and monitoring production operations.

title: Manufacturing Leadership
description: Lectures on personal and professional development, ethics, global leadership, and belonging. An emphasis on resumes and internship preparation will be included.

title: Materials & Processes
description: Manufacturing tools, processes, and materials commonly used in product design.

title: Manufacturing Processes
description: Common manufacturing processes, including technological limitations and economic considerations. Influence of product design on process selection and manufacturing efficiency.

title: Manufacturing Simulation
description: Design and optimization of manufacturing systems using simulation. Simulation languages and modeling methodology.

title: Mfg Systems
description: Analyzing lean manufacturing systems. Numerous examples and case studies from industry demonstrating principles of lean production, inventory management, and lean distribution. Project with a local company to gain confidence with these principles in an industrial setting.

title: Manufg Systms Analysis & Dsgn
description: Analysis, synthesis, and control of processing and assembly operations; mathematical modeling of manufacturing processes; systems integration; applying conservation principles to processing and assembly operations.

title: Mfg Systems & Simulation
description: Advanced elements, planning and integration issues of manufacturing systems, including modeling and simulation of manufacturing operations.  How to apply simulation to validate lean processes that eliminate waste, learn the basics of queuing theory, basic statistical analysis by analyzing raw data and fitting that data to the proper distribution, how to run multi-scenario experiments that are statistically correct by running multiple replications to provide valid confidence intervals of performance. \n

title: Mapping Your World
description: Managing and portraying geospatial information to solve geographic tasks using maps (cartography), aerial and satellite imagery (remote sensing), location services (GPS), and quantitative methods.

title: Mariachi Band
description: Musical group that meets regularly to rehearse and perform mariachi numbers (vocal, instrumental, or both) from Spanish-speaking countries.

title: Marine Biology
description: Independent student research under faculty supervision.

title: Marine Biology
description: Principles of physical and biological oceanography, biodiversity, and ecology of numerous ocean habitats.

title: Marr & Fam Enrichment/Therapy
description: Theories and techniques. Professional family enrichment and therapy applied to couples and families.

title: Marital,Indiv Psyc
description: Assessment, intervention techniques, therapist's role, and principle processes in theories of systemic individual and marital psychotherapy.

title: Marital Relationships
description: Critical analysis of literature regarding dating, spouse selection, and transition to marriage processes leading to successful marriage, as well as processes for maintaining, strengthening, and repairing marital relationships. Preparation for research and teaching in the field.

title: Marketing Analytics
description: Key issues in using data and analytical techniques to identify marketing insights from business data.

title: Marketing & Brand Consulting
description: Marketing consulting projects with real clients, from business development to project execution and delivery.

title: Marketing Lecture Series
description: Marketing executive guest lecture series. Students will gain exposure to marketing professionals and insight into the challenges and opportunities of marketing careers.

title: Marketing Management
description: Marketing's role in society and the firm, marketing opportunities, the consumer market, and management of marketing mix.

title: Marketing Management
description: Development of analytical marketing tools and techniques; their utilization in case analysis and decision making in marketing management.

title: Marketing Management
description: Development of analytical marketing tools and techniques; their utilization in case analysis and decision making in marketing management.

title: Mrkt Media Planning & Strategy
description: Media planning, theory, and practice in context of the marketing mix. Application of computer-based models as aids to media decisions. Writing of marketing- based media plans. Case study approach to both print and broadcast media.

title: Marketing Research
description: Concepts and methodology for conducting marketing research. Emphasis on solving problems faced by the marketing manager. Consulting research project required.

title: Marketing Strategy
description: Integration of finance, marketing, and case studies in economic concepts and techniques in marketing decision making and planning.

title: Markets & Society
description: Economic sociology exploring social dynamics of market behavior from an interdisciplinary perspective; topics include social factors related to value, price, and price volatility.

title: Marriage & Family Practice
description: Methods of assessment, planning intervention, and evaluation and termination with marital dyads, family, and community.

title: Marriage Enhancement
description: Enhancing marital communication skills, conflict resolution styles, intimacy, stress management, and developing a shared relationship vision using social science theories and research findings.

title: Marriott Student Review
description: Develop advanced communication skills by engaging in real-world projects. Collaborate to publish a student, peer-reviewed business journal in both print and digital formats, as well as create business podcasts in English and Spanish.

title: Martial Arts
description: Hybrid martial art class based primarily in Jui-Jitsu. Show and explain proper etiquette expected in martial arts, perform basic grappling control tactices, and participate in grappling martial art competition.

title: Marx, Nietzsche, Freud
description: An introduction to the ideas of Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud in historical and contemporary contexts.

title: Masonry Design
description: Introduction to analysis, design, and construction of masonry structures. Compressive, tensile, flexural, and shear behavior of masonry structural components.

title: Mass Comm & Soc
description: Historical and modern roles of mass media in society, emphasizing media effects on individuals and institutions.

title: Media History & Philosophy
description: Historical and philosophical development of today's media. Approaches may include theories of media change, social responsibility, economic factors, and influential pioneers.

title: Master Seminar
description: Special topics seminar on topics relevant to the fields of media and/or performance studies.

title: Master's Action Rsrch Project
description: Design, production, and evaluation of MA action research project in the student's language of emphasis.

title: Master's Internship
description: Practical experience in state office, local school districts, higher education, and other agencies.

title: Master's Project
description: Design, production, and evaluation of MA project in Linguistics or TESOL. May involve various media: paper/print, computer software, audio recordings, or video recordings. Supervised by graduate advisory committee chair.

title: Master's Project
description: Clinical project required for non-thesis option in MFT.

title: Master's Project
description: Making a significant contribution to the advancement of theory, research, and/or practice through a successful development, implementation, and evaluation or critique of an evaluation, measurement, research, or design project.

title: Master's Project
description: Applied project demonstrating skills, knowledge, and competencies in the nutrition and dietetics field.

title: Master's Project
description: Students will make a significant contribution to the advancement of theory, research, and/or practice through the successful development, implementation, and evaluation or critique of a design project related to the field of Technology and Engineering Studies.

title: Project
description: Plan, implement, and evaluate a clinical quality improvement project.

title: Master's Project
description: Culmination of acquired skills and knowledge that will consist of the application of such, utilizing project based assessment.

title: Professnl Improvement Project
description: Presentation of project and written report.

title: Master's Project
description: Candidates in nonthesis program may complete approved field project as their writing/research experience.

title: Master's Research Project
description: Applying research and statistical methods to evaluative, experimental, and survey studies in social work.  Research project of publishable quality required.

title: Master's Thesis
description: Includes a review of the research literature and a report on the research study. Thesis students are encouraged to work with faculty members in their areas of research.

title: Master's Thesis
description: Concluding research for master's program, culminating in final oral examination.

title: Master's Thesis
description: Written report that places final exhibition in a contextual setting and defines, defends, and justifies its existence. Report clarifying how exhibit verifies original proposal.

title: Master's Thesis
description: 699R is the thesis advisement course during which graduate students meet with their committee chair to discuss their graduate thesis or graduate project.

title: Master's Thesis
description: Formal report/defense of substantive research, evaluation, or curriculum project that makes original contribution to field. Thesis credit hours distributed and accompanied by seminars.

title: Master's Thesis
description: Students demonstrate significant oral and written communication skills and research competencies through conceiving, proposing, and defending a thesis.

title: Master's Thesis
description: Making a significant contribution to the advancement of theory, research, measurement, and/or practice through proposing, implementing, and writing a research study.

title: Masterpieces of Russian Film
description: Developing listening comprehension and speaking skills through discussing Russian films.  Includes International Cinema.

title: Russian Literature 1
description: Survey of shorter masterpieces in Russian.

title: Russian Literature 2
description: Survey of shorter masterpieces in Russian.

title: Russian Novel in English
description: Survey of Russian novels by such authors as Pushkin, Tolstoy, Dostoevsky, and Pasternak.

title: Masterpieces of World Lit 1
description: Major world civilizations from antiquity through the early Italian Renaissance, approached through literature and emphasizing socioeconomic, religious, political, intellectual, and aesthetic developments.

title: Masterpieces of World Lit 2
description: Major world civilizations from Europe's High Renaissance to modern times, approached through literature and emphasizing socioeconomic, religious, political, intellectual, and aesthetic developments.

title: Material Removal
description: Methods and procedures to shape materials using basic machine tools; cutting theory, tool selection, metrology methods, and machine operation. Introduction to computer numerical control.

title: Materials and Reactions Lab
description: Walk-in laboratory course covering topics from Material Science and Chemical Reaction Engineering.

title: Materials and Surfacing
description: Shading and rendering techniques for the attainment of desired visual effects:  use of shading languages for the realization of both photorealistic and non-photorealistic imaging.

title: Extreme Environments
description: This class introduces students to models and empirical data that predict safe operational ranges for materials in high temperature, irradiated, and corrosive environments.\nMethods to measure material properties and performance in each environment are discussed, as well as the fundamental mechanisms that cause changes in material properties. \n

title: Materials Modeling
description: Theory and application of various computer simulations to model, understand, and predict the properties of real materials.  Specific topics include: first-principles atomistic models, empirical potential atomistic models, mesoscale models, and continuum finite element analysis.

title: Materials of Painting.
description: Introduction to the techniques and history of producing painting materials, exploring traditional supports, grounds, mediums, and paint production. Most of the course will be spent making painting materials.

title: Materials Science Seminar
description: Students will attend department or college seminars that pertain to the materials science discipline. This will expand their breadth and scope of materials science and help prepare them for graduate school or employment in materials science.\n

title: Matrnl/Chld Nutrition & Health
description: Critical examination of current nutrition-related research, legislation, and policy guidelines for the life stages of pregnancy, lactation, infancy and school-aged children, with the preparation of a nutrition-related public policy position paper based on one of these life stages.

title: Business Career Essentials
description: Introduction for science, math, and statistics majors to careers in industry. Project planning, oral and written business presentations, business accounting, and technology readiness.

title: History & Philosophy of Math
description: Historical development of important mathematical ideas and philosophies; implications for the mathematical curriculum.

title: Survey of Geometry
description: Logical and historical development of Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometry, transformations and symmetry; relationships among axiomatic systems; use of software and other geometric models; proofs and Van Hiele levels.

title: Mathematical Analysis 1
description: Development of theory of vector spaces, linear maps, inner product spaces, spectral theory, metric space topology, differentiation, contraction mappings and convex analysis.

title: Mathematical Analysis 1 Lab
description: Programming algorithms to implement the key mathematical methods taught in Math 344.  Applications presented.  Developing models and applying results of computations to the application domain.

title: Mathematical Analysis 2
description: Theory of Riemann-Darboux integration, calculus on curves and surfaces, complex integration, spectral calculus, generalized inverses of matrices, basic matrix perturbation theory, groups of permutations and matrices.  Time permitting, exterior calculus and differential forms.

title: Mathematical Analysis 2 Lab
description: Programming algorithms and using functions to implement the mathematical methods taught in Math 346. Applications presented. Developing models and applying results of computations to the application domain.

title: Mathematical Biology
description: Using tools in mathematics to help biologists.  Motivating new mathematics with questions in biology.

title: Mathematical Cryptography
description: A mathematical introduction to some of the high points of modern cryptography.

title: Mathematical Finance
description: The binomial asset pricing model (discrete probability). Martingales, pricing of derivative securities, random walk in financial models, random interest rates.

title: Mathematics of Data Science
description: Mathematical aspects of data science, including high-dimensional geometry and linear algebra, optimization, and probabilistic modeling.

title: Mathematics of Deep Learning
description: Mathematics necessary to understand how deep neural networks are formulated and designed. Analyzing the stability, generalizability, and potential extension of neural networks to new datasets.

title: Mathematical Physics
description: Topics in modern theoretical physics, including applications of matrix and tensor analysis and linear differential and integral operators.

title: Mathematical Physics
description: Topics in modern theoretical physics, including applications of matrix and tensor analysis and linear differential and integral operators.

title: Math Thry of Elec & Mag
description: Advanced electrostatics and magnetostatics, Maxwell's equations and electromagnetic waves, relativistic electrodynamics, radiation theory, and interaction of matter with electromagnetic fields.

title: Math Thry of Elec & Mag
description: Advanced electrostatics and magnetostatics, Maxwell's equations and electromagnetic waves, relativistic electrodynamics, radiation theory, and interaction of matter with electromagnetic fields.

title: Math for Engr 1
description: Multivariable calculus, linear algebra, and numerical methods.

title: Math for Engineering 2
description: ODEs, Laplace transforms, Fourier series, PDEs.

title: Math for Physical Chemistry
description: Instruction in the mathematics relevant for physical chemistry, particularly in multivariable calculus, differential equations, and series expansions. Other topics, such as linear algebra, will be revisited in the context of physical chemistry. Computational software, such as Matlab, will be used to solve complex problems with numerical methods.

title: Math of Signals & Systems
description: Introduction to mathematics of signal processing, communication, and control theory; linear spaces, Eigenvalue and singular-value decompositions, quadratic forms, linear operators, adjoints, dual spaces.

title: Math Tchng in Public Schools
description: Developing skill in designing and implementing lesson plans that include high-cognitive demand tasks; anticipating, monitoring, and building on student mathematical thinking; and orchestrating mathematical discussions that lead to student understanding of fundamental mathematics concepts.

title: Teaching with Tech
description: Examining technological tools that illustrate mathematical concepts and assist in solving mathematics problems. Using technology tools to investigate modeling, highlight mathematical relationships, and motivate proof. Additionally, exploring and creating algorithms, functions, constructions, and transformations.

title: Matrix Analysis
description: Special classes of matrices, canonical forms, matrix and vector norms, localization of eigenvalues, matrix functions, applications.

title: Matrix Theory 1
description: Symmetric matrices, spectral graph theory, interlacing, the Laplacian matrix of a graph.

title: Matrix Theory 2
description: Research topics in combinatorial matrix theory.

title: MDT Vocal Technique 2.
description: Contemporary vocal styles and techniques, including pop/belt, stage, and studio singing.

title: Aircraft Structures
description: Requirements, objectives, loads, materials, and tools for design of airframe structures; static behavior of thin-wall structures; durability and damage tolerance; certification and testing. Airframe component team design project.

title: Composite Structures
description: Design and analysis of advanced composite structures; deflections, buckling, and vibration of thin plates and sandwich plates; design guidelines; design examples; project.

title: Computer Struc Optimization
description: Matrix stiffness method for 1D, 2D, and 3D skeletal structure classes. Implementing the matrix stiffness method as a computer program. Nonlinear second-order structural analysis. Structural optimization techniques including stress-ratio method, gradient-based methods, and genetic algorithms.

title: CAE Software Development
description: Programming methods for development of engineering software. Data structures, architecture, libraries, and graphical user interfaces, with applications to CAD systems.

title: Continuum & Solid Mechanics
description: Derivation of partial differential equations of continuum mechanics. Closed-form solution of classical problems in elasticity. Theory of beams, plates, and axisymmetric shells with closed-form solutions. Large displacement strain tensors, stress tensors, equilibrium equations, beam theory, and plate theory. Constitutive theory including nonlinear elasticity, viscoelasticity, plasticity, and hyperelasticity.

title: Linear Finite Element Methods
description: Linear static finite element analysis of elastic solids; problem formulation, finite element discretization, and equation solving; stability, interpolation theory, and error estimates. Introduction to underlying continuum mechanics principles. Isogeometric analysis as a generalization of classical finite element analysis; basic principles of analysis-suitable computational geometry. Introduction to the industrial practice of finite element modeling leveraging commercial packages. Topics include CAD preprocessing, an overview of the mesh generation process and simulation model setup, and how to effectively use appropriate solution strategies for a given problem. Application domains include strength and durability, vibrations, transient structural dynamics, and multi-physics problems.

title: Nonlinear Finite Element Mthds
description: Nonlinear dynamic finite element analysis of solids.  Nonlinear continuum mechanics, finite element formulation, and elementary solution algorithms for nonlinear algebraic problems. focusing on hyperelastic solids.  Advanced topics in isogeometric analysis, computational analysis-suitable geometry, and adaptivity.  An introduction to dynamics; basic methods of time integration, such

title: Optimization Techniques
description: Application of computational optimization techniques to constrained engineering design.  Theory and application of gradient-based and gradient-free algorithms for unconstrained and constrained nonlinear problems.  Robust design methods.

title: Structural Vibrations
description: Dynamic analysis of single degree-of-freedom, discrete multi-degree-of-freedom, and continuous systems. Applications include aerospace, civil structures, and mechanical components.

title: Design of Control Systems
description: Classical frequency response and time domain design of control systems. State variable control and computer simulation of control systems.

title: Linear System Theory
description: Mathematical introduction to time-varying linear systems; state-space descriptions, controllability, observability, Lyapunov stability, observer-based control.  Design of linear quadratic regulators and infinite-horizon Kalman filters.

title: Non-Linear System Theory
description: Mathematical introduction to non-linear dynamic systems. Topics include Lyapunov methods, passivity, input-output stability, and non-linear feedback design.

title: MEMS
description: Design, fabrication, and applications of MEMS. Mechanical properties governing their design and reliability and the processing technologies used to fabricate them.

title: Acoustic Systems
description: Analyzing and modeling electro-mechano-acoustic systems. Transducers, calibration, and acoustical measurements. Sound sources, arrays, coupling, radiation, and directivity. Duct acoustics and acoustic filters.

title: Fundamentals of Acoustics
description: Vibrating systems, elastic media, mechanical energy, and radiation. Sound generation, transmission, reflection, and reception.

title: Introduction to Acoustics
description: Mathematical descriptions of physical phenomena in generation, propagation, and reception of acoustic waves. Fundamental acoustical instrumentation and analysis techniques. Application of physical principles and mathematical models to realistic problems.\n \n

title: Meaning in Language
description: Introduction to the analysis of meaning in words, grammar, and discourse.

title: Measure and Integration Theory
description: Abstract measure and integration theory; L(p) spaces; measures on topological and Euclidean spaces.

title: Measurement in Accounting
description: Case-based course that examines measurement issues in accounting. Focuses on techniques and approaches used in practice for measuring financial instruments, acquisitions, revenue recognition, and asset impairments, among others. Also focuses on measurements used by entities to report Environmental-Social-Governance (ESG) and Sustainability matters.

title: Measurement Project
description: Designing, conducting, and reporting a comprehensive measurement project.

title: Measurement Theory
description: Classical and modern models for measuring human attributes. Issues related to reliability, validity, item selection, scoring, standard setting, and test equating. Use of item response theory and generalizability theory.

title: Mechanical Behavior
description: Engineering methods for modeling deformation, fracture and fatigue of materials, including metals, polymers, composites and ceramics. Deformation modes include elastic, plastic, viscoelastic and creep.

title: Mechanical Behavior
description: Engineering methods for modeling deformation, fracture and fatigue of materials, including metals, polymers, composites and ceramics. Deformation modes include elastic, plastic, viscoelastic and creep.

title: Mech Spinal Impair & Mobil
description: Study of human spinal motion and function in relation to manual therapy techniques used to restore spinal mechanics.

title: Mechanical Sys Dsgn Fundmntls
description: Static and dynamic stress and failure analysis for mechanical systems.

title: Mechncl Systms Dsgn Applctns
description: Theory, analysis, and design of mechanical systems and components.

title: Mechanical Vibrations
description: Introduction to energy methods for system modeling, eigenvalues and mode shapes, frequency response, and spectral characterization of vibrations.

title: Mechanics
description: Newton's laws applied to particles and systems of particles, including rigid bodies. Conservation principles and Lagrange's and Hamilton's equations.

title: Mechanisms of Molecular Biol
description: Second-semester biochemistry. Nucleic acid biochemistry and molecular biology: nucleotide metabolism, chromosome and chromatin structure, DNA structure and replication, RNA transcription and gene expression, protein synthesis and regulation, eukaryotic gene systems, signal transduction.

title: Media Advocacy & Social Change
description: Communication principles, theories, and approaches applied to effect social change. Approaches may include public policy, grass roots advocacy, social marketing, and social movements.

title: Media and Culture
description: Issues related to gender, race, and class in the communication process.  Implications of current developments in critical theory and issues of diversity.

title: Media & Perf Hist & Theory 1
description: Media and Performance history sites - beginnings through 1900 - emphasizing existing archives, representative texts and cultural documents, and contemporary criticism.

title: Media & Perf Hist & Theory 2
description: Media and Performance history sites - 1900-today - emphasizing existing archives, representative texts and cultural documents, and contemporary criticism.

title: Media and Pop Lit after 1800
description: Study of the codes, conventions, contexts, transmissions, and transformations of popular literary texts from 1800 to the present. Special attention will be paid to the medium and reception of these texts.

title: Media and Pop Lit before 1800
description: Study of the codes, conventions, contexts, transmissions, and transformations of popular literary texts before 1800. Special attention will be paid to the medium and reception of these texts.

title: Media & Religion
description: Seminar regarding the interface of media and religion.

title: Media&Tech in Foreign Lang Ins
description: Applying modern technology and instructional media in teaching foreign languages.

title: Media & the First Amendment
description: Advanced understanding of media law, policy, and regulation of free speech and press. Approaches may include Freedom of Information, rights of press, government control, and legal precedents regarding the First Amendment.

title: Media & Their Audiences
description: Understanding media content and channels empowering and improving media consumption and interpretation. Approaches may include new technology, social media, consumer behavior, media criticism, and media literacy.

title: Media and World Religions
description: The interaction of media, world religions, and beliefs. Approaches may include media coverage and portrayal of religion, religions' use of media, conflict between the two, and communicating across religious cultures.

title: Media Arts Crew
description: Practical supervised experience in media arts production. Exposure to protocols, as well as organizational and technical aspects.

title: Media Arts Experience
description: Practical introductory experience working in media environments (including film and broadcast facilities).

title: Media Arts Genres
description: Intensive analysis of a single major traditional media genre (i.e., western, musical, sitcom, or melodrama) with consideration of contextual, subtextual, and textual issues.

title: Media Arts History 1
description: Survey of social, aesthetic, business, and technical dimensions of film and media from 1895 to 1945.

title: Media Arts History 2
description: Survey of social, aesthetic, business, and technical dimensions of film and media from 1946 to present.

title: Media as a Mirror of Our Times
description: Interdisciplinary approach to media texts as aesthetic and historical documents expressing a people, place, and time.

title: Media Collaboration
description: Experience collaborating with senior capstone media arts experience.

title: Media Design & Graphics
description: Foundational principles and theories of visual communication; use of graphics to communicate information and support persuasive appeals.

title: Media Effects
description: Effects resulting from the interaction between media and members of society.  Approaches may include self-image, sterotypes, violence, and other social constructs and behaviors involving media consumption.

title: Media Effects
description: Media's roles in major social settings. Capstone course, including preparation for comprehensive exams.

title: Media Ethics & Moral Reasoning
description: Advanced application of moral reasoning and understanding of ethical issues in mass communication. Approaches may include current cases and issues, professional practices, and philosophical foundations of ethics.

title: Media Ethics
description: Advanced application of moral reasoning and understanding of ethical issues in mass communication pertaining to diverse and inclusive audiences. Approaches may include current cases and issues, professional practices, and issues of racial and gender diversity within ethical practice.\n

title: Media in Contemporary Clssrm
description: Developing educational methods and techniques for using media in the specialized media classroom; study of educational models and theories related to historical and emerging media technologies.

title: Media Innovations Capstone
description: Synthesis of news media competencies gained through successful completion of directed project. Projects may include a digital media product, in-depth reportage or documentary.

title: Media Law
description: The intersection of media and the law and impact upon the press. Prior restraint, reporter's privilege, access to court proceedings, libel, appropriation, and rights of privacy.

title: Media Law & Responsibility
description: Introduction to First Amendment history and press freedom, law, and theory; media regulation and policy; relationship between law and ethics; key ethical issues in professional communications.

title: Media Literacy Education
description: Media literacy principles and basic film production in the context of educating students and teachers in local K-12 public schools.

title: Media Orchestration
description: Emphasizes the theory and advance practices associated with creating realistic orchestral and contemporary production music through the use of sample libraries, synths, software, and other resources.

title: Media Production Experience
description: Basics of film and video production as they apply to the secondary classroom/student.

title: Media Sale/Promo
description: Fundamentals of media sales process.  Theory and application of persuasion relating to media sales.

title: Media, Fam & Human Dev
description: Aspects of media and their potential effects on family interactions and human development across the lifespan.

title: Mediation Practicum
description: Students build on the basic skills they learned in Basic Mediation both in weekly meetings and in participating in actual mediations in small claims court and other venues.

title: Mediation Techniques & Practic
description: Mediation helps people more effectively resolve disputes. Build mediation skills; develop a greater capacity to communicate, empathize, and reduce conflict.

title: Medical Anthropology
description: Interactions between culture and health in comparative perspective, emphasizing social, historical, and ecological determinants.

title: Medical Geography
description: Understanding how geographic locations influence health outcomes. Learning to identify geographic patterns of health and disease as a tool to improve overall understanding of disease etiology and development of effective prevention and control strategies. The course utilizes geographic information systems (GIS) to meet these goals. No prior experience with the software is required.

title: Medical Imaging & Image Recon
description: Fundamentals of medical imaging modalities (x-ray, CT, ultrasound, and MRI) from a signals and systems perspective, magnetic resonance physics, medical image reconstruction methods (backprojection, partial-Fourier techniques, parallel imaging, compressed sensing).

title: Medical issues  in AT
description: Discussion of current medical issues in athletic training with guest lectures by medical specialists from the community.

title: Med Nutr Therapy 1
description: Nutritional assessment and medical nutrition therapy across disease states.

title: Med Nutr Therapy 2
description: Medical nutrition therapy across disease states; continuation of NDFS 300.

title: Medical Parasitology
description: Pathogenesis, diagnosis, and epidemiology of human parasitic diseases.

title: Medical Sociology
description: Social epidemiology, the sick role, sociocultural definitions of and responses to illness, and the organization of medical-health delivery systems.

title: Medical Speech Pathology
description: Genetic, gestational, and neurogenic factors related to communication disorders in children and adults; role of the speech-language pathologist in medical teams.

title: Medicinal Botany
description: Independent student research under faculty supervision.

title: Medieval Europe Women Writers
description: Readings in European literature by women in the Middle Ages (prior to 1500).

title: Medieval Latin
description: Study of particular periods (e.g., Carolingian renaissance, twelfth-century renaissance) or genres (e.g., historiography, epic, autobiography), or survey of medieval Latin.

title: Medieval Lit
description: Problems of literary periodization in medieval literature.

title: Medieval Spanish Literature
description: Spanish Literature from El Cantar de Mio Cid (1140) through La Celestina (1499).

title: Medieval Span Lit
description: Spanish literature from El Cantar de Mio Cid (1140) through La Celestina (1499).

title: Meditation
description: Learn and apply methods of meditation to quiet the mind.

title: Design & Materials Applicatns
description: Materials selection in design; effects of materials properties, structure and geometry on performance; process selection and property modification techniques; basics of material failure mechanism.

title: Spectral Analysis Dynamic Sys
description: Digital signal processing and analysis applied to computer-aided testing, system identification, and characterization of random processes. Applications include vibration and acoustic testing, seismic recording and analysis, and system identification for control.

title: Stress Analysis & Design
description: Stress analysis and deflection of structures; general bending and torsion, with computer applications to mechanical and aerospace structure design.

title: Men's Chorus
description: Ensemble of male voices that performs a variety of styles and repertoire, ranging from the established literature to popular idioms of the 20th century.  Audition required.

title: Ment Tch Stdn  w/ Mild/Mod Dis
description: Mentored learning experience in the effective teaching cycle for students with mild/moderate disabilities. Experience will take place in a grade K-6 classroom in one the BYU Public School Partnership districts.

title: Ment Sec Ed: M/M Disabilities
description: Mentored field experience in teaching students with mild-moderate disabilities in secondary settings within the BYU Public School Partnership districts.

title: Ment Tchg Stds Severe Dis Elem
description: Mentored learning experience in the effective teaching cycle for students with severe disabilities. Experience will take place in a grade K-6 classroom in one the BYU Public School Partnership districts.

title: Ment Sec Ed: Severe Disability
description: Mentored field experience in teaching students with severe disabilities in secondary settings within the BYU Public School Partnership districts.

title: Mentored Internship
description: Approved experiential learning.

title: Mentored Learning Experience
description: Mentored learning for undergraduates in the fields of Environmental Sciences; Genetics, Genomics, and Biotechnology; Landscape Management; Wildlife and Wildlands Conservation.

title: Mentored Coursework
description: Selected topics in mechanical engineering.

title: Mentored Projects
description: Independent learning focused on an engineering project.

title: Mentored Learning
description: Undergraduate research experience under the direction of a faculty mentor.

title: Mentored Outreach Svc Learning
description: Develop or practice experiments, activities, and demonstrations for community outreach. Develop leadership and communication skills to support community engagement with chemistry and science.

title: Biomedical Projects
description: Experiential learning in complex problems focused on the intersection of Electrical Engineering, Computer Engineering, and Biomedical Engineering.\n

title: Mentored Research
description: Original research under the guidance of a faculty mentor.  Proposals must be approved by the department curriculum coordinator.

title: Mentored Research
description: Introduction to mentored research in the fields of Microbiology and Molecular Biology.

title: Mentored Research
description: Participating in research integrating material learned in major.  Emphasizes individual or collaborative research and creative thinking through active learning and reflective analysis.

title: Mentored Research
description: Collaborate with professors on mentoring grants or other public health-related research and initiatives.

title: Mentored Research
description: Independent student research under faculty supervision.

title: Mentored Research
description: Collaborating with graduate faculty of public health on mentoring grants or other health-related research and initiatives.

title: Mentored Research
description: Mentored research opportunity; specific content will be determined in consultation between the student and the mentoring professor. Invitation only, although you may suggest the option to a professor.

title: Mentored Research and Thesis
description: Experiential learning in complex problem solving inherent to fundamental research.

title: Mentored Research Practicum.
description: Conducting research in a mentored environment with a faculty-sponsored research project.

title: Mergers and Acquisitions
description: This course will review a wide range of issues related to buying and selling companies, including transaction alternatives, tax roadblocks, the essential elements of the acquisition agreement and risk allocation strategies of the buyer and the seller.  The course will address the differences between stock and asset acquisitions, and issues related to valuing a business, successor liability, a

title: M&A Simulation Course
description: A simulation skills course in which students role-play the lawyer in an M&A transaction.

title: Arch Mesoamerica
description: Cultural and environmental bases of ancient civilizations in Mexico and Central America. Olmec, Maya, Toltec, and Aztec cultures.

title: Metagenomics
description: Introduction to comparative and fuctional analysis of genomic and metagenomic datasets, including microbial functions that affect host health.  Analyzing existing and novel datasets with field-standard techniques.

title: Metallurgy
description: Fundamental principles of physical metallurgy and their application to design.

title: Metallurgy
description: Fundamental principles of physical metallurgy and their application to design.

title: Metals Processes
description: Capabilities and applications of common metal-processing methods, including relationships between part design, material, and process parameters.

title: Metamorphic Petrology
description: Principles of metamorphism, including chemical equilibrium and thermodynamics of metamorphic reactions, geothermobarometery, origin and interpretation of zoned metamorphic minerals, pressure-temperature paths, and metamorphism of pelites, mafic, ultramafic and carbonate rocks. Additional subjects based on interest of the students.

title: Metaphysics
description: Basic categories of being: appearance and reality, law, causality, space, time, eternity, deity.

title: Meteorology Science
description: In-service course for science teachers.

title: Methods 1 - Structural Systems
description: Basics of structural components in buildings. The content of this course will help the students understand the importance of these components, and how they are installed in buildings.  This brief component overview will look at the materials, processes, and applicable building code basics in buildings.

title: Methods 2 - Bldg Systems
description: Building Systems  is an introduction to the electrical, plumbing, and HVAC systems in buildings. The content of this course will help the students understand how these systems operate and how they contribute to our personal comfort and productivity. This brief systems overview will look at the infrastructure that provides the public utility services we need and how we use those utilities in our buildings, including history, design, materials, equipment, fixtures, etc.

title: Methods & Sources Greek NT
description: This class is an introduction to the academic study of the Greek New Testament designed for ANES majors and minors. It considers the historical context, cultural setting, literary framing, and content of key biblical writings, as well as various disciplinary and faith-informing approaches taken to these writings within the field of biblical studies..

title: Methods & Sources Hebrew Bible
description: This class is an introduction to the academic study of the Hebrew Bible (Old Testament) designed for ANES majors and minors. It considers the historical context, cultural setting, literary framing, and content of key biblical writings, as well as various disciplinary and faith-informing approaches taken to these writings within the field of biblical studies.

title: Methods in Teaching German
description: Developing meaningful and engaging instruction for secondary students in German; developing critical thinking, problem solving, literacy, and democratic character; assessing learner performance.

title: Mthds Tchg Nordic Languages
description: Prior or concurrent enrollment in this course required for student instructors of Nordic languages.  Focuses on teaching skills specific to foreign language instruction in beginning and intermediate language courses.

title: Methods of Portuguese Teaching
description: Methods for planning Portuguese language and culture instruction, teaching communicative skills, and assessing students' learning. Course is geared toward instructors at K-12 as well as university level.

title: Methods of Research in Soc
description: Tools of social research; survey, experimentation, content analysis, secondary analysis, qualitative research, evaluation research, data processing and analysis, and report writing.

title: Methods of Survey Sampling
description: Sampling frames; questionnaire design; simple random, systematic, stratified, and cluster sampling methods; comparing domain means; contingency table analysis.

title: Methods of Teaching Ballet
description: Teaching classical ballet from preballet through advanced; includes analysis of Bournonville, Cecchetti, Vaganova, RAD, Kneeland, and SAB methods.

title: MthdsTchg Chld Creative Dance
description: Methodologies of teaching children's creative dance with emphasis on the private dance studio setting.

title: Tchg Mthds of Mdrn & Cont Dnce
description: Teaching methodologies of contemporary modern dance including planning, teaching, and evaluating lessons for adolescents through adults.

title: Mthds of Tchg Cultural Dance
description: Theoretical and practical methodologies of teaching rhythmic dance.

title: Language Teaching Methods
description: Methods for teaching foreign languages. Topics include curriculum/lesson planning, teaching in the foreign language, contextualized approaches for teaching grammar and vocabulary, assessing language learning.

title: Methods of Tchg Social Dance
description: Pedagogy training in social dance at the bronze and silver skill levels.

title: Advanced Statistical Methods
description: Topics include advanced structural equations and hierarchical linear models, or panel data techniques and generalized linear models.

title: Child & Adolescent
description: Child and adolescent development in the context of social interaction, with particular emphasis on the family. Current theory and research evaluated.

title: Contemporary Fam Theories
description: Introduction to basic micro, macro, and processual approaches to study of the family; social and political theory on the family; philosophical issues and assumptions underlying family theory, research, and practice.

title: Ethnographic Tech
description: Rationale, methods, and limitations of qualitative research; includes participant observation and hermeneutic skills.

title: Experimental Design
description: Research methods, logic, writing, and data analysis.

title: Family Symposium
description: Presentation and discussion of professional papers about the family.

title: Seminar in Fam Relationships
description: Premarital dyad, marital dyad, and issues in family interaction and familial roles.

title: Outcome and Process Research
description: A survey of the state of the art of clinical outcome and process in Marriage and Family Therapy.

title: MFT Research and Statistics
description: Applied methods and statistics in marriage and family therapy research.  Outcomes include understanding research findings in research articles, ability to interpret statistical procedures (using SPSS or a similar software), developing a plan to prepare to use research in future professional development.

title: Microbial Ecology
description: Natural history of a microbe; its distribution and abundance. Critical influence of scale and perspective in determining underlying mechanisms.

title: Microbial Ecology Lab
description: Laboratory methods in microbial ecology and diversity.

title: Microbiology and Immunology
description: The focus of this course is to increase studentsâ€™ understanding of the structure, physiology, replicative mechanisms, and pathogenic mechanisms of bacteria and viruses, while touching more lightly on fungi and parasites since few of our faculty do research in this area. Additionally, students will master key concepts of both the innate and adaptive arms of the immune system and how immunity prevents and clears infections. Mechanisms of vaccines and anti-microbial drugs will also be covered.

title: Microbiology
description: Principles of prokaryotic biology emphasizing cell structure, function, and metabolism. Introduction to bacterial genetics, microbial diversity, and microbial ecology.

title: Microstructure & Properties
description: Representations of inhomogenous material microstructure, crystallography, orientation distribution functions, Fourier representations, bounding theories for defect-insensitive properties, grain boundaries and grain boundary engineering, microstructure sensitive design.

title: Micrwv Remote Sens
description: Emphasis on space-borne remote sensing of the earth's atmosphere, land, and oceans. Primary methods and applications for both active (radar) and passive (radiometry).

title: Middle & South America
description: Environmental, cultural, economic, and political parameters of Latin American societies.

title: Middle East
description: Physical and cultural geography of Southwest Asia and North Africa, emphasizing the cultural mosaic, geopolitics, environment, and resources of the region.

title: M E Hist from 1800
description: History of the Middle East in the modern period form 1800; rise of nation states, relationship with West, role of Islam.

title: M E Hist to 1800
description: History of the Middle East from the rise of of Islam until 1800.

title: Middle East Politics
description: Introduction to important themes, concepts, and cases in the study of the Middle East and North Africa, with particular attention to the domestic and international politics of the region.  Examination of social and political issues in the region from the early 20th century to the present, focusing primarily on issues of contemporary relevance.

title: Middle Eastern Field Studies
description: Topics include the history, archeology, religion, society, and politics of the region. Visit key sites described in both the Old and New Testaments, monuments of the Hebrew and Roman worlds, as well as sites of historical and contemporary social and political relevance. Assess the rich historical and spiritual legacy of biblical Israel, patterns of political and social development in the 20th century, including the founding of the state of Israel. Examine the history of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, contemporary domestic social and political issues in Israel and Palestine, attempts at conflict resolution, and opportunities for future political development.

title: Middle English
description: Detailed study of the principal dialects of Middle English, as illustrated in the literature of the period.

title: Military Ministry
description: Preparation of new military chaplains; learning the historical foundation of the U.S. Armed Forces Chaplaincy, emphasizing a practical ministry within a theological and spiritual context.

title: Mil Ministry 2: Homiletics
description: Preparation of new military chaplains; leading worship, preaching, and guiding the teaching ministry within a chapel and operational environment, emphasizing a practical ministry within a theological and spiritual context.

title: Miller New Venture Leadership
description: Working as a team with faculty and management in strategic consulting projects for local, national, and international business.

title: Mind/Body Health
description: Theories and research on the effect of emotions and attitudes on health: how negative emotions increase disease susceptibility and positive emotions encourage immune strength, health, and healing.  Behavioral medicine and complementary and alternative health practices also presented.

title: Mindfulness & Psychotherapy
description: Fundamentals of mindfulness practices; mindfulness-based interventions in psychotherapy. The course has three primary objectives: 1) help students develop competencies in core mindfulness practices; 2) enhance student mindfulness-related "microskills" in therapy, 3) provide students with a deeper exposure to the various interventions with strong mindfulness components.

title: Mineralogy
description: Principles of crystallography and crystal chemistry. Physical, chemical, and crystallographic properties of minerals.

title: Minicourse in Hispanic Ling
description: One-week evening mini-course on a specialized topic taught by invited faculty. Counts toward mini-course requirement for department M.A. programs.

title: Minicourse in Hispanic Lit
description: One-week evening mini-course on a specialized topic taught by invited faculty. Counts toward mini-course requirement for department M.A. programs.

title: Minicourse in Luso-Braz Lit
description: One-week evening mini-course on a specialized topic taught by invited faculty. Counts toward mini-course requirement for department M.A. programs.

title: Minicourse in Portuguese Ling
description: One-week evening mini-course on a specialized topic taught by invited faculty. Counts toward mini-course requirement for department M.A. programs.

title: Minicourse in Port Pedagogy
description: One-week evening mini-course on a specialized topic taught by invited faculty. Counts toward mini-course requirement for department M.A. programs.

title: Minicourse in Span Pedagogy
description: One-week evening mini-course on a specialized topic taught by invited faculty. Counts toward mini-course requirement for department M.A. programs.

title: Mining Law
description: Study of mineral interests, land status determinations, acquisition of mineral rights, mining entry and location of claims, mineral leasing, and mining agreements.

title: MISM Capstone Introduction
description: Presentations by faculty and professionals to make students aware of the latest developments in the field.  Prepare a capstone project proposal.

title: MISM Capstone Project
description: Development and completion of capstone project integrating information systems knowledge previously gained in the MISM program

title: Missionary Preparation
description: Focuses upon the purpose, skills, and doctrines of missionary work and prepares prospective missionaries for a more meaningful MTC and mission experience.

title: Mixed Model Methods
description: Fixed effects, random effects, repeated measures, nonindependent data, general covariance structures, estimation methods.

title: Genomics
description: Current analysis of genes and genomes; computational approaches for interpreting genomic data, including genome sequencing and annotation, gene expression and the transcriptome, functional genomics, metagenomics, and genetic variation and SNPs.

title: Mobile and Ubiquitous HCI
description: Iterative user experience design for mobile and ubiquitous computing with an emphasis on conceptualization and prototyping in specific contexts. Complete an open-ended project from initial design through functional prototype, with design and critique sessions.

title: Mobile Platform Development
description: Principles of mobile platforms. Application development for mobile platforms such as smart phones and tablets. Emphasizing best practices in user experience and programming.

title: Model Arab Lg Prep
description: Understanding Middle Eastern governments and foreign policies. Preparation and attendance at the Model Arab League Conference.

title: M U N Preparation
description: Preparation for participating in MUN projects, on campus, in public schools, and at the United Nations in New York.

title: Modeling and Analysis of PDEs
description: Methods for modeling and analyzing partial differential equations.

title: Modeling Composites MFG
description: Applications of spreadsheets, computer programming, mathematics, mechanics, heat transfer, fluid dynamics, and reaction kinetics to the description and prediction of various elements of manufacturing processes for polymer-based composite materials.

title: Model Dynamics & Control 1
description: Theory and applicatiions of dynamic systems and partial differential equations.  Topics include dynamic systems; bifurcation theory; control theory; hyperbolic, parabolic, and elliptic partial differential equations; commonly-used algorithms.

title: Model Dynamics & Control 1 Lab
description: Using and developing software to implement the content of Math 436.  Developing models and applying results of computations to several application domains.  Introduction to parallel computation.

title: Model Dynamics & Control 2
description: Introduction to integral equations, calculus of variations, stochastic differential equatons, optimal stochastic control; common algorithms used for these systems.

title: Model Dynamics & Control 2 Lab
description: Using and developing software for problems in the calculus of variations, stochastic differential equations, and stochastic optimal control.  Developing models and applying the results of computations to several application domains.

title: Model Uncertainty & Data 1
description: Theory of probability and stochastic processes, emphasizing topics used in applications.  Random spaces and variables, probability distributions, limit theorems, martingales, diffusion, Markov, Poisson and queuing processes, renewal theory, and information theory.

title: Model Uncertainty & Data 1 Lab
description: Using and developing algorithms for the content of Math 402; developing I/O wrappers for numerical libraries.  Applications presented.  Developing models and applying results of computations.

title: Model Uncertainty & Data 2
description: First course in mathematical statistics, focusing on mathematical aspects.  Topics include estimation, inference, analysis of variance, regression, multivariate statistics, Bayesian statistics, state estimation, Kalman filtering, time series, GARCH models.

title: Model Uncertainty & Data 2 Lab
description: Using and developing software to implement the content of Math 404 and handle large data sets.  Applications presented.  Designing and executing statistical tests and applying computations to application domains.

title: Modern Africa
description: Survey of the history of the African continent from circa 1800, focusing on experiences and perspectives of Africans.  Topics may include culture and identity, colonialism, independence movements, religion, gender relations, the environment, and economic development.

title: Modern Amer Political Thought
description: Core principles and seminal texts of American politics from Reconstruction to the present.

title: Modern American Usage
description: Current conventions and effective use of American English.

title: Mod. American Warfare Studies
description: Explores the science, art, and theory of warfare from the early periods of history to the present. Investigates the nuances of military leadership, the evolution of strategic/operational/tactical principles and the influence of technological, economic, moral, psychological, political, and social factors on the conduct of warfare.\n

title: Modern Arabic Literature
description: Readings in modern Arabic literature.

title: Modern Architectur
description: Critical review of roots and evolution of modern architecture.

title: Modern Art
description: Modern European art and theory, 1900--1945.

title: Modern Britain
description: Political, economic, social, and religious developments in England, Scotland, and Wales during the modern era, focusing on Atlantic connections and British imperialism

title: Modern Chinese Literature
description: Authors, themes, and writing styles of the period 1915--1949.  Texts in Chinese.

title: Mod European Women Writers
description: Readings in European literature by women after 1700.

title: Modern Germany
description: Political, military, societal and cultural development of Germany from the late eighteenth century until the present.

title: Modern Japan
description: Main themes in Japanese history from the early 19th century to the present.

title: Modern Korea
description: Political, economic, and social history of Korea from 1850 to the present.

title: Modern Korean Lit in Trans
description: Reading and discussing selected topics in Korean literature (narrative, poetry, drama) from the 1900 (late Choson period) to the present.

title: Modern Latin Amer
description: National period (1810 to present):  independence, institutional development, culture, and inter-American relations.

title: Modern Manufacturing
description: Methods and characteristics of successful manufacturing engineers and managers. Introduction to engineering and technology, design, and project management. Lab.

title: Modern Physics
description: Quantum physics, atoms, molecules, condensed matter, nuclei, elementary particles, and selected topics in contemporary physics.

title: Modern Political Philosophy
description: Examine selected topics, periods, and figures in social and political philosophy with an aim to understand and apply theories to particular problems and questions.

title: Modern Southeast Asia
description: Complex history of the varied nations of this vast area:  religion, colonialism, nationalism, independence.

title: Modern Theory of Solids
description: Quantum theory of solids, emphasizing the unifying principles of symmetry, energy-band theory, dynamics of electrons and of periodic lattices, and cooperative phenomena.

title: Modern Theory of Solids
description: Quantum theory of solids, emphasizing the unifying principles of symmetry, energy-band theory, dynamics of electrons and of periodic lattices, and cooperative phenomena.

title: Modernism
description: Problems of literary periodization in Modernism.

title: Modular Forms
description: An introduction to modular forms including Fourier expansions, dimension formulas, Hecke operators, generalizations, and applications.

title: Molecular & Cellular Bio Lab
description: Molecular and cellular biology techniques laboratory.

title: Molecular Biology
