description: Fundamentals of protein and nucleic acid structure and their function in the context of the classical experiments that have informed our current models of biology at the molecular level.

title: Molecular Biology Seminar
description: Critical examination of current literature and research in molecular biology.

title: Molecular Diagnostics
description: Molecular techniques in medical laboratory sciences.

title: Molecular Genetics in Practice
description: Fundamental concepts in molecular genetics and protein biochemistry with the following emphases:  experimental approaches, model organisms, quantitative reasoning, and statistical analysis.

title: Molecular Genetics Laboratory
description: Mentored, systematic instruction in basic biotechnology techniques and their application in addressing molecular genetic research questions.

title: Molecular Modeling
description: Fundamentals of quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics, and molecular-level modeling. Basics of computational chemistry and simulations using deterministic and stochastic methods (molecular dynamics and Monte Carlo) to calculate thermodynamic and transport properties of fluids and fluid mixtures.

title: Molecular Plant Breeding
description: Molecular genetics methods applied to improvement of economically important plants. Theory and methods of plant transformations.

title: Molecular Virology
description: Molecular mechanisms of virus architecture, attachment and entry pathways, replication strategies, oncogenesis, evolution, and mechanisms of pathogenesis.

title: Monetary Theory & Policy
description: Macroeconomic aspects of money demand, money supply, the monetary transmission mechanism, central bank policy, and other current issues.

title: Money, Banking, & Business
description: Economic analysis of effects of money, banking, and financial institutions on business decisions and aggregate economic activity.

title: Money, Fin Markets & Forecast
description: Applying macroeconomics and statistics to understand key institutions, anticipate business conditions, predict interest rates, and forecast market indicators.

title: Money & Economics
description: Applications of industry analysis and microeconomic principles in the macroeconomic environment that influences individuals and financial intermediaries that transact in money and credit markets.

title: Moral & Ritual Institutions
description: Anthropological approaches to religion; its content and relation to other social institutions in societies ranging from gatherers to industrialists.

title: Moral Development
description: Theories and applications of moral development, including moral reasoning, moral emotions, contextual factors, and socialization influences that influence moral decisions and moral behavior.

title: Mormonism Am Exper
description: Social, economic, political, intellectual, and religious environment in which Mormonism flourished; contributions of Mormon men and women to American culture and history.

title: Mormonism Amg Chrstn Theol
description: Comparison of the historical development and varying constructions of key aspects of Mormon and other Christian thought.

title: Morphology
description: Theory and analysis of word structure in human language.

title: Motion Analysis Techniques
description: Analysis of human movement using 2D and 3D kinematic and kinetic descriptions and models of motion based on 3D video and force plate techniques.

title: Motion Concepts
description: Studio course instructing students in the art of design and communication with motion and sound. Design principles, editing, and narrative concepts are employed to create short motion design projects.

title: Motion Design
description: Studio course instructing students in the art of design and communication with motion and sound. Design principles, editing, and narrative concepts are employed to create short motion design projects.

title: Motivational Interviewing
description: Motivational interviewing (MI) is a collaborative and goal-oriented counseling style designed to increase motivation and commitment in clients. MI is well suited for clients who are ambivalent about making personal or lifestyle changes because the counselor helps the client make their own argument for change. This course is intended to provide students with a thorough and practical introduction to this counseling approach.

title: Motivational Psychology
description: Theoretical, historical, and empirical overview; recent trends and issues; role of animal studies; methodological issues.

title: Motor Control
description: This upper level exercise sciences course will synthesize neuromuscular and biomechanical principles from other courses in the department (i.e., EXSC 362, 440 and 463) and introduce new physiological principles that direct healthy, purposeful control of voluntary movement. Course concepts will include (1) neuromuscular anatomy and physiology, (2) biomechanics of single- and multi-joint systems, (3) current questions and pressing problems related to healthy and pathological control of voluntary movement, (4) current approaches to improving athletic performance, and (5) overcoming orthopedic and neuromuscular impairments.

title: Motor Speech Disorders
description: Neuropathology, symptomology, clinical assessment, and treatment of adult motor speech disorders.

title: MPH Seminar
description: This seminar helps students develop skills and knowledge relating to public health research and leadership. Throughout the semester, students will read research papers written by public health faculty and will read a book on leadership; students meet weekly in a seminar format to discuss the readings and their application to public health.

title: Business Career Essentials
description: (Math-Chem-C S-Geol-MthEd-Phscs-Stat) Introduction for science, math, and statistics majors to careers in industry. Project planning, oral and written business presentations, business accounting, and technology readiness.

title: History & Philosophy of Math
description: Historical development of important mathematical ideas and philosophies; implications for the mathematical curriculum.

title: Survey of Geometry
description: Logical and historical development of Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometry, transformations and symmetry; relationships among axiomatic systems; use of software and other geometric models; proofs and Van Hiele levels.

title: Multi-Agent Systems
description: Introduction to fundamental concepts emphasizing current literature. Topics include game theory, repeated play games, Arrow's impossibility theorem, negotiation, search, and learning.

title: Multicultural America
description: Diverse cultural heritages in the United States. Cultures studied scientifically will include African American, Hispanic, Asian American, and Native American.

title: Multicultural Education
description: Multicultural issues in educational theory and practice, with special reference to race, ethnicity, gender, socioeconomic status, and various types of exceptionality.

title: Multicultural Issues in SLP
description: Speech and language assessment and intervention with persons from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds. Specific topics include cultural diversity, bilingualism, and use of interpreters/translators.

title: Multicultural Italy
description: Examination of the seismic cultural changes occurring in contemporary Italy through the literature that has been produced by and about migrants entering Europe since the 1990s. How this growing field of literature both charts and contributes to the re-definition of the nation occurring in Italy.  Students will analyze literature by migrant authors in several genres - autobiography, short story, poetry, theater, and novels (including a comic murder mystery) - through the theoretical lenses of post-colonialism and feminism in order to confront the issues of racism, national and individual identity construction, and the concept of "otherness."

title: Multicultural Psychology
description: Examination of multiculturalism from a psychological perspective, with a focus on the impact of culture on psychological theory, research, and practice. Particular attention will be given to the sociocultural and psychological analyses of four ethnic minority groups in the United States: American Indians, Asian Americans, African Americans and Hispanics/Latina/os.

title: Mltimedia Authoring & Publish
description: Developing advanced media authoring skills for teaching interactive design.  Solving real-world interactive design problems for the World Wide Web, CD-ROM, and DVD-ROM in an entrepreneurial environment.

title: Multimedia Reporting
description: Research and reporting skills. Database retrieval, interviewing, and creation of audio, video, and still images. Beat reporting for online media. Lab required.

title: Multiple Regression Analysis
description: Ordinary least squares and logistic regression techniques. Data acquisition, management, analysis, and report writing.

title: Multiple Regression Analysis
description: Techniques and assumptions of regression models, data management, and analysis. Topics include ordinary least squares, binary, ordinal, and multiple logistic regression, and models for count variables.

title: Regression Analysis
description: Data analysis and computer use in sociology; least squares and logistic regression techniques; SPSS and its use in conducting data analysis. Research report required.

title: Multispecies Sociality
description: This course brings anthropological perspectives to human-nonhuman sociality and considers how language and communicative ideologies mediate plants-primates-people-animal-fungi-bacteria relations.

title: Multivariate Statistcl Methods
description: Inference about mean vectors and covariance matrices; multivariate analysis of variance and regression; canonical correlation; discriminant, cluster, principal component, and factor analysis.

title: Musculoskel & Vascular Imaging
description: Students will gain an understanding of the use and purpose of ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging for research in Exercise Sciences and clinical practice settings (i.e., athletic training, sports medicine, rehabilitation).

title: Museology: Curation & Wrtng
description: Professional practices supporting the educational, research, and reporting functions of museums, emphasizing museum writing leading to publication, cataloguing, policy writing, exhibition conceptualization, etc.

title: Museum Art Education
description: The museum as a learning environment; current exhibitions; learning and teaching strategies for collaboration with museum and classroom educator.

title: Museum Collections Management
description: Instruction and practice in aspects of managing museum collections: writing catalogs, processing donations, preserving objects.

title: Museum Exhibitns & Progrmmng
description: Instruction and practica in all aspects of exhibition development.   Current thought and literature in museum education with practica for application.

title: Museum Internship - Classics
description: Combined study-work experience related to classical studies majors.

title: Museum Practices & Technlgs
description: Core museum disciplines: collections management, curation, education, exhibition, and conservation. Supporting technologies: database, digital photography, Web design, etc. Career paths.

title: Museum Projects
description: Supervised experience in a museum working with exhibitions, public programs, or research.

title: Museum Projects
description: One or more supervised museum projects, such as producing an exhibition, developing educational materials, conducting inventory, or accessioning collections.

title: Museum Reg & Collectns Mgt
description: Managing anthropological collections: object-handling, object-tracking, accessioning, deaccessioning, collections databases, loans, valuating collections, conservation environments, ethics, and NAGPRA and other laws relating to museums.

title: Museum Registration & Ethics
description: Managing museum collections: cataloging, loans, ethics, legal issues, object handling, basic object conservation. Practical experience working with museum objects and specific museum challenges.

title: Museums & Cultures
description: Role of museums in society. Analyzing museum content, use, and sociology. Visits to and critiques of area museums. Final projects with real museums in the region.

title: Museums & Cultures
description: Museums in society. Cultural foundations of museum content and sociology of museum use. Analyzing museum studies literature. Visits to and critiques of area museums. Final projects in real museums in the region.

title: MDT Sr Performance Project
description: Participation in an MDT performance group culminating in a showcase for agents and directors in New York City during April.

title: MDT:  Sr Performance Project
description: Participation in an MDT performance group culminating in a showcase for agents and directors in New York City during April.

title: Music for Dancers
description: Practical application of musical theory related to dance performance, pedagogy, and choreography.

title: Music for Elem Schl Tchrs
description: Experiences in teaching various music activities in the elementary school.

title: Music for Movement
description: Theory and technique to increase knowledge and skills in accompanying dance; including understanding of musicality through movement and how music supports movement experiences.

title: Mu Elem Clsrm Tchr
description: Establishing a classroom environment for musical development; emphasis on appropriate songs, activities, resources, and teaching strategies.

title: Music Fundamentals
description: Organizational systems of music, their notation and aural patterns.

title: Music Production Seminar
description: Principles and techniques in music production taught by commercial music faculty in a private one to one lesson fashion and then meeting as a group (master class setting) to showcase, discuss, and critique student works.

title: Music Technology 1
description: Music technology concepts, principles, and applications. Foundation course in Commercial Music core.

title: Music Technology 2
description: Continuation of Music 251. Music technology concept, principles, and applications.

title: Music Theatre Ensemble
description: Auditioned chorus or orchestra for opera or music dance theatre productions.

title: MT in Contemporary Culture
description: Analysis of the form, evolution, and influence of music dance theatre in Western culture.

title: MT in Contemporary Culture
description: Analysis of the form, evolution and influence of music dance theatre in Western culture.

title: Music Theory 1
description: Writing and analysis in diatonic harmony.

title: Music Theory 2
description: Writing and analysis in diatonic and chromatic harmony.

title: Music Theory 3
description: Extended chromatic techniques and introduction to twentieth-century concepts.

title: Music Theory 4
description: Set theory, serialism, and other 20th- and 21st-Century concepts.

title: Music Theory for MDT
description: Music theory, sight singing, aural dictation, and keyboard harmony.

title: Musical Scene Study
description: In-depth study of different genres of musical theatre; text analysis, research, written assignments and performance.

title: Musical Theater Accomp
description: Accompanying in the style of Musical Theater

title: Musical Theater Pedagogy
description: Introductory course preparing students to teach musical theater skills and techniques in a public school setting.

title: MT in Contemporary Culture
description: Analysis of the form, evolution, and influence of music dance theatre in Western culture.

title: Musical Theatre Performance
description: Performance in a BYU Theatre musical.

title: Musicality in the Elem School
description: Survey of authentic folk song and art music tonal systems and structures; their use in developing musical intuition through singing, movement, listening, and playing instruments.

title: Myth, Legend, & Folktale
description: Major mythic and legendary works that provide background for the literary tradition.

title: NAHB Competition
description: A culminating experience, emphasizing the application of knowledge and skills gained through students' undergraduate careers. Students participate in an industry-sponsored competition organized by the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB).  Preparation for, and participation in the competition deepens an understanding of real-world challenges toward solution-finding in the built environment.

title: Narrative Illustration
description: Narrative problem solving through the use of character, mood, and environment to tell a story or develop a conceptual idea. Study of media, aesthetic principles, and classic story models.

title: National Security Affairs
description: American national security affairs, including American grand strategy and topics such as nuclear weapons and cybersecurity.

title: Natnl Sec Affairs
description: Africa, Middle East, and Latin American regional studies; military operation other than war; military justice system; officer professional development.

title: Natnl Sec Affairs
description: Civilian control of military, civil-military interaction, the forming of defense strategy. Military profession; Russia, Europe, and East Asia regional studies.

title: National Security Law
description: This course surveys the framework of domestic and international laws that variously authorize and restrain the pursuit of the U.S. government's national security policies. "National security" can mean a great many things, of course, but for purposes of this course we will be concerned primarily with the interactions of the government and the allocation of power between the branches of the government in relation to (i) the use of military force, (ii) the activities of the intelligence community, and (iii) counter terrorism-related activities (including the interrogation, detention, and trial of captured persons).

title: Natural History of Wildlife
description: Wildlife species and their habitats, including ecology, life histories, adaptations, behavior, genetics and population viability variables, and the ethics of global stewardship.  Field trips required.

title: Natural Lang Processing
description: Intensive overview of natural language processing, including computational techniques, hands-on experience with linguistic technologies and corpora, language modeling approaches, and readings from current research.

title: Natrl Resources & Envir Econ
description: Economic theory applied to allocation of natural resources and environmental amenities. Issues relating to externalities, common property resources, public goods, allocation of depletable natural resources over time, economic factors of environmental polarization, and others.

title: Natural Resources Law
description: Introduction to legal rules and processes that govern the human use, management, and protection of nature, with a focus of resources other than those found on public land. The course introduces the legal, historical, political, and intellectual influences that shape natural resources development and conservation in a range of resources including timber, wildlife, fisheries, oil and gas, mineral resources, and water.

title: Natural Science
description: Not a valid course. Only to be used to apply credits to General Education requirements.

title: Natural Science
description: Not a valid course. Only to be used to apply credits to General Education requirements.

title: Nature & History
description: Human historical interactions with animals, plants, and landscapes. Global histories of climate, population, whaling, fossil fuels, the car, animal rights, suburban sprawl, eco-theology, environmentalism, ecotourism, etc.

title: Nature Photography
description: Techniques of professional nature and landscape photography.

title: Near East Seminar
description: Current issues in Near Eastern archaeological research.

title: Near Eastern Archaeology
description: Peoples and culture history in Mesopotamia, Syria, Palestine, Egypt, 3500--500 B.C. Substantial reading, writing, discussion.

title: Negotiation
description: Negotiation is essential for all lawyers. This course helps students understand negotiation strategies and ethics, improves communication skills, and provides practice for effective implementation of negotiation techniques. Will benefit students interested in any practice area.

title: Negotiations
description: This course covers basic negotiation skills and principles for public administrators. Students apply their learning through practice and self-reflection.

title: Neoclassicism
description: Problems of literary periodization in Neoclassicism.

title: Arab & Islamic Civilization
description: Social science/humanities core course covering Arab and Islamic civilization; historical evolution of Middle East to present. Overview of modern Palestinian society.

title: Jewish Civilization
description: Social science/humanities core course; broad introduction to Jewish self-understanding and history, focusing on relationships among people, faith, and land.

title: Network Theory
description: Representing networks mathematically. Measures and metrics, computer algorithms, random graphs, and large-scale structures. Percolation and network resilience. Dynamical systems on networks.

title: Networking-Career Advancement
description: Examination of the job seeking process, with a focus on the most time-effective approaches to launching a career.  Prioritizing time, setting goals, and effectively creating a strategic network within the desired career field. Tailored for those seeking a job directly after graduation.

title: Networks & Security
description: Conceptual and practical computer networks. Internet, local and wide area networks. Switches and routers. Network security.

title: Neural Basis of Rehab
description: Facilitating the discussion and knowledge of neuromechanics associated with orthopedic injury and rehabilitation. Becoming familiar with research in the area of neuromechanics; critical evaluation of such.

title: Neuro Case Conference
description: Neuropsychological emphasis of case presentations; professional, ethical, and research issues pertinent to assessment and intervention.

title: Neuroanatomy
description: Functonal anatomy of the human brain and spinal cord, including surface and cross-sectional gross anatomy, microscopic anatomy, and sensory, motor, and integrative systems' circuitry.

title: Neuroanatomy
description: Develop mastery of gross brain anatomy, especially those regions most relevant to the field of clinical neuropsychology. Understanding normal brain anatomy will be used to form the basis for understanding neuropathological conditions and their implications for neuropsychiatric disorders

title: Neurobiology
description: Structure and function of the nervous system: cellular communication; sensory, motor, and autonomic systems.

title: Neurofndtns Lang,Spch,Hearing
description: Neuroanatomy and neurophysiology underlying normal and impaired language, speech, and hearing processes.

title: Neuroimaging Analysis 1
description: Exposure to the physical and biological bases of image acquisition, the technologies of in vivo neuroimaging, the application of these technologies to understanding questions in neuroscience, and an introduction to the design and analysis of structural neuroimaging experiments.

title: Neuroimaging Analysis 2
description: The principles of diffusion weighted image acquisition and how to design, analyze, and interpret diffusion tensor imaging experiments.

title: Neuroimaging Analysis 3: fMRI
description: Functional MRI experimental design and data analysis methods.

title: Neurolinguistics
description: Overview of topics in neurolinguistics, such as what areas of the brain are involved in language acquisition and processing, how we store and access words, how we build sentences and form dependencies, how we process discourse, how emotion is involved in language, how we learn and process a second language, neural mechanisms involved in social interaction and language use, and methods used in neurolinguistic research.

title: Neuromech Signal Processing
description: Focus will be given to processing and interpretation of neuromechanical data, with an emphasis on electromyography and ground reaction force data.

title: Neuromechanics of Movement
description: Biomechanics and neural control of human movement.  Principles of mechanical engineering (system dynamics, control) and physiology (motor neuroscience, musculoskeletal biomechanics) are combined to model and simulate how humans plan, control, learn, and adapt their movements.

title: Neuropathology
description: This course will focus on the clinical features, neuroimaging findings and the defining pathology of diseases that affect the central and peripheral nervous system.

title: Academic Internship
description: Off-campus internship experience in neuroscience.

title: Neuroscience Advanced Writing
description: Processes of research writing and oral presentation for neuroscience students.

title: Neuroscience Grad Seminar
description: Seminar series organized by the Neuroscience Center. Speakers are enlisted from both inside and outside the university.

title: Neuroscience Laboratory
description: Exposure to classical/modern experiments in neuroscience.

title: Neuro Seminar
description: Seminar (research) presentations for undergraduates in Neuroscience.

title: Teaching Experience
description: Undergraduate student lecture or laboratory teaching assistantship, or other activities that provide students hands-on curriculum design, teaching, and mentoring experiences.

title: Neutral Mask
description: Use of masks in teaching specificity of movement, communication, and emotion.

title: New Genre Interdisciplinary
description: Developing an artistic voice while exploring new genres of art making including installation, digital, time-based, performance, sound, and technology-based work. Includes an introduction to hybridized, collaborative, and cross-disciplinary art projects.

title: New Media Conceptualization
description: Concepts and techniques for creating new media production.

title: New Media Produce & Direct
description: Pre-production and production of short projects. Discussion and individual/group experiences and critiques.

title: New Media Tools
description: Introductory course to familiarize students with using new media tools.

title: New Play Dramaturgy
description: Develop further research and hands-on theatrical skills in four critical studies areas: literary management, production dramaturgy, new play development, educational outreach.

title: New Student Seminar
description: Overview of electrical and computer engineering with group and individual design projects.

title: New Student Seminar
description: Topics of special interest to new mechanical engineering majors.

title: New Testament in Greek:Gospels
description: Introduction to the study of the canonical gospels in Koine Greek.

title: New Testament Jerusalem Center
description: Study of the New Testament Gospels integrated with geography, history, and culture of the Holy Land at the time of Jesus Christ, leading to an understanding, appreciation, and application of scriptural teachings today.

title: New Testament Studies
description: Study of the New Testament Gospels integrated with extensive field experiences in the biblical world; leads to an understanding, appreciation, and application of scriptural teachings today.

title: New Venture Launchpad
description: Mentored support and coaching of launch of an actual venture. Guidance on solution validation, prototype development and testing, product/service launch, and business fundamentals (marketing, finance, operations, systems, etc.). At a minimum, students must be committed to launching a specific idea. Businesses already operating and generating revenue also welcome.

title: New Venture LaunchPad
description: Student entrepreneurs currently building a business will learn business best practices through mentored learning with a proven entrepreneur. Topics covered include product-market fit, sales systems, pitches, boards, employees, compensation, leadership, ethics, and fundraising.

title: Newspaper Arabic
description: Extensive reading of Arabic newspapers and magazines, with appropriate vocabulary building.

title: Newsroom Leadership
description: Advanced concepts in newsroom management, ranging from editorial conceptualization and news judgment to copy editing, headline writing, and page design. Lab includes fulfilling senior editing positions.

title: 19th Cent Europe
description: Political, economic, social, and intellectual history of Europe from 1815 to 1914.

title: 19th C Europe Art
description: Nineteenth-century art in Europe.

title: 19th Century Lit
description: Romanticism (1770s through 1870s) and/or the novels of Benito Perez Galdos and his contemporaries.

title: 19th Century Literature
description: Romanticism (1770s through 1870s) and/or the novels of Benito Perez Galdos and his contemporaries.

title: Non-Western Philosophy
description: Study selected figures, texts, and problems in the history of non-Western philosophy.

title: Chinese Philosophy
description: Study selected figures, texts, and problems in the history of non-Western philosophy.

title: Nonlinear Analysis
description: Differential calculus in normed spaces, fixed point theory, and abstract critical point theory.

title: Nonparametric Stat Methods
description: Permutation tests, rank-based methods, analysis of contingency tables, bootstrap methods, curve fitting.

title: Nonprofit Board Practicum
description: Students serve on the Board of Directors for a local nonprofit.

title: Nonprofit Finance
description: Study financial structure and income sources for nonprofit organizations, and applicable laws regulating nonprofit finance.

title: Nonprofit Organization Mgt
description: Orient students to principles of best practice in the management of nonprofit organizations. Build foundational knowledge in the role, function, and diversity of nonprofit organizations generally, and examine the strategic management techniques most likely to help nonprofit organizations thrive.

title: Nonprofit Structure & Tax
description: Introduction to the study of nonprofit organizations, including history, philosophy, organizational structure, government relations, tax rules, and applicable laws.

title: Nonresearch Academic Internshp
description: Academic internship for work experience or job shadowing.  Does NOT involve mentored research.

title: Norm Thr Pol Analy
description: Alternative norms and values used in making policy choices.

title: Northern Baroque Art
description: This course examines Northern European Art from 1600 to 1700.

title: Northern Mesoamerican Art
description: Survey of art and architecture of Mexico from antiquity to present.

title: Northern Renaissance
description: Fifteenth- and sixteenth-century art in northern Europe.

title: N US Family History Research
description: Records, geographical-historical background, paleography, and methodologies for reconstruction of invididual families and development of family history studies in the northern states, including New England, the Midwest, and some Mid-Atlantic states in the 19th and 20th centuries.

title: Norwegian Literature
description: Readings in Norwegian literature; introduction to basic literary concepts.  Includes International Cinema.

title: Novel
description: History and theory of long prose narrative.

title: Nuclear Reactor Design & Anal.
description: This course teaches the basic principles of nuclear reactor design including core design, nuclear system design, structural design, safety analyses, and nuclear licensing.  Integration of nuclear reactor systems, structures, and components is also a strong focus of this course.  Finally, lectures will include the integration of these highly technical design topics with Nuclear Regulatory Commission licensing requirements and processes.

title: Nuclear Reactor Transient Mod.
description: This course focuses on the thermal-hydraulic assessment of nuclear reactor design basis and beyond design basis transients using state-of-the-art computer code.  Instruction will focus on both instruction in using this code and study of design basis accidents for both standard and advanced reactor concepts.

title: Lang Skills Dev: Rarotongan
description: Increasing proficiency in one or more of the following Rarotongan language and culture skills: speaking, listening, reading, writing, cultural awareness.

title: Research in Open Education
description: Students will engage in an in-depth literature review and research project related to issues in open education including the use of open educational resources.

title: Leadership Projects
description: This course analyzes the most effective means for being a change agent in the community. The course also teaches students critical skills of analysis, evaluation, leadership, innovation, and teamwork by requiring the design and completion of a group project involving some form of civic improvement and incorporating interaction with an external community partner.

title: Ad Issues and Strategy
description: Advertising theory, research, target market analysis, campaign strategy, creative and media strategies, advertising promotions, and ethical issues facing the advertising industry.

title: Number & Number Sense
description: Research on children's understanding of early numbers, number operations, number sense, multidigit arithmetic, fractions, decimals, and proportions.

title: Number Theory
description: Foundations; congruences; quadratic reciprocity; unique factorization, prime distribution or Diophantine equations.

title: Numerical Methods
description: Iterative solvers for linear systems, eigenvalue, eigenvector approximations, numerical solutions to nonlinear systems, numerical techniques for initial and boundary value problems, elementary solvers for PDEs.

title: Numerical Methods
description: Introduction to numerical methods for engineering. Algorithms for numerical integration, large linear system solutions, finite difference methods, method of moments, and the finite element method, with examples from wave propagation and electromagnetic field theory.

title: Numerical Methods for Eng.
description: Computer-aided design and numerical methods of chemical engineering processes.

title: Num Methods for Linear Algebra
description: Numerical matrix algebra, orthogonalization and least squares methods, unsymmetric and symmetric eigenvalue problems, iterative methods, advanced solvers for partial differential equations.

title: Num Methods for Partial Diff
description: Finite difference and finite volume methods for partial differential equations. Stability, consistency, and convergence theory.

title: Nurs-Med Term
description: Nursing and medical terminology for prenursing and beginning nursing students or those interested in health occupations.

title: Nursing Capstone
description: Advanced theory and synthesis of concepts for the nursing profession focusing on planning, delivering, and managing patient care in complex environments including leadership in the health care environment.

title: Nurs Care of Adults in Crisis
description: Theory and content in the nursing interventions and care for individuals and families in crisis.

title: Acute & Chronic Illness
description: Theory and content in the nursing care of acutely and chronically ill adults; professional behavior; illness implications for patients and families.

title: Nurs Care of Children
description: 2-credit, in-person didactic course provides students with theory and content in the nursing care of children and their families from diverse backgrounds including health promotion, growth development, disease prevention, and care of acute and chronic illness.

title: Nurs Care of the Older Adult
description: Theory and content in the nursing care optimizing the functional status of older adults through health promotion, risk reduction, and disease prevention strategies.

title: Nurs Care of Women & Newborns
description: Theory and content in the nursing care of childbearing families from diverse backgrounds.  Health promotion, assessment, and interventions relating to complicated and uncomplicated pregnancy and birth.

title: Nursing Science 1: EBP
description: Developing skills and knowledge in selecting and synthesizing the best research evidence to provide quality health care.

title: Translating Evidence to Pract
description: Developing skills and knowledge in systematically appraising and translating the best research and evidence to provide quality health care.

title: Nursing Skills I
description: 1-credit lab course focuses on cognitive and psychomotor introductory nursing skills development and application with hands-on, interactive learning activities in the Nursing Learning Center.

title: Nursing Skills II
description: 1-credit lab course focuses on cognitive and psychomotor introductory to intermediate nursing skills development and application with hands-on, interactive learning activities in the Nursing Learning Center.

title: Nursing Skills III
description: 1-credit lab course focuses on cognitive and psychomotor intermediate nursing skills development and application with hands-on, interactive learning activities in the Nursing Learning Center.

title: Nursing Skills IV
description: 1-credit, lab course focuses on cognitive and psychomotor intermediate to advanced student nursing skills development and application with hands-on, interactive learning activities in the Nursing Learning Center.

title: Nursing Skills V
description: 0.5 lab course focuses on cognitive and psychomotor advanced student nursing skills development and application with hands-on, interactive learning activities and pass-offs in the Nursing Learning Center.

title: Nutrient Metabolism
description: Chemical structures of nutrients, their food sources, requirements, digestion, absorption, transport, metabolism, functions, storage and excretion; metabolic consequences of nutrient deficiencies, interactions, imbalances, and toxicities.

title: Nutrition and Genes
description: Use of primary literature to discuss the effect of food on an individual's genome and the effect of genetics on food metabolism and dietary health outcomes.

title: Nutr & Metab Sports Exercise
description: Scientific basis for the role of nutrition in human performance.  Critical evaluation of popular practices; making optimal food choices for physical activity.

title: Nutrition Assessment Lab
description: Developing skill in anthropometric, biochemical, clinical, and dietary parameters of nutritional assessment.

title: Nutrition Education
description: Theories that guide nutrition education; nutrition education programs for various target populations; designing and implementing a nutrition education intervention.

title: Nutrition Educ & Counseling
description: Learning theory; curriculum development and dissemination; nutrition counseling; for dietetics majors.

title: Nutrition Research Fundamentls
description: Design of protocols for and ethics of research with human subjects and animals.  Scientific literature searches and presentations.

title: Nutrition Through Life Cycle
description: Nutritional requirements, diet, and health concerns for pregnancy and lactation; infants; toddlers and preschoolers; school-age children; adolescents; and older adults.

title: Nutritional & Food Toxicology
description: Principles of nutritional and food toxicology with primary emphasis on food toxins will be discussed.  An overview of absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion of foreign materials, allergenic and toxic constituents in plant, animal, marine and fungal origin will be covered.  Priority will be placed on the role food ingredients and nutrients may have in mutagenesis and carcinogenesis, including food processing induced toxins.  Safety assessments of food additives, environmental contaminants, pesticides, antibiotic residues and dietary supplements and the laws and regulations surrounding their uses will be presented.

title: Nutr Bio-organic Chemistry
description: Principles of organic chemistry and biochemistry relating to the function and structure of macronutrients, vitamins, and minerals.

title: Nutr Biochem & Metabolism
description: Biochemical and metabolic processes and interrelationships among nutrients.

title: Nutr Implications of Disease
description: Nutritional assessment and medical nutrition therapy across disease states.

title: Obesity & Weight Management
description: Review of the scientific literature surrounding obesity and weight management, primarily the causes and consequences of this growing epidemic.

title: Obj/Project Assess
description: Objective assessment of personality (including MMPI) as well as projective techniques (including TAT). Pragmatic psychological report writing.

title: Oboe
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice

title: Observational Astronomy
description: Basic techniques of observational astronomy, emphasizing practical experience in optical data acquisition and analysis.

title: Occupational Exposure Lab
description: Theory and application of occupational sampling methods that are used to evaluate chemical, biological, and physical exposures in the workplace. Focus on the quantitative and qualitative methods used to evaluate occupational exposures to suspended particulates, gaseous contaminants, noise and other physical agents, and biological agents; interpretation of sampling results; identification of appropriate control strategies to prevent hazardous exposures; and exposure assessment communication.

title: Occupational Health & Safety
description: In-depth focus on workplace health and safety through a multidisciplinary approach to the anticipation, recognition, evaluation, and prevention and control of workplace-related illnesses and injuries.

title: Off-Campus Internship
description: An art museum or auction house internship at a national or international institution providing training in administrative practice, curatorship, and connoisseurship.  Establishing a network of connections to future employment and professional opportunities.

title: Oil and Gas
description: The nature of interests in oil and gas, the oil and gas lease and associated problems, title and conveyancing problems with respect to transfers of oil and gas interests, and pooling and unitization. In some semesters, this course may be taught exclusively online.

title: Old English 1
description: Old English grammar and vocabulary; traditional syntactical patterns in various types of Old English prose and poetry.

title: Old English 2
description: Additional reading in Old English, emphasizing sound changes, dialects, and textual production.

title: Old Icelandic Lang &Literature
description: Readings and exercises in Old Icelandic; introduction to Old Icelandic literature and its influence on later Icelandic culture.

title: Old Norse
description: Grammar and exercises. Readings in Old Norse literature.

title: Old Testament Studies
description: Study of the Old Testament integrated with extensive field experiences in the biblical world; leads to an understanding, appreciation, and application of scriptural teachings today.

title: Old Testament Jerusalem Center
description: Study of the Old Testament integrated with geography, history, and culture of the biblical world, leading to an understanding, appreciation, and application of scriptural teachings today.

title: On-Campus Experiential Project
description: Direct, practical on-campus (not in the field) professional experience consulting with established and startup companies and organizations.  Students are accepted to work on specific projects based on their skills, interests, and major emphasis.  Students apply to be involved in specific projects.

title: Opera Ensemble
description: Students will prepare for, rehearse, and perform in a theatrical operatic production. They will do so in a variety of styles and languages as a soloist and/or as a member of an opera chorus.

title: Opera Ensemble
description: Students will prepare for, rehearse, and perform in a theatrical operatic production. They will do so in a variety of styles and languages as a soloist and/or as a member of an opera chorus.

title: Opera Workshop
description: In a masterclass/workshop setting, students will learn and practice acting and interpretation skills for musical performances, including opera, concerts, recitals, auditions, and other opportunities. Students will perform both individually and as part of an ensemble.

title: Opera Workshop
description: In a masterclass/workshop setting, students will learn and practice acting and interpretation skills for musical performances, including opera, concerts, recitals, auditions, and other opportunities. Students will perform both individually and as part of an ensemble.

title: Operating Systems
description: Applying and using computer operating systems. Configuration, file systems, security, administration, network interfacing, multitasking, multiuser, device driver installation. Analyzing operating system performance.

title: Operating Systems Design
description: Principles and concepts of operating systems design and the implementation of an operating system.

title: Operations Analytics
description: Methods and tools necessary for analyzing and solving problems associated with global supply chain management.

title: Operations and Maintenance
description: Acquisition, operation, maintenance, and disposal of building systems, structures, permanent interiors, furniture, and equipment; grounds and other exterior elements.

title: Operations Management
description: Examining issues and tools in production and operations management.  Specific tools for forecasting, planning, inventory control, and project management presented and developed.

title: Operations Management
description: Examining issues and tools in production and operations management.  Specific tools for forecasting, planning, inventory control, and project management presented and developed.

title: Operations Management
description: Examining issues and tools in production and operations management. Specific tools for forecasting, planning, inventory control, and project management presented and developed. Process design and improvement in both manufacturing and service organizations.

title: Operations Management
description: Examining issues and tools in service operations, production, and operations management. Presenting and developing specific tools for forecasting, planning, inventory control, and project management.

title: Operations Management
description: Doing work efficiently and well within a company's own operation and in the connected operations of a supply chain. Topics in the course include: strategic sourcing, operations fundamentals (bottlenecks, cycle times, throughput time, work in progress, etc.), operations strategy, cellular processes, product/process fit, continuous improvement/quality/lean, forecasting, supply chain coordination, operations and organizational transformation, and capacity planning.\n\n

title: Opinion Writing
description: Function of editorials, columns, commentaries, and reviews in the mass media.

title: Optimization
description: Applying analytical decision-making tools to management situations, emphasizing spreadsheet decision models that optimize a key variable subject to constraints.

title: Optoelectronic Devices
description: Design, operation, and fabrication of modern optoelectronic devices, including photodiodes, photovoltaics, LEDs, and lasers.

title: Oral Comm for Bus. Leaders
description: Weekly professional seminar on presentation skills, interaction in social settings, and resolving workplace conflict. Highly experiential, skills-based course.

title: Oratorio Lit for Solo Voice
description: History, repertoire, and performance practice of sacred works with a focus on works from the Baroque Era to Contemporary.

title: Orchestra Literature 1
description: Concentrated analytical study and application of orchestral literature of the baroque and classical eras.

title: Orchestra Literature 2
description: Concentrated analytical study and application of orchestral literature of the romantic era and the 20th century.

title: Orchestral Excerpts: Bass
description: Performance instruction in standard orchestral repertoire.

title: Orchestral Excerpts: Brass
description: Performance instruction in standard orchestral repertoire for brass instruments.

title: Orchestral Excerpts: Cello
description: Performance instruction in standard orchestral repertoire.

title: Orchstrl Excerpts: Harp
description: Performance instruction in standard orchestral repertoire.

title: Orchestral Excerpts: Viola
description: Performance instruction in standard orchestral repertoire.

title: Orchestral Excerpts: Violin
description: Performance instruction in standard orchestral repertoire.

title: Orchstrl Excerpts: Woodwinds
description: Performance instruction in standard orchestral repertoire.

title: Orchestration 1
description: An introduction to orchestration, including a study of the characteristics of each instrument and the ability to write for them in combination at a fundamental to intermediate level.

title: Orchestration 2
description: Advanced studies in orchestration. Includes analysis of techniques seen primarily in modern and contemporary scores as well as the development of related orchestrational skills.

title: Ordinary Differential Equation
description: Methods and theory of ordinary differential equations.

title: Organ
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice

title: Organ Literature
description: Survey of literature. Research in area of concentration.

title: Organ Literature
description: Continuation of Music 404A.

title: Organ Pedagogy
description: Preparation for supervised private or group teaching.

title: Organ Practicum
description: Refining the practical skills required of the organist, with emphasis on melody harmonization, choir accompaniment, hymn playing, and improvisation.

title: Organ Practicum
description: Developing the practical skills required of the organist, with emphasis on improvisation, figured bass, melody harmonization, transposition, and open score reading.

title: Organ Practicum
description: Designing and implementing a personal strategy for developing the practical skills required of the organist.

title: Organ Registration
description: Organ stops and their application to various performance styles.

title: Organ Tech & Lit
description: Continuation of Music 115.

title: Organic Chemistry 1
description: Fundamentals of bonding, structure, and reactions of organic compounds, including molecular geometry, polarity, conformation, isomerism, functional groups, stereochemistry, reactions and reaction mechanisms, and spectroscopy.

title: Organic Chemistry 1 - Majors
description: Fundamentals of bonding, structure, and reactions of organic compounds, including molecular geometry, polarity, conformation, isomerism, functional groups, stereochemistry, reactions and reaction mechanisms, and spectroscopy.  Chem 351M provides a more in-depth treatment of the above topics than Chem 351.

title: Organic Chemistry 2
description: Emphasis on organic reactions, reaction mechanisms, synthesis, and spectroscopy building on the foundation of Chem 351, including carbonyl chemistry, and chemistry of aromatic compounds, organic acids and bases, polymers, and biomolecules.

title: Organic Chemistry 2 - Majors
description: Emphasis on organic reactions, reaction mechanisms, synthesis, and spectroscopy building on the foundation of Chem 351M, including carbonyl chemistry, the chemistry of aromatic compounds, organic acids and bases, polymers, and biomolecules.  Chem 352M provides a more in-depth treatment of the above topics than Chem 352.

title: Organic Lab 2 - Nonmajors
description: Physical and chemical properties, isolation, purification, characterization, identification, and syntheses of organic compounds.

title: Organic Chem Lab-Major
description: Physical and chemical properties, manipulative skills, isolation and purification, characterization and identification, syntheses.

title: Organic Chem Lab-Nonmajors
description: Physical and chemical properties, isolation and purification, characterization, syntheses.

title: Organic Spectroscopic Ident
description: Theory and practice of spectrometric methods of identifying organic compounds, including infrared, ultraviolet nuclear magnetic resonance, and mass spectrometries.

title: Admn of Literacy Programs
description: Examining ways to organize and administer school and classroom reading programs. Examining issues relating to program types, reading assessment, grouping, grade level articulation, and supervision.

title: Org & Admin of Reading Prog
description: Topics vary.

title: Org and Systems Leadership
description: Utilize principles of organizational and systems leadership to promote high quality and safe patient care.

title: Organizational Behavior
description: Theories and concepts for creating effective organizations, e.g., individual, group, and organizational processes and human resource functions, including selection, compensation, and performance management.

title: Organizational Behavior
description: Personal effectiveness in organizations; increased awareness of interpersonal strengths and weaknesses.

title: Organiztnl Developmnt & Change
description: Macro topics in organizational behavior, including organizational structure, culture, design, change management, strategic implementation, and HR training and development.

title: Organizational Effectiveness
description: Theories and concepts for creating effective organizations, e.g., individual, group, and organizational processes and human resource functions, including selection, compensation, and performance management.

title: Organizational Effectiveness
description: Analysis of individual, group, and organizational variables that inhibit or facilitate effective organizational functioning. Topics include motivation, rewards, leadership, conflict, decision making, structure, evaluation, and change.

title: Organizational Effectiveness
description: Theories and concepts for creating effective organizations, e.g., individual, group, and organizational processes and human resource functions, including selection, compensation, and performance management.

title: Org Governance/Exec Leadership
description: Key managerial functions of complex organizations and institutions; administrative theory and selected management techniques.

title: Org Psych
description: Personal and interpersonal aspects of organizational life: goal setting, decision making, problem solving, communication, control, leadership, motivation, and change.

title: Organizational Psychology
description: Personal, interactional, and structural aspects of organizations; motivation, decision making, problem-solving communication, leadership, organizational structure, change.

title: Orientation to Psych Major
description: Overview of curriculum and major requirements, faculty research programs and specialties, campus resources, and career possibilities.

title: Origins of Const
description: Examination of intellectual origins of the U.S. Constitution; review of drafting and adoption of Constitution and Bill of Rights. Students read all of Madison's Notes of the Debates at the Federal Convention, some of the Federalist and Anti-Federalist Papers, and a few contemporary reflections upon the Constitution's origins.

title: Ornithology
description: Avian systematics, evolution, distribution, identification, and natural history.

title: Orthopaedic Anatomy
description: Advanced regional musculoskeletal anatomy. Students dissect cadavers.

title: Ortho Impairments & Ther Exer
description: Fundamentals of body mechanics and therapeutic exercise, coupled with kinesiological principles for detection and correction of basic neuromusculoskeletal anomalies.

title: Lower Extremities
description: Advanced principles of lower-extremity injury evaluation; evaluation techniques for the lower extremities.

title: Upper Extremities
description: Advanced principles of injury evaluation; evaluation techniques for the upper extremities and trunk.

title: Outdoor Skills Leadership
description: In-depth approach to leadership skills in selected outdoor specialty areas, including camping, hiking and survival, basic backpacking, winter camping, mountain biking, fly-fishing, sailing, river recreation, rock climbing, family outdoor recreation, and outdoor therapeutic recreation skills.

title: Outreach in Family Life Ed
description: Principles and practices for the development, implementation, and evaluation of family life education programs for audiences and settings outside the traditional classroom: community workshop teaching, print media, internet technology, radio, and television.

title: Ovid
description: In-depth study of Ovid's poetry.

title: Packaging Technologies
description: Fundamentals of packaging technologies; materials, design and processes. Understanding of the importance and role of packaging in the manufacturing and product environment. Combined instruction and hands-on project application of the various aspects of packaging materials, design, and processes through individual and team assignments, written reports, and oral presentations.

title: Painting
description: Fundamental concepts and techniques of oil painting.

title: Painting for Non-Majors
description: Paint media such as watercolor and acrylic will be presented; primary focus will be on oils. Course will explore both traditional and current modes of painting. Emphasis will be placed on developing a strong work ethic, development of a personal vocabulary in paint, and the exploration of a variety of painting processes.

title: Painting Fundamentals
description: Narrative illustration problems emphasizing academic study of the human figure using various media.

title: Painting Fundamentals
description: Fundamentals in oil painting and aqueous media.

title: Painting the Human Head
description: Studio course emphasizing figurative painting from live models, with an emphasis on unique aspects of portraiture and coloring of the human face.

title: Painting-Mixed Media
description: Exploring multiple aqueous media and painting mediums and processes as they relate to problem solving, idea development, and art-making.

title: Paleoclimatology
description: This course explores Earthâ€™s climate history. We explore how climate, the lithosphere, and the biosphere impact one another, review the methods used to reconstruct paleoclimate conditions, and apply these tools to new research questions.

title: Paleontology
description: Distribution, morphology, paleoecology, evolution, and stratigraphic significance of organisms in the geologic record. Field trips.

title: Pan American Women Writers
description: Readings in literature by women from throughout the Americas from 1600 to the present, with a particular focus on the intersections of gender, race, class, ethnicity, and age.

title: Parenting & Child Guidance
description: Theories and skills related to quality parent-child relationships.

title: Parenting and Guidance in ECE
description: Address young children's socio-emotional development in early childhood classrooms. Review theory and research to related peer interactions and parent-child and teacher-student relationships. Develop an understanding of instructional strategies and guidance practices in early childhood classrooms.

title: Partnership Tax
description: Examines the federal income tax consequences arising from the operation of an enterprise that is treated as a partnership for tax purposes. Topics include the allocation of partnership income and deductions among partners as well as the various problems created by contributions, distributions, and acquisitions and dispositions of partnership interests.

title: Pas de Deux
description: Ballet partnering techniques.

title: Pastoral Counseling Lab
description: Introducing chaplain candidates to basic pastoral counseling skills used in the military.  Various models of pastoral counseling; how to proved pastoral counseling in a variety of situations common in a military setting.

title: Patent Drafting & Prosecutn
description: Providing a practical, hands-on overview of the typical role an attorney plays in the representation of a client before the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) in securing a United States patent. Involving a series of case study exercises designed to follow a series of events encountered when seeking patent protection, including advising a client as to the patentability of an invention; drafting various components of a patent application such as the specification and claims; and preparing and advocating responses to Office Actions issued by the USPTO.

title: Patent Law
description: Focuses on the U.S. patent system and is designed for those with a significant interest in patent law and patent practice.

title: Pathophysiology
description: Variations in physiological mechanisms that account for development of common disturbances in normal control and activities of body's organs and organ systems.

title: Pathophysiology for AT
description: Foundational understanding of the physiology underlying common systemic diseases. Recognize, evaluate and differentiate common systemic diseases.

title: Pavement Design
description: Design, construction, evaluation, maintenance, and rehabilitation of flexible and rigid pavements; influence of traffic and environmental factors; mechanistic analysis of pavement structures using computer software.

title: Pavement Management
description: Process of planning infrastructure repairs, institutional issues, network and project levels of infrastructure management, pavement performance, deterioration modeling, benefits of treatments, life-cycle cost analyses.

title: Pedagogical Methods
description: This course provides graduate students with basic pedagogical training for teaching in the Humanities and hands-on experience in course design, classroom activity planning, and assessment strategies.

title: Thry & Mthds of Media Instrctn
description: Educational methods and techniques for addressing media in the secondary classroom; educational models and theories related to cultural and historical representations of media technologies.

title: Pedagogy
description: Advanced pedagogical studies.

title: Peer Consulting
description: Active involvement as a peer consultant in the College of Life Sciences.

title: Peoples of Africa
description: Political, economic, and social organization, family life, language, worldview, religion, ritual, artistic expression, ecological adaptation, and contemporary development issues among rural and urban sub-Saharan peoples.

title: Peoples of India
description: Society and culture on the Indian subcontinent. Stratification, kinship, marriage, religion, politics, economics.

title: Peoples of the Middle East
description: Ecology, social organization, and beliefs of nomadic, rural, and urban groups between western Africa and Pakistan.

title: Perception Cognition Language
description: Development of mental abilities; effects of maturation and learning on memory, perception, attention processes, intelligence, language, and social cognition.

description: A premier percussion chamber ensemble that seeks to connect with the percussion community. Members are determined by audition.

title: Performance Matters
description: An introduction to the Theatre Arts Studies major that emphasizes the critical thinking and creative planning necessary to become an innovative scholar artist.

title: Performance Psychology
description: Learning psychological barriers to peak performance. Developing effective techniques and routines to enhance performance.

title: Performance Seminar
description: The integration and performance of information gathered from careful research and analysis of movement style, script and score.

title: Performance Study
description: Private instruction and studio class requiring from one to four hours of daily practice.

title: Performance Workshop 2
description: Advanced experience in production: acting.

title: Performance: Recital
description: Thirty- to forty-five minute performance of cuttings from varied genres.

title: Period Studies
description: Various periods in Greek history and culture.  Topics vary.

title: Period Studies
description: Various periods in Roman history and culture.  Topics vary.

title: Personal & Group Ldrshp in Ed
description: Theoretical foundations of leadership and organizational behavior, specifically applied at the micro level to individuals and groups within educational organizations.

title: Personal Finance
description: Practical course in money management and utilizing savings.

title: Personal Financial Planning
description: Financial decision making for households in planning your financial future: vision and goals, budgeting, tax, cash management, debt reduction, insurance, investment planning and portfolio management, retirement and estate planning.  Business and family interests affecting personal finances.

title: Personal Genomics
description: For non-majors who may have a particular interest in biological and genetic principles as they apply to making informed decisions about health, medical care, and genealogy.

title: Personal Training Strategies
description: The art and science of personal fitness training for healthy adults, utilizing safe and effective techniques to develop and maintain optimal functional fitness (proper posture, balance, joint mobility, and stability), and optimal physical fitness (cardiorespiratory endurance, flexibility, muscular strength, and power).

title: Personality
description: Individual patterns of behavior, thought, and emotion; personality theories and their associated strategies of research, assessments, and personality change.

title: Personality Assessment
description: Methods used in assessing the personality and behavioral characteristics of children and adults.

title: Personality Theory
description: Contemporary theories of personality developed within the framework of major psychological systems.

title: Persuasion in the Media Age
description: A contemporary approach to examining theories, empirical research, and rhetorical practices pertaining to persuasion as well as the broader perspective of social influence.  Emphasizes how media impacts persuasive practices and draws upon examples from advertising, public relations, journalism, popular culture, etc.

title: Persuasive Writing
description: Expository and persuasive writing focusing on practical reasons for evaluating audiences, generating and structuring an argument, and making stylistic decisions. Library research paper.

title: Petrography to Petrogenesis
description: Principles of optical mineralogy and their application to the identification of minerals in thin section Petrographic analysis and its relation to rock-forming processes in igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks.

title: Petroleum Systems Analysis
description: Properties of petroleum; exploration methods; generation and migration of hydrocarbons, reservoirs, traps, and seals; sedimentary basin classification; energy resources. Extended field trip required.

title: Petrology
description: Compositions, fabrics, and field relations of igneous and metamorphic rocks; behavior of rock-forming systems. Field trips.

title: Petrophysics & Reservoir
description: Advanced use of well log tools combined with direct (core) or analog (outcrop) lithologic information to characterize underground petroleum or groundwater reservoirs.

title: Phage Genetics
description: Phage genetics with student-designed experiments.

title: Phage Comparative Genomics
description: Phage genome annotation.  Focus on experimental design and data analysis.

title: Phage Discovery
description: Phage isolation and characterization.

title: Pharmacology
description: Introduction to foundation of drug interactions from both prescription and natural herb remedies; survival, morbidity, quality of life, neurohormonal changes, symptoms, treatment indications.

title: Pharmacology
description: Principles of pharmacology, prescribing and managing drug therapy for advanced practice nurses.

title: Pharmacology in AT
description: Foundational concepts in pharmacology and pharmcological interventions for students in a variety of allied health professions. Specifically tailored to the Athletic Training master's student.

title: Phil & Aesthetic Foundations
description: Questions related to teaching music in the public schools.

title: Phil & Psych Foundations
description: The formative ideas in philosophy and psychology used to conduct and evaluate scholarly inquiry in education.  Includes basic issues, inquiry methods, and forms of scholarly analysis.

title: Philosophical Lecture Series
description: Lectures on philosophical topics by faculty and advanced students.

title: Philosophical Writing
description: Writing philosophical papers about philosophical texts or problems. Research methods in philosophy. Library research paper.

title: Family Work & Relationships
description: Changes in household labor across time, current issues around gender and household labor, and philosophical perspectives of family work and family relationships.

title: Philosophies of History
description: Fundamental problems and types of historical analysis and interpretation, philosophies of history, and work of outstanding historians.

title: Philosophies Hist
description: Fundamental problems and types of historical analysis and interpretation, philosophies of history, and work of outstanding historians.

title: Phil/Ethical School Leadership
description: Major philosophies of education and their influence on educational theory, practice, and leadership.

title: Philosophy & Hist of West Educ
description: Major philosophies of education and their influence on western educational theory and practice.

title: Philosophy & Lit
description: Interrelationship of literary art with philosophical issues.

title: Phil & Soc Psych of Leisure
description: Historical and theoretical roots of developmental youth programs that stress preventative approaches. How to develop character, citizenship, moral and physical fitness, and volunteerism; service learning.

title: Phil/Thry Coun Psy
description: Introduction to counseling psychology. Philosophical assumptions and theoretical perspectives. Integration of science and practice within a consistent philosophical framework.

title: Philosophy in Family Life Educ
description: Ethical issues and interpretive frameworks in human science that address quality of life in families.

title: Philosophy Orientation
description: Overview of philosophy as a discipline; review of philosophy major requirements and course sequence; complete introduction to philosophy research methods.

title: Philosophy of Language
description: Meaning and reference, synonymy, metaphor, exemplification, translation; linguistic, artistic, and perceptual symbol systems.

title: Philosophy of Law
description: The relation between natural and enacted law; theories of punishment; utilitarian and nonutilitarian theories of law; liberty.

title: Philosophy of Mind
description: Relationship between the mental and the physical: consciousness, intentionality, mental causation.

title: Philosophy of Religion
description: Selected figures or problems.

title: Philosophy of Science
description: Issues in philosophy of science as they apply to social sciences, including methods, epistemology, and construction of knowledge.

title: Philosophy of Social Sciences
description: Comparative analysis of the philosophy of scientific and normative inquiry.

title: Internship
description: Credit for career-oriented or job-related internship work.  Internships can be in any field for which the student qualifies.

title: Phonetics
description: General inventory of speech sounds possible in language, from both an acoustic and articulatory point of view.

title: Phonology
description: Study of natural language sound systems from a variety of theoretical perspectives.

title: Photographic Field Study
description: On-location study of photography.

title: Photography for Animation
description: Layout, references, camera technology and terminology, application of composition, lighting, and core art skills emphasized.

title: Photo Fundamentals
description: This class serves as an introduction to contemporary art photography and is designed to help familiarize students with current themes and movements within the medium while building a foundation of pertinent technical skills.

title: Photojournalism
description: Shooting, processing, selecting, and preparing images for use in various news platforms.

title: Business Career Essentials
description: Introduction for science, math, and statistics majors to careers in industry. Project planning, oral and written business presentations, business accounting, and technology readiness.

title: Acoustic Systems
description: Analyzing and modeling electro-mechano-acoustic systems. Transducers, calibration, and acoustical measurements. Sound sources, arrays, coupling, radiation, and directivity. Duct acoustics and acoustic filters.

title: Fundamentals of Acoustics
description: Vibrating systems, elastic media, mechanical energy, and radiation. Sound generation, transmission, reflection, and reception.

title: Introduction to Acoustics
description: Mathematical descriptions of physical phenomena in generation, propagation, and reception of acoustic waves. Fundamental acoustical instrumentation and analysis techniques. Application of physical principles and mathematical models to realistic problems.

title: Phylogenetic Systematics
description: Theoretical foundations of modern systematics, methods of phylogenetic inference, and discussion of contemporary literature.

title: Physical Activity & Health
description: Role of physical activity and fitness in the prevention and reversal of disease, including type 2 diabetes, heart disease, cancer, osteoporosis, etc., and in the promotion of health.

title: PE & Hlth Ed - Elem Sch Tchrs
description: Required for state licensure and designed to provide prospective elementary school teachers with an understanding of the need for, necessary content, and field experience working in an effective, quality physical education program. Areas of focus include the instructional process, class management and discipline, program implementation, materials, issues affecting the elementary school physical education program and its students, and strategies and activities for learning. Addresses elementary health education, including protective factors of healthy self, mental and emotional health, safety and disease prevention, substance abuse prevention, nutrition, and human development. Includes early and frequent field-based experiences that provide the opportunity to practice and refine new-teacher performance standards in the physical education setting. Aligned with both the BYU-Public School Partnership Five Commitments and UETS teaching standards.

title: Physical Chemistry 1
description: Quantum mechanics, group theory, atomic and molecular structure, spectroscopy, computational methods, statistical mechanics.

title: Physical Chemistry 2
description: Thermodynamics and equilibria, states of matter, kinetic-molecular theory, kinetics, statistical mechanics.

title: Physical Chemistry - Engineers
description: Quantum mechanics, atomic and molecular structure, spectroscopy, computational methods, statistical mechanics, thermodynamics and equilibria, states of matter, kinetic-molecular theory, kinetics.

title: Physical Chemistry Lab 1
description: Experiments in areas of physical chemistry, including quantum mechanics, spectroscopy, thermodynamics, kinetics, and statistical mechanics; computer manipulation of data; report preparation and presentation.

title: Physical Chemistry Lab 2
description: Additional experiments in physical chemistry (see Chem 464 for subjects); computer manipulation of data; report preparation and presentation.

title: Physical Education
description: Not a valid course. Only to be used to apply credits to General Education requirements.

title: Physical Education
description: Not a valid course.  Only to be used to apply credits to General Education requirements.

title: PE for Special Populations
description: Theoretical and practical aspects of teaching individuals with disabilities in the physical education setting.

title: Physical Educ Pedagogy
description: Sport pedagogy for students minoring in coaching and teaching physical education.

title: PE, Health, and Play
description: This course prepares pre-service teachers with an understanding of the foundational motor skills and content specific to physical education and health as they consider play as an important pedagogical approach to support physical and emotional development, health, and wellness.

title: Physical Geology
description: Materials, structure, and surface features of the earth and the geologic processes involved in their development. Field trips and lab studies, use of aerial photos.

title: Physical Optics
description: Concepts of physical optics. In physical optics the dominant property of light is its wave nature. In this course we use a variety of models, including the scalar wave, electromagnetic wave, and statistical optics models, to examine the phenomena of interference, coherence, polarization, and absorption and dispersion. We learn not only the fundamental aspects of these topics, but also concrete applications that are ubiquitous in the technology of our modern world.

title: Physical Reasoning With Data
description: An experiential learning physics-based approach to data science that includes designing physical experiments, collecting data, and investigating uncertainties, causality and correlation in datasets while developing cross-discipline technical communication skills.

title: Physical Science
description: Conceptual lectures and demonstrations of the most significant and universal laws and models describing the physical world by faculty from the Physics and Astronomy, Chemistry and Biochemistry, and Geology departments.

title: Physical Training-AF ROTC
description: Physical training course for Air Force ROTC members only.

title: Physical Training - Army ROTC
description: Physical training course for Army ROTC members only.

title: Physics & Math Review
description: Review of mathematics and introductory physics for returning missionaries and others returning after a significant break.

title: Physics By Inquiry:Electricity
description: Exploring principles of electricity through scripted inquiry resulting in personal discovery of key principles and learning to teach through inquiry methods.

title: Physics By Inquiry: Mechanics
