description: Students will master a new topic related to American government and politics, learn to appropriately apply theories and methods learned in previous courses to understanding this new topic, and improve writing and research skills.

title: Topics in American Studies
description: Multidisciplinary study of a carefully defined problem in American culture. Topics vary.

title: Topics Analytic Number Theory
description: Current topics of research interest.

title: Topics in ANES
description: Topical studies in the ancient Near East based on student interest and faculty expertise.

title: Arts and Entrepreneurship
description: Taught in collaboration with the Rollins Center for Entrepreneurship and Technology. Application of foundational principles of entrepreneurship in developing goals as artists, performers, and creative professionals. The latest in design thinking, innovation, entrepreneurship, and the correct principles for starting or developing a business specifically related to the arts.\n

title: Topics in Beh Neuroscience
description: Advanced topics and skills in behavioral neuroscience.

title: Topics: Biological Sciences
description: Survey or introduction to principles of biological sciences; topics may include but are not limited to human, environmental, micro or molecular biology, health and disease, nutrition, genetics, etc.

title: Topics in Business Management
description: Current business-related topics varying by semester and section.

title: Topics in Classical Lit & Civ
description: Classical literary genres; rhetorical, philosophical, and historical writings; relationships of art and literature; or the classical tradition in the Middle Ages and Renaissance. Topics vary.

title: Topics in Clinical Psychology
description: Theory and practice in specific topics.

title: Topics in Comparative Politics
description: Students will learn how to critique and construct theories of democratic development, and deepen their familiarity with the research traditions of regime change and theoretical paradigms of comparative politics.

title: Topics in Computer Graphics
description: Latest research in the field of computer graphics.  Recent papers read, presented, and discussed.

title: Topics in Computer Science
description: Undergraduate level subjects as announced before each semester.

title: Topics in Computer Science
description: Undergraduate-level topics as announced.

title: Topics in Computer Science
description: Undergraduate level subjects as announced before each semester.

title: Topics Econ Analys
description: Topics vary. Examples include career preparation, monetary and financial history. Check with instructor.

title: Topics in Economic History
description: History of economic thought using modern techniques to understand the evolution of the discipline.

title: Topics in Economic Theory
description: Topics vary. Examples include history of economic thought, behavioral economics. Check with instructor.

title: Topics in Entrepreneurship
description: Special topics in entrepreneurship. Specific topics covered vary year to year.

title: Topics in Ethics
description: Select topics, figures, problems, and theories in ethics. Topics include meta-ethics, deontology, consequentialism, virtue theory, applied ethics, ethical argumentation.

title: Topics in EXDM
description: Special topics, mentored research, and learning experiences, including attending professional conferences, Study Abroad participation, and other learning experiences.

title: Topics in Finance
description: Current finance-related topics varying by semester and section.

title: Topics in Geology
description: Short, undergraduate-level courses and extended field trips offered on an irregular basis.The following topics may be offered given sufficient demand: Energy Systems; Exploratory Geophysics and Modeling; and Planetary Seminar.

title: Topics in Geology
description: Short, graduate-level courses and extended field trips offered on an irregular basis. The following topics may be offered given sufficient demand: Advanced Sedimentology; Energy Systems; Exploratory Geophysics and Modeling; and Planetary Seminar.

title: Topics in German Linguistics
description: In-depth study of a topic related to Germanic linguistics.

title: Topics in German Literature
description: In-depth study of a period, movement, theme, or author in German literature, film, or culture.

title: Topics in German Lit (English)
description: In-depth study of a period, movement, theme, or author in German literature, film, or culture. Instructional language is English.

title: Topics: Global&Cltrl Awareness
description: Survey or introductory approach to issues of global and cultural awareness.

title: Topics in Global Development
description: Special topics for the Global Development track. Topic chosen by instructor.

title: Topics in GSCM
description: Focus on a major topic, issue, or analytical method used in the field of global supply chain management. The specific topics covered will vary year to year.

title: Topcs Greek Liter
description: Topics vary.

title: Topics in HRM
description: Special topics in organizational behavior. Course content varies from year to year.

title: Topics in IAS
description: Study relating to current world problems.

title: Topics in Intl Relations
description: Students will become familiar with the international, regional, and national policies in place to address some difficult challenges. Students will appreciate the complex nature of the interplay between economic, political and cultural aspects of the global and national communities.

title: Topcs Latin Liter
description: Topics vary.

title: Topics in Legal Studies
description: Special topics for the Legal Studies track. Topic chosen by instructor.

title: Topics: Literature
description: Survey or introductory approach to issues in literature.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: Topics selected from various aspects of mathematics. Possibilities include, but are not limited to, combinatorial theory, factorization and primality testing, game theory, harmonic analysis, hyperbolic geometry, linear programming, Lie groups, p-adic numbers, set theory and mathematical logic stochastic processes, supply chain management, voting theory.

title: Topics in Math Ed
description: Includes specific research areas and curriculum studies of school mathematics topics (i.e. geometry, algebra, and calculus).

title: Topics in Middle East Studies
description: Topics vary.

title: Topics in Music
description: Topics vary.

title: Topics Neural Nets
description: Advanced topics and readings in neural  networks and machine learning.

title: Topics in Neuropsychology
description: Current topics, including neuroanatomy and adult and child assessment. Other topics as determined by student interest.

title: Topics: Physical Science
description: Survey or introduction to principles of physical sciences; topics may include but are not limited to chemistry, physics, geology, etc.

title: Topics in Political Philosophy
description: Students will develop skills in use of philosophical methodology, give attention to articulating premises clearly and to understanding inferential validity using argumentative tools such as deduction, abduction, induction, and reflective equilibrium.

title: Topics in Pol Sci Methods
description: Advanced methods of political science. Topics selected by instructor.

title: Topics in Political Strategy
description: Special topics for the Political Strategy track. Topic chosen by instructor.

title: Topics in Politics
description: Students will use appropriate methods of analysis and research, including qualitative and quantitative methods, historical comparison, and textual interpretation to answer political questions. Students will improve on their ability to write effectively for a professional audience.

title: Topics in Public Policy
description: Students are expected to develop a knowledge of current issues and policies which affect our society. This course will pay a particular attention to how policies effect diverse and at-risk populations in the United States.

title: Topics in Public Policy
description: Advanced topics in public policy methods, process, and specializations.

title: Topics: Quantitative Reasoning
description: Introduction to principles of mathematics, statistics, quantitative reasoning, finance and/or accounting.

title: Topics in Scandinavian Studies
description: Topic varies. Typical topics might be folklore, culture, music, film, emigration, art and design, political and economic problems, literature in translation, etc.  Includes International Cinema.

title: Topics in Social Impact
description: Current social impact-related topics varying by semester and section.

title: Topics: Social Science
description: Survey or introductory approach to issues in the social sciences; topics may include but are not limited to anthropology, archaeology, economics, government, history, psychology, sociology, social work, etc.

title: Topics in Strategic Management
description: Focus on a major topic, issue, or analytical method used in the field of strategy. The specific topics covered will vary year to year.

title: Advanced Philosophy of Art
description: Topics and figures in the philosophy of art, architecture, music, and film.

title: Topics:  Arts
description: Survey or introductory approach to issues in the arts.  Topics may include but are not limited to music, dance, fine art, design, film, interdisciplinary humanities, or area studies.

title: Topics in TRM
description: Special topics, mentored research, and learning experiences, including attending professional conferences, Study Abroad participation, and other learning experiences.

title: Torts
description: Study of the judicial process in civil actions for damages or equitable relief for physical, appropriational, and defamatory harms to personality, property, and relational interests, with some consideration of alternative reparation systems such as workers' compensation.

title: Toward Superior Japanese 1
description: Using Japanese to debate on abstract topics related to current events reported in Japanese media.

title: Toward Superior Japanese: Lit
description: Reading and analyzing fictional texts in Japanese from major modern authors. Emphasis on reading comprehension, vocabulary and kanji mastery, and stylistic analysis.

title: Toward Superior Communication
description: Students will work to improve speaking and listening skills in Japanese that will assist them in moving toward Superior ranking, including stating abstract opinions, supporting opinions, hypothesizing, and doing professional oral tasks.

title: Trademark Law
description: Introduction to Lanham Act and related common law doctrines designed to protect against consumer confusion and appropriation of commercial goodwill. In addition to the technical requirements for trademark eligibility, registration, and infringement, the constitutional and economic underpinnings of trademark protection will be considered and current trends toward the propertization of trademark law will be evaluated. Will also include material on the trademark treatment of Internet domain names, metatags, and links.

title: Traditional China
description: From a loose federation of Neolithic societies, Chinese civilization emerges as East Asia's dominant political and cultural force; developments to ca. 1500.

title: Traffic Engineering
description: Traffic stream characteristics, traffic flow theory, traffic control devices, capacity and level of service, warrants, signal timing and optimization, signal coordination.

title: Traffic Simulation & Analysis
description: Concept of traffic simulation, modeling techniques, calibration and validation, simulation output comprehension, shock wave analysis, queuing theory, use of simulation software.

title: Tragedy
description: History and theory of tragedy.

title: Imprl Trag & Epic
description: Selections from Seneca, Lucan, and the Flavian epic poets.

title: Transactional Lawyering
description: Emphasizes practical skills over substantive knowledge, teaches the elements of contracts and how these elements work together. Learn how to translate what your client wants to accomplish into a clear and effective contract, and how to revise contracts with an eye to advocacy rather than stylistic preference. Work with various forms of existing agreements to craft contracts tailored to your client's needs. Prepare contracts and documents used by early stage companies.

title: Transactional Legal Drafting
description: Introduction to skills needed to be an effective transactional lawyer. Learning to draft clear, effective, plain language contracts and to analyze transactional documents. Introduction to a variety of subject matters, including real estate, intellectual property, employment, general corporate, and mergers and acquisitions.

title: Transatlantic Literary History
description: This course explores British and American literary history from the eighteenth through the twenty-first centuries by studying key figures, movements, genres, events, themes, and ideas through the lens of transatlantic literary exchange.

title: Transcendence: Religion & Film
description: Historical, stylistic, and thematic survey of approaches to religious and spiritual subject matter in film.

title: Transformers for NLP
description: Understand and learn how to use state of the art transformer language models for many Natural Language Processing and Understanding tasks, such as text classification, text generation, question answering, machine translation, and many other tasks.

title: Transition planning
description: Selection and adaptation of curriculum accommodations, transition planning, and post-secondary preparation.

title: Translation Localizatn Intern
description: Off-campus internship experience in the field of Translation & Localization.

title: Trans & Interpretation Project
description: Individual translation and/or interpretation projects.

title: Trans Electron Microscopy
description: Practical and theoretical aspects of sample preparation, basic and advanced imaging, electron diffraction, and other analytical materials characterization techniques on the transmission electron microscope (TEM).

title: Transnational Lit after 1800
description: Period-specific course, after 1800, using transnational models for literary analysis. Involves selected texts in a transatlantic context and in the light of applicable theoretical approaches.

title: Transnational Lit before 1800
description: Period-specific course, before 1800, using transnational models for literary analysis. Involves selected texts in a transnational context and in the light of applicable theoretical approaches.

title: Transport Phenomena
description: Transport mechanisms and coefficients and fundamental field equations for momentum, heat, and mass transport, with application to system design.

title: Transportation Site Planning
description: Characteristics of transportation site planning; traffic impact analysis; principles of access design; driveway, site circulation, and parking lot design; permitting of proposed developments.

title: Trauma-Informed SW Practice
description: How to work effectively with clients who have experienced trauma. Viewing client mental distress symptoms through a trauma lens, and preparation to work with clients who have experienced diverse forms of trauma. Upon completion, students will receive multiple online trauma certificates, including, but not limited to TF-CBT and CPT from MUSC (Medical University of South Carolina) and complex trauma; secondary traumatic stress; culture and trauma; family systems; terrorism, disaster and children; and military families through the National Child Traumatic Stress Network (NCTSN).

title: Travel Writing
description: Theory and practice of writing about travel experience.

title: Trees
description: Understand fundamental concepts dealing with the ecology, biology and care of trees, including how they affect the mental, emotional, and spiritual well-being of individuals.

title: Trigonometry
description: Circular functions, triangle relationships, identities, inverse trig functions, trigonometric equations, vectors, complex numbers, DeMoivre's theorem.

title: Trombone
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice

title: Trumpet
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice

title: Trusts
description: This course examines the legal framework of private and charitable trusts as vehicles for the donative disposition and management of personal wealth, both inter vivos and testamentary with emphasis on the nature of the fiduciary obligations of trustees and the rights and obligations of trust grantors and beneficiaries.

title: Tuba
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice

title: Turbulence
description: Introduction to turbulence, flow instability and transition, concept of scale, Reynolds averaging, wall-bounded and free shear flows, closure modes, and measurement techniques.

title: Tutorial in Public Policy
description: Tutorial in public policy process and specializations.

title: Tutorial Internship in Arabic
description: Individual research in cooperation with graduate faculty member in problems relating to Arabic literature and language. Tutorial work in writing research papers. Topics vary according to interests and expertise of faculty supervisor.

title: Tutorial Internship in Chinese
description: Individual research in cooperation with graduate faculty member in problems relating to Chinese literature and language. Tutorial work in writing research papers. Topics vary according to interests and expertise of faculty supervisor.

title: Tutorial Internship: Japanese
description: Individual research in cooperation with graduate faculty member in problems relating to Japanese literature and language. Tutorial work in writing research papers. Topics vary according to interests and expertise of faculty supervisor.

title: Tutorial Internship in Korean
description: Individual research in cooperation with graduate faculty member in problems relating to Korean literature and language. Tutorial work in writing research papers. Topics vary according to interests and expertise of faculty supervisor.

title: Tutorial Internship in Russian
description: Individual research in cooperation with graduate faculty members in problems relating to Russian. Tutorial work in writing research papers. Topics vary according to interests and expertise of faculty supervisors.

title: TV Commercial Production
description: Discussing and applying television commercial production principles; creating and executing TV commercial concepts.

title: 20th-Century Brazilian Lit
description: Critical study of genres and texts from 20th-century Brazil.

title: 20th-Century Counterpoint
description: Counterpoint from the works of Schoenberg, Stravinsky, Crumb, Lutoslawski, and others.

title: 20th Century Lit
description: Genre (twentieth-century novel, drama, or poetry) or particular school (Generation of 1898, Generation of 1927, etc.) emphasized.

title: 20th Century Literature
description: Genre (twentieth-century novel, drama, or poetry) or particular school (Generation of 1898, Generation of 1927, etc.)

title: Typography 1
description: Studio course which familiarizes the student with the history, terminology, elements, and principles of effective typographic communication.

title: Typography 2
description: An advanced studio course that continues the study of complex typographic grid systems and their application to visual problem solving. Through a rigorous exploration of written and visual content, students refine their understanding of typography as an essential element in visual communication.

title: Typology
description: Introduction to the study of language universals and linguistic typology.

title: US Constitutional History
description: American constitutional history from the founding to the present, with special emphasis on four periods of especially significant constitutional development: the Founding, Reconstruction, the New Deal, and the Civil Rights movement. Not exclusively a history of the Supreme Court, but a study of the regime created by the Constitution in all its branches and in all its facets.

title: US Constitutnl His
description: Constitutional traditions and constitution making, federalism, and constitutional notions of political equity and social justice, from the colonial period to the present.

title: US Foreign Policy
description: Formation, implementation, analysis, and criticism of themes in American foreign policy.

title: US Foreign Relations
description: U.S. diplomatic history from the American revolution to the present; examines major themes and critical events within both domestic and international contexts.

title: U.S. Foreign Relations Law
description: Examines constitutional, statutory, and common law doctrines that govern the United States' conduct of foreign relations. Focuses on the allocation of foreign relations authority, both among the branches of the federal government and between the federal and state governments. Specific topics include the scope of the treaty power, the constitutionality of executive agreements, the judiciary's role in deciding foreign relations questions, and the domestic legal status of international law.

title: US Hist, 1890-1945
description: Political, economic, and social movements and ideas that trace rise of U.S. as a world power in first half of twentieth century.

title: US Hist, 1945-2000
description: Movements and ideas that shaped society, politics, economy, and diplomacy of the United States from 1945 to 2000.

title: U.S. Latinx Literature
description: Spanish-English literature of the Mexican-American within the United States.

title: U.S. Latinx Literature
description: Spanish-English literature of Mexican-Americans within the United States.

title: US Religious Hist Since 1860
description: Examines religious people, institutions, beliefs, and practices in U.S. history since the Civil War.

title: US Religious History to 1860
description: Religious developments from colonial times to 1860.

title: Ukrainian Dance Tech 1
description: Ukrainian dance techniques and skills from selected dance styles.

title: Ultimate Frisbee
description:
Beginning skills and strategies of ultimate, including throwing, catching, cutting,
footwork, various defensive and offensive designs, as well as a survey of the rules and regulations of the
game.

title: Ulysses Theme
description: History and development of Ulysses theme.

title: Uncertainty Quantification
description: The theory and practice of for assessing the influence of uncertainty on the behavior of systems, models, and corresponding predictions. Students will apply uncertainty quantification methods to example models and a system/model of their choice.   \n

title: Undrgraduate Research
description: Undergraduate research experience.

title: Undergraduate Research
description: Students receive course credit for doing undergraduate research under the supervision of a faculty mentor.

title: Undergrad Research & Study
description: Individual research and study in any area of exercise science.

title: Research Experience
description: Gain laboratory research skills under the supervision of a faculty mentor. Experiences may include, but are not limited to, review of literature, experimental design, data gathering and analysis, interpretation, writing, presenting, and publishing of the research, as determined by the faculty mentor. Experiences will enhance student learning through hands-on activities and close collaboration with faculty or a qualified on-campus mentor.

title: Neuro Research Experience
description: Neuroscience-related laboratory research experience skills required to review literature, properly gather and interpret data from scientific experimentation as well as data analysis, writing, and publishing research.  Enhance student learning through hands-on activities and close collaboration with faculty or a qualified on-campus mentor.

title: Undergrad Research in N D F S
description: Mentored research experience.

title: Undergrad Research Training
description: Introduction of undergraduate students to the concepts of research and evaluation through practical experience.

title: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Student leadership training, including organization and operation of student technology education clubs. College Lecture attendance required. Separate program sections.

title: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Topics or issues in Construction and Facilities Management are presented and discussed.

title: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Current information in the plant and wildlife sciences.

title: Undergraduate Special Projects
description: Students identify an interesting problem in computer science and solve it with the aid of faculty members.

title: Community, Family & Indiv Hlth
description: Application of resilience/family theories to understanding health issues and solutions at the community, family, and individual level. Analyze how faith and science enable effective solutions to public health issues.

title: Understanding Modern Societies
description: Comparative-historical theory and research on the political, economic, social, and cultural processes in the formation, social organization, and future prospects of modern societies.

title: Understanding Organizations
description: Perspectives of psychology and sociology on the organization, organizational identity, organizational effectiveness, and organizational change.  Critical thinking and application to cases and personal experience.

title: SLA for K-12 Schools
description: Major concepts, principles, theories, and research relating to acquisition of English as a second language; creating learning environments supporting the development of English proficiency.

title: Unexpect Connect: Biol-Arts
description: The class, team-taught by professors from different disciplines, explores unities between biology and the arts. Through reading, writing, and conversation, students gain understanding and skills to engage in real-life questions. Topics are announced in the class schedule. Honors only.

title: Unexpect Connect: Biol-Letters
description: The class, team-taught by professors from different disciplines, explores unities between biology and letters. Through reading, writing, and conversation, students gain understanding and skills to engage in real-life questions. Topics are announced in the class schedule. Honors only.

title: Unexpect Connect: Phys-Letters
description: The class, team-taught by professors from different disciplines, explores unities between the physical sciences, literature, and philosophy. Through reading, writing, and conversation, students gain understanding and skills to engage in real-life questions. Topics are announced in the class schedule. Honors only.

title: Unexpect Connect: Phys-Culture
description: The class, team-taught by professors from different disciplines, explores unities between physical science and culture. Through reading, writing, and conversation, students gain understanding and skills to engage real-life questions. Topics are announced in the class schedule. Honors only.

title: Unexpect Connect: Soc Sci-Ltrs
description: The class, team-taught by professors from different disciplines, explores unities between the social sciences, literature, and philosophy. Through reading, writing, and conversation, students gain understanding and skills to engage in real-life questions. Topics are announced in the class schedule. Honors only.

title: Unexpect Connect: Soc Sci-Art
description: The class, team-taught by professors from different disciplines, explores the unities between social science and art. Through reading, writing, and conversation, students gain understanding and skills to engage real-life questions. Topics are announced in the class schedule. Honors only.

title: Unexpect Connect: Sp Topics
description: The class, team-taught by professors from different disciplines, explores unities between life sciences, culture, physical sciences, social sciences, languages of learning, letters, or the arts. Through reading, writing, and conversation, students gain understanding and skills to engage real-life questions. Topics and disciplinary perspectives are announced in the class schedule. Honors only.

title: Ungulate Conservation & Mgt
description: Integrating principles of natural history, population ecology, behavior, and conservation biology of North American ungulates.  Special emphasis on management and conservation applications.

title: Unit Operations Laboratory
description: Experimental verification of unit operations design principles; data collection and reduction; report preparation.

title: Unit Operations Lab 1
description: Experimental verification of unit operations design principles; data collection and reduction; report preparation.

title: Unit Operations Lab 2
description: Experimental verification of unit operations design principles; data collection and reduction; report preparation.

title: US and Canada
description: Analysis of the natural environment, historical development, cultural patterns, economic systems, and political structures of geographic regions.

title: U S History
description: Not a valid course. Only to be used to apply credits to General Education requirements.

title: US Immigration History
description: Overview of the key developments, questions, debates, and theories surrounding the study of U.S. immigration history. A chronological and thematic exploration of the intersection of race/ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality, and citizenship within U.S. immigration history.

title: US Women's History
description: Survey course of women's experience in American culture and society from the Puritans to the present.

title: University Spanish 1
description: Continued development of grammar, cultural understanding, reading, writing, and conversation skills as introduced in foundational courses. Students are expected to attain an Intermediate-Mid proficiency level.

title: University Spanish 2
description: Expanded development of grammar, cultural understanding, reading, writing, and conversation skills as introduced in foundational and intermediate courses. Students are expected to attain an Intermediate-Mid to Intermediate-High proficiency level.

title: University Spanish 3
description: Continued development of grammar, cultural understanding, conversation skills, writing, and reading through the study of literature. Students are expected to attain an Intermediate-High proficiency level.

title: Univ Teaching 1
description: An exploration into learning theories that influence teaching pedagogies: understanding how students learn; designing curriculum to fit current research-backed models of learning; understanding assessment strategies; practicing backward design; and preparing graduate students for an authentic teaching experience.

title: Univ Teaching 2
description: Guided experience in development and evaluation of instructional product: analyzing learning outcomes; developing instructional materials and assessment instruments; critique of finished instruction; and practical experience under the direction of a faculty member.

title: Univ Teaching 3
description: Authentic teaching experience under the mentorship of a faculty member.

title: Teaching Apprenticeship
description: Mentored experience teaching a university course.

title: University Teaching Practicum
description: University teaching under supervision of a faculty member, including teaching or team teaching an undergraduate course and/or team teaching a master's level course (or portions of courses).

title: Urban and Local Politics
description: Theories and empirical research on politics of cities, counties, and districts. Policy solutions for issues affecting local governments, such as housing, law enforcement, and racial inequality.

title: Urban Economics
description: Economic models relating to spatial location of economic activities and development of cities. Application of economic theory to problems and policies associated with housing, urban transportation, congestion, local government finance, and other urban problems.

title: Geog Urban Environ
description: History and theory of urban development, including why cities exist and how cities function.

title: Urban Planning Law
description: The political and legal context within which urban planning takes place.

title: Urban Planning Methods
description: Applications of methods and techniques commonly used in the urban planning process, emphasizing data collection and analysis, fieldwork, and writing skills.

title: Urban Sociology
description: Norms, social controls, and social processes in urban areas in both historical and contemporary perspectives.

title: Urban Transportation Planning
description: Theories and principles of transportation planning emphasizing environmental, energy, economic, and social issues.

title: Urban Transportation Planning
description: Urban transportation planning and decision making, intermodal transportation, land-use transportation interrelationships, transportation demand modeling, site impact analysis, sustainable transportation; livable cities.

title: Urban Water Infrastructure
description: Purposes and features of municipal drinking water, wastewater, irrigation, and storm water systems. Analysis of their capacity and demand. Overview of their planning, design, construction, and operation.

title: User Experience 1
description: Students will design better human interactions by mastering the process of creating usable digital experiences and crafting engaging user interfaces.

title: User Experience 2
description: This course helps students develop engaging user experiences in digital products, using more advanced design research methods, and ability to create some design in code

title: User Experience Design
description: User experience design techniques and best practices including requirements analysis, usability studies, prototyping methods, evaluation techniques, and cognitive, social, and emotional theories.

title: User Experience Design
description: Leadership in a technical field, and user experience design in the context of web and mobile application development.

title: UX Portfolio
description: This course helps students showcase and design their overall portfolio by pulling together all of the projects created in previous design classes using effective case studies in well-designed websites and presentation decks.

title: UX Research Methods
description: This class offers an in-depth study of user experience research methods and techniques for developing engaging digital products.

title: Using Basic Media Tools
description: Introductory course to familiarize students with basics in camera, lighting, and sound fundamentals.

title: Tech in Lang Tchg & Rsrch
description: Using and applying various types of media and technology appropriate for second language teaching, learning, and research.

title: Utah
description: Major themes and events in the history of Utah, including the evolution of Latter-day Saint identity and culture, with particular emphasis upon thematic intersections between Utah's history and the history of the American West and the United States at large.

title: Utah Legislative Politics
description: Preparatory seminar for students in the Utah State Legislature internship. Utah history and political structure. Relations between legislature and other branches of government. Challenges of legislative service.

title: Utah Legislature Internship
description: Students will fulfill the tasks and duties of their individual internships with the Utah State Legislature and complete academic writing assignments related to the substance of their work.

title: Utilitarianism
description: Designed to survey the history of ethics or to examine multiple periods and figures in the history of philosophy.

title: Varieties of English
description: Research and theory of issues regarding regional and social variation in English, including world Englishes and English-based pidgins and creoles

title: Venture Capital for Startups
description: Explore how successful startups navigate obtaining funding from venture capital firms, the typical terms and structures of those relationships, and how they manage those relationships over time. Considered from the perspective of both the venture capital firm and the founder seeking capital, with hands-on practice.

title: Venture Capital/Private Equity
description: Academic and applied experience opportunities focusing on venture capital and private equity industries, capital acquisition, due diligence, management, governance issues, and best-practice decision making.

title: Venture Studio Practicum
description: This student-led Venture Studio helps founders and operators of new ventures in their early stages to to begin and execute appropriate "next steps." This acceleration process is a beginning-to-end solution for new venture problems in tactical operations, sales and marketing, people organizations, legal and compliance, and engineering and product development as needed at each stage of the process. The course requires diligence, analysis, and resource application to reduce failure risk for new ventures by all key measures. Students will typically address client capability gaps in several market stages: Incubator/Accelerator; Studio; Bootstrap; and Angel/Seed stage.

title: Venture Studio Practicum
description: This student-led Venture Studio helps founders and operators of new ventures in their early stages to to begin and execute appropriate "next steps."   This acceleration process is a beginning-to-end solution for new venture problems in tactical operations, sales and marketing, people organizations, legal and compliance, and engineering and product development as needed at each stage of the process. The course requires diligence, analysis, and resource application to reduce failure risk for new ventures by all key measures.  Students will typically address client capability gaps in several market stages:  Incubator/Accelerator; Studio; Bootstrap; and Angel/Seed stage.

title: Vergil
description: In-depth study of Vergil's poetry.

title: Vergil, Aug.&Dante
description: Literary influence, originality, status of classic.

title: Verification and Validation
description: Foundational topics in verification and validation; the application of logic to building correct systems. Covers logics to formally specify properties of systems, verifications of basic systems, and advanced topics in formal verification for complex systems.

title: Vertebrate Paleont
description: Paleobiology, osteology, and phylogeny of the vertebrates. Field trips required. Lab studies.

title: Veterinary Science
description: Independent student research under faculty supervision.

title: Video & Photography Production
description: Teaching video and photography to inspire, communicate, and develop creativity. Fundamentals include planning, storyboarding, camera techniques, composition, assembling, and editing video and photo projects.

title: Video Game Pre-Production
description: Develop video game ideas

title: Video Game Production 1
description: Using prototyping to develop game experience ideas by building a minimal viable product around a core experience idea. Participating in a team and coordinating tasks, including white-boxing, concept design, modeling, layout, rigging, and tool building.

title: Video Game Production 2
description: Polishing a video game for production as a team, including texturing, animation, FX, lighting, tool applications, AI, UI, and gameplay mechanics.

title: Video Reporting
description: Principles and techniques of video reporting. Includes recording and editing reports on campus happenings, government, courts, and other institutions. Lab includes reporting for digital audiences through online platforms.

title: Viola
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice

title: Violin
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice

title: Virology
description: Basic principles of virology, emphasizing selected molecular aspects of virus life cycles and disease processes.

title: Virology Laboratory
description: Laboratory exercises illustrating in vitro behavior of selected viruses. Developing laboratory skills for virus studies.

title: Virtual Design & Construction
description: Develop mechanical, electrical, and plumbing plans using Building Information Modeling (BIM) and clash detection and resolution. Manage the coordination process, including 5D estimating, site logistics, animations, and high definition renderings.

title: Visual Anthro
description: Overview of visual and sonic anthropology methods including ethnographic film, photography, art, sound and other sensory methods. Students will receive training in modes of data collection and presentation, including how media allow new ways of understanding what it means to be human.

title: Visual Communication
description: Rhetorical perspectives on the theory, criticism, and production of visual media.

title: Visual Communication Design
description: Teaching visual design principles and processes through digital and print media.

title: Vis Comm in PR
description: This class is designed to teach students how to effectively tell stories through media graphics, photos and videos. As students embrace the creative process and learn to think (and see the world around them) in terms of space, line, shape, form, size, color, texture, value, camera framing and video sequencing, they will become a more effective communicator, with the ability to create their own visual communication pieces from scratch (i.e., no templates) and/or give valuable feedback to others who are creating content.

title: Visual Development
description: Fundamental skills of animation artists including design, composition, staging, value and color.

title: Vis Dev & Character Design
description: Design characters, props, and environments for various uses in animation and print.

title: Visual Literacy
description: Introduction to designerly methods of visual literacy; including how designers think, practice, evaluate, and create persuasive, visual compositions. Manipulating visual elements to a goal. How to break down the persuasive qualities of a visual composition by creating both 2 and 3-dimensional abstract artifacts. Understanding and applying a well-designed line and space. One of four core design courses exploring aptitude for a career in design.

title: Visual Narrative
description: This class teaches foundational skills that animation students require when working in a shot-based production environment. Cinematography, layout, composition and storytelling techniques will be a focus of study.

title: Visual Storytelling
description: Narrative storytelling through the medium of photography. Concepts, techniques and styles used in photojournalism, documentary, and photoreportage.

title: Vis & Presentation Methods
description: Creating appropriate imagery for industrial design presentations. Improving on the analog motor skill of sketching. Introduction to digital sketching methods to enhance fundamental sketching concepts (use of line, proportion, composition, manually indicating basic form, perspective), as well as to the use of color, materials and finishes to accurately communicate an artifact.

title: VLSI Comm Circuits
description: Frequency synthesizers; low-jitter, voltage-controlled oscillators; high Q circuits; clock regeneration; phase-locked loops; frequency discriminators; and radio-on-a-chip concepts.

title: Vocal Literature
description: Continuation of Music 402A with emphasis on opera and oratorio.

title: Vocal Literature
description: Survey of literature with emphasis on art song. Research in area of concentration.

title: Vocal Pedagogy
description: Introduction to physiology, acoustics, and pedagogy of singing.

title: Vocal Tech for Choir Men
description: Vocal training to prepare student for participation in an advanced choral ensemble.  Topics will cover vocal technique, sight singing, and choral musicianship.

title: Voice & Diction
description: Skills involved in producing an effective voice; International Phonetic Alphabet. Lab required.

title: Voice Over
description: Studio procedures and protocol, skills involved in producing effective reading choices, creation and cataloging voice over characters for commercial and animation voice overs.

title: Voice Prod Phonetics 1
description: Foundational exercises to aid in freeing tensions, habits/patterns, and finding the natural state of the voice. Lab required. Introduction to the use of Standard American Stage Dialect with International Phonetic Alphabet. Identification of speech/articulation problems.

title: Voice Prod Phonetics 2
description: Advanced exercises to aid in the understanding and use of optimal vocal technique with emphasis on singing. Continued study and mastery of Standard American Stage Dialect with International Phonetic Alphabet.  Lab required.

title: Voice Technique 1
description: Class instruction in voice technique.

title: Voice Interfaces
description: Methods and development platforms for Voice User Interfaces. Principles of effective design; differences from visual or menu-based interfacesâ€™ mechanics of automatic speech recognition, intent detection, slot filling, dialog state tracking, text generation, and knowledge representation.

title: Voice, Resonance, Upper Airway
description: Assessment and treatment of disorders of the speaking voice.

title: Volcanoes & Ore Deposits
description: Examination of the role of volcanic rocks and processes in the generation of ore deposits.

title: Volleyball, Beginning
description: Beginning volleyball skills, rules, and strategies. Skills include underhand and overhand serves, forearm passing, setting, attacking, blocking, serve reception techniques, 6-6 and 4-2 offense and 4-2 defense strategies, scoring.

title: Volleyball, Intermediate
description: Intermediate volleyball skills, rules, and strategies. Skills include floater and top spin serves, forearm passing, setting, back setting, strong side and seak side attacking, blocking serve reception techniques, 6-6 and 6-2 offenses, and 4-2 defensive strategies.

title: Volunteer Management
description: The focus of this course is on recruiting, training, motivating, and retaining volunteers, as well as managing volunteer programs as a whole.

title: Walking
description:
Beginning introduction to principles of exercise and nutrition, safety, and principles
of walking. Students will go on a variety of walks around and starting from BYU campus.

title: Washington DC Internship
description: Students will fulfill the tasks and duties of their individual internships in Washington, D.C. and complete academic writing assignments related to the substance of their work.

title: Wastewater Treatment
description: Evaluation, selection, and design of wastewater treatment facilities.

title: Water Adv Treatment Process
description: Treatment and disposal of industrial wastes; basic industries and their waste problems.

title: Water Law
description: The course considers (1) state water law with a focus on the western United States, (2) public vs. private rights in water; and (3) allocation of water between the federal government, states, and Indian tribes.

title: Water Planet
description: This course is designed as a general education investigation of the importance of water to the existence of life on Earth, and the qualities of water that lead to its unusual but critical properties.

title: Water Polo
description: Course will focus on the techniques of water polo including rules, treading, and game play.

title: Water Resources Study Abroad
description: BYU students team with engineers and engineering students from other countries to work on water resources projects of consequence. Collaboration with international teams occurs electronically through the semester with a 1-3 week visit to the country assigned.

title: Water Safety Instructr Traing
description: Leads to American Red Cross WSI certification. Swimming teaching methods that include teaching swimming to special needs students.

title: Water Treatment Fac Design
description: Evaluation, selection, and design of water treatment facilities.

title: Watercolor for Non-Majors
description: Introduction to aqueous media.

title: Watershed Ecology
description: Applications in catchment hydrology and ecosystem ecology to quantify energy and nutrient flow through watersheds. An overview of major biogeochemical cycles. Identification and description of interactions between human society and health of soil, surface water, and groundwater.\n

title: Watershed Ecology Lab
description: Learning and applying principles of watershed ecology to address real-world questions and environmental problems.

title: Watershed Management
description: Processes and management of the hydrologic cycle of forests and rangelands.

title: Waveform Geophysics
description: Principles and methods used in seismic and ground-penetrating radar (GPR) geophysics, with petroleum exploration, engineering, environmental, and hydrological applications. Includes introduction to state-of-the-art industrial software applications for data processing and visualization.

title: Ways of Reading
description: Reading strategies course focused on fundamental concepts and practices of literary analysis.

title: Web and Social Media Analytics
description: Techniques for managing, exploring, visualizing, and analyzing web and social media data including social network analysis, search engine optimization, ethical treatment of social data, and web analytics research methods.

title: Web Design with CSS
description: Web design using Cascading Style Sheets including best practices, current trends, and accessibility standards. This 2nd-block course may be taken with the 1st-block course DigHT 251: Web Publishing with HTML.

title: Web Information Technologies
description: Using advanced web applications and services to create dynamic, database-driven Web sites. Integrating database methods with web publishing approaches and principles. Techniques for Web-based Digital Humanities applications such as crowd-sourced markup, automatic data visualizations, etc.

title: Web Localization
description: Exploration of the technology and challenges behind creating and managing multilingual web content, including multilingual input and Unicode, and localization testing.

title: Web Programming
description: Introduction to web application design and implementation. Both front end and back end development with an emphasis on REST architectures.

title: Web Publishing
description: Overview and introduction to web programming as a form of expression. Includes HTML, CSS, and some JavaScript.

title: Web Publishing with HTML
description: The fundamentals of web publishing with content management systems and HTML including syntax, validity, media, and accessibility. This 1st-block course may be taken with the 2nd-block course DigHT 252: Web Design with CSS

title: Web Systems & Security Part 1
description: Web technologies including web development and deployment tools, HTML, CSS, Javascript, session management and security, relational database concepts, architecture, testing and debugging; lifelong learning and written and visual technical communication.

title: Web Systems & Security
description: Web technologies including secure distributed architecture, web frameworks, document databases, systems administration and security, API development and testing, professional coding practices; life-long learning and written and visual communication.

title: Weidman Cntr Global Internship
description: Provides students international technical work experience under the guidance of an industry supervisor.

title: Weight Training
description: Weight training concepts and strategies. Specific exercises for a personalized strength training program including safety, fundamental skills, training considerations and general techniques for all lifts.

title: Welsh Choir
description: Enhance cultural appreciation and language skills through choral singing.

title: Western Am. St. Seminar
description: Advanced interdisciplinary seminar to deepen regional awareness and understanding of the American West.

title: Western Humanities 1
description: Western civilization from Greek antiquity to Renaissance from perspective of traditional humanistic values reflected in its arts and ideas. Examines fundamental questions about human experience, formative events in history, and value of important literary and artistic texts.

title: Western Humanities 2
description: Western civilization from Renaissance to present from perspective of traditional humanistic values reflected in its arts and ideas. Examines fundamental questions about human experience, formative events in history, and value of important literary and artistic texts.

title: Western Political Heritage 1
description: Western civilization from Greek antiquity to Renaissance, primarily from perspective of political philosophy and scriptures; exploring fundamental questions in human experience; examining formative events in history; understanding value of important texts.

title: Western Political Heritage 2
description: Western civilization from Renaissance to present, primarily from perspective of political philosophy; exploring fundamental questions in human experience; examining formative events in history; understanding value of important texts.

title: White Collar Crime
description: Explores what white collar crime is, what separates it from traditional street crime, and surveys many of the classic types of white collar crime. Covers various types of fraud and white collar offenses including ponzi schemes, money laundering, cyber crimes, healthcare fraud, securities fraud, and public corruption. Reviews the major state and federal statutes which are used to prosecute these crimes as well as reviewing key principles in the investigation of white collar crime such as investigative guidelines. Examines how to accurately assess and determine mens rea in a white collar case.

title: Wildlife Senior Seminar
description: Capstone course bringing together portfolios, student experiences, exams, and exercises necessary for completing and assessing wildlife and wildlands program learning outcomes.

title: Wildlife Behavioral Ecology
description: Integrating principles of ethology, sociobiology, and behavioral ecology using examples from wildlife resources; behavioral sampling methods.

title: Wildlife Law Enforcement
description: Current and historical principles of federal and state wildlife law enforcement, case development, evidence, evaluation, human rights, and testimony.

title: Wills and Estates
description: Transfer of property through intestate succession; wills and will substitutes; effect of community property ownership; legal and ethical issues surrounding end-of-life decisions, including living wills, medical directives, and medical powers of attorney; administration of decedents' estates.

title: Wireless Communicatn Circuits
description: Analysis, design, and fabrication of RF/microwave passive circuit structures, amplifiers, oscillators, and mixers.  System concepts, including stability, gain, and noise figure.

title: Wireless Networking
description: Principles and practices of wireless networks, including design, implementation, protocols, and applications. Examination and comparison of popular wireless protocols.

title: Women and Global Migration
description: Understanding how gender affects im/migration trends, laws, policies, patterns, and migrants' lived experiences, especially for women. Examination of how migration occurs on a voluntary and involuntary basis between, within, and across borders, and interrogate the role of sovereignty, liberalism, and citizenship in facilitating  or limiting -- the mass movement of women, their families, and communities.  Includes a service component. With instructor approval, students may identify and participate in a service opportunity of their own choosing that relates to women and migration. Alternatively, students may participate in service opportunities identified by the professors or other class members.

title: Women and Global Migration
description: Exploration of how gender affects im/migration trends, laws, policies, patterns, and migrants' lived experiences, especially for women, and how migration occurs on a voluntary and involuntary basis between, within, and across borders. An examination of the role of sovereignty, liberalism, and citizenship in facilitating  or limiting -- the mass movement of women, their families, and communities.

title: Women and Philosophy
description: Women philosophers and important women in the history of philosophy and/or feminist or gender-based philosophical inquiry in contemporary philosophy (e.g., feminist epistemology). Topics vary.

title: Women in a Changing World
description: Examines women in particular historical settings, how womenâ€™s lives changed over time, and how women actively shaped their own lives as well as the societies in which they lived.

title: Women in Art
description: History of women artists, critics, and patrons, along with women in representation in Western art.  Consideration of theories and methodologies of feminist art history.

title: Women in French Literature
description: Analysis of the contributions of women in French and/or Francophone literature. Assessment of the representations of women in French literary texts.

title: Women in Science
description: Women scientists, their challenges, and their contributions to scientific knowledge in many fields.

title: Women in the Scriptures
description: A close examination of stories and writings about women found within the scriptural canon of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, focusing on the contributions of biblical women to the life, culture, religion, and history of Israel and the interpretation of their stories over time.

title: Women Who Made a Difference
description: This course focuses on a woman or a small group of women who have made important contributions in their fields, within their cultures, and/or to society locally or globally.

title: Women Writers in Portuguese
description: Readings and research about women writers in Portuguese and their texts.

title: Women Writers in Spanish
description: Readings and research about women writers in Spanish and their texts.

title: Women's Chorus
description: Draws on works from the vast repertoire for treble voices.  Audition required.

title: Women's Health
description: Overview of selected health topics affecting women's health status.  Primary emphasis on steps to enhance personal health and fulfill divine roles from childhood through adulthood.

title: Women's Studies Seminar
description: Exploration and discussion of works created by women and of other texts that participate in discourses of gender. Training in different types of research methodology, including archival work and text recovery. Completion of a research paper that combines original research and review of pertinent secondary sources.

title: Woodwinds
description: Private or semiprivate instruction. One to two hours of daily practice

title: Work and Family
description: Research and practical application related to successfully harmonizing one's family and work lives.

title: Work and Family
description: Introduction to contemporary work/family issues. Framework for helping parents and managers deal effectively with work/family issues at work and home.

title: Families in Communities
description: How family life and employment interact with each other and with other community contexts (school, church, government, recreation, media, the economy, and health care, etc.) in patterns of mutual influence.

title: Vulnerable & Diverse Poplns
description: Developing skills and building competency in working effectively with vulnerable and diverse populations in domestic settings. Emphasis on cultural competency and cross-cultural communication skills, and their application in the variety of settings where health care and public health professionals work.

title: Works of H C Andersen
description: Study of the life, works, and times of Danish author Hans Christian Andersen.

title: Workshop 1: Acting
description: Experience in production: acting.

title: Wkshop in App Tech Educ
description: Teaching and learning technological literacy skills. Reviewing and participating in current technological advances, with a focus on teaching practice and methods.

title: Workshop in Ballroom
description: Workshop in teaching methodologies and/or research of ballroom dance.

title: Workshop in MFT
description: Training in delivery of and research about psychoeducational programs for couples and families.

title: Wkshp in MFHD
description: Intensive study in applying principles of specified family sciences, subject matter in early childhood education, child development, family relationships, family resource management, or marriage/family therapy.

title: Worksite Health Promotion
description: Managing, designing, marketing, implementing, assessing, and administering health promotion programs in a worksite setting.

title: World Civilization from 1500
description: World civilization from Renaissance to present; explores fundamental questions in the human experience, examines formative events in history, and seeks to teach value of important texts.

title: World Civilization Since 1500
description: Survey of Western civilization emphasizing the visual arts from the Renaissance to the twentieth century.

title: World Civilization to 1500
description: World civilization from Greek antiquity to Renaissance; explores fundamental questions in the human experience, examines formative events in history, and seeks to teach value of important texts.

title: World Civilization to 1500
description: Survey of Western civilization emphasizing the visual arts from ancient Greece to the Gothic period.

title: World Literatures in English
description: Study of the literature of a given world region or culture.

title: World Music
description: Exploration of music making from a global perspective.

title: World Music Cultures
description: Traditional music of selected cultures of Asia, Oceania, Africa, Europe, and the Americas, including both folk and art music traditions.

title: World Populations
description: Fertility, mortality, and migration patterns of world populations as they relate to current social, economic, political, and religious issues.

title: World Religions
description: Doctrines, teachings, world views, and practices of the world's great religions, including Christianity, Islam, Judaism, Buddhism, Hinduism, Confucianism, Sikhism, and Bahai.

title: World Religion & Area Analysis
description: Focuses on the various Islams (Sunni, Shia, and Sufi) and groups of interest (Hezbolah, al-Qaeda, Taliban, etc.) and how they influence areas of interest (e.g., Middle East).

title: World Rel & Security Analysis
description: Focuses on how religion influences our national policy and more specifically provides a framework for assessing how religion impacts the military operational environment where chaplains advise commanders.

title: WW II in History & Memory
description: Explores the causes, flow, and the global significance of the Second World War, emphasizing U.S. experiences in the European and Pacific theatres. Fosters the skills necessary to analyze the war through the perspectives of military and political figures, the "Greatest Generation," and voices beyond the battlefields.

title: WDA Workshop
description: Collaborative workshop developing new stage and screenplays through exercises, discussion, and writing. Scripts selected competitively; public readings at end of course.

title: Writing About Literature
description: Methods of literary interpretation.  Reading, writing, and research skills integral to the literary analysis expected in German major courses. Taught in German or English, depending on instructor.

title: Writing abt Art & Humanities
description: Writing for both academic and mass audiences about the functions, meanings, values, and qualities of art and the humanities. Library research paper.

title: Writing & Rhetoric
description: Writing and research with a focus on inquiry, information literacy, rhetorical awareness, genre knowledge, and reflection. Emphasizes writing as a flexible process and writers as curious, open, and charitable.

title: Writing Branded Content
description: Principles and practices of writing persuasive content for multiple media platforms.

title: Writing Creative Nonfiction
description: Creations of style and technique in prose nonfiction; discipline and practice of the writer.

title: Writing Fiction
description: Creation of style and technique in prose fiction; discipline and practice of the writer.

title: Writing for Animation
description: Traditional screenwriting emphasizing stories for the medium of animation.

title: Writing for Child & Adolescent
description: Theory and practice of writing prose and verse for youth readership. Specific attention to requirements of picture books, middle-grade novels, and young adult stories.

title: Writing for News Media
description: Principles and practices of writing news content for multiple media platforms.

title: Writing in Physics
description: Writing scientific and technical articles and proposals. Writing and presentation skills applied to senior thesis or capstone project. Resources and guidelines for publishing in physics.

title: Writing in the Social Sciences
description: Writing characteristic of disciplines that inquire into human behavior and institutions; correspondence, proposals, library paper, empirical research, and reviews.

title: Writing Instruction
description: Topics vary.

title: Writing Literary Criticism
description: Research and writing about literature, including disciplinary conventions and expectations.

title: Writing Poetry
description: Creation of style and technique in poetry; discipline and practice of the poet.

title: Multilingual Writing Tutorial
description: L2 and other multilingual writers will be paired with a trained Writing Center undergraduate peer tutor who will meet with them weekly throughout the semester, supporting them in their writing goals, helping them refine their writing processes, and providing them with feedback and focused collaborative experiences related to their writing.

title: Writing with Style
description: Developing stylistic competency and range in nonfiction writing, especially at the sentence and paragraph levels.

title: Writing Within Psychology
description: Processes of research-oriented writing and presentation for psychology majors.

title: Writings of Isaiah
description: Teachings and prophecies of Isaiah in light of their historical context and relevance to latter-day people.

title: Intro Global Women's Studies
description: An introduction to the most important issues affecting women's lives and to contributions made by women both nationally and internationally.  The course will include historical, sociological, psychological, theological, legal, and/or cultural, and other approaches.

title: X-ray Diffraction
description: This course will explore how X-rays can be used to characterize the atomic structure of solid, crystalline materials. Students will learn the fundamental concepts of crystallography and will gain practical, hands-on experience with both single crystal (SC-XRD) and powder (P-XRD) diffraction techniques.

title: X-Ray Physics
description: Physical characteristics of X-ray generation, optics, and experimental applications. Methods of X-ray imaging emphasized.

title: Yoga
description: Yoga teaches how to exercise and/or meditate in order to unify the mind, body and spirit, feeling quiet in your mind, strong and energized in your body, and peaceful in your spirit.

title: Yoga & Alexander Technique
description: Techniques of relaxation, breath, focus, and posture to enhance actor's body and voice as a whole integrated tool in performance.

title: Young Adult Literature
description: Literature written for or read by teenagers.

title: Young Ambassadors
description: Participation as soloists, coaches, or directors in music dance theatre performances.

title: Young Adult Novel Workshop
description: Writing for young adult readers. Individual consideration of manuscripts.

title: Zumba
description: Zumba Fitness is a dance exercise program designed to bring about an increase in total body fitness for participants of all levels of condition, ability, and needs.
